TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the Minister for Defence Support (Mr Viner) left Australia on 22 October to attend the South Pacific Conference in Western Samoa and to visit several South East Asian countries for ministerial discussions. The Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman) is acting as Minister for Defence Support until Mr Viner returns.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROBERTSON; TATE

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of my colleague Senator Tate I present the following petition from 17 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) that United States, Australian and allied forces used huge amounts of toxic chemicals for military purposes, such as Agents Orange, Blue and White, in Vietnam during the war there;
(2) many of these chemicals were, and are, known to be highly dangerous to human health;
(3) Australia's Vietnam veterans and their families are suffering many severe problems which may be due to their exposure to these chemicals; and
(4) the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia has been seeking a Royal Commission for well over two years to ensure an independent investigation of these matters.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Parliament of Australia will:
(a) express its support for the Royal Commission; and
(b) urge the Federal Government to establish the Royal Commission immediately.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MACKLIN

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 120 citizens of Australia :

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That your Petitioners do not want a Uranium Enrichment Plant constructed in South-East Queensland because:
(a) there is no known way of safely storing uranium waste products;
(b) there has not been an environment impact study conducted into the effects of such a Uranium Enrichment Plant;
(c) Australia has adequate coal supplies to provide energy for industry;
(d) the risks to local inhabitants from the operation of such a plant have not been established;
(e) the products of such a plant will contribute to the prospect of nuclear war ;
(f) the local area would become a target in the event of such a nuclear war;
(g) the investment in such a Uranium Enrichment Plant would be better spent in research into clean, renewable energy sources such as solar energy.
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
(a) legislate to give power to the Commonwealth Parliament to make decisions on the export of products from Uranium Enrichment Plants;
(b) reject all applications for the export of products from Uranium Enrichment Plants;
(c) legislate to give power to the Commonwealth Parliament to make decisions on foreign investment in Uranium Enrichment Plants;
(d) reject all applications for foreign investment in Uranium Enrichment Plants ;
(e) do all in the Senate's power to prevent the construction of a Uranium Enrichment Plant in South-East Queensland.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BJELKE-PETERSEN

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 19 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of Queensland respectfully showeth:
That the plan by the Australian Telecommunications Commission to withdraw public telegram facilities and downgrade telegram standards by:
1. planning to withdraw the 24 hour telegraph service at the Chief Telegraph Office in each capital city and in Canberra and Darwin
2. closing country telegraph offices
3. increasing telegram charges whilst downgrading the service
4. withdrawing telegram operating facilities from a large number of suburban and country post offices
5. generating serious delays in telegram delivery by reducing standards of service through centralisation of the network and reduction of operating and delivery staff

will reduce an available means of communications in commercial enterprise, deny the opportunity for people of Australia to make contact with family and friends in times of emergency, and civil or natural disasters, particularly for the 30 per cent of Australians who are not telephone subscribers.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will take measures to ensure the maintenance of an efficient, effective public telegram service to meet the needs of the Australian people socially, publicly, commercially and in times of emergencies and civil or natural disasters.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at proposed future hydro-electric developments in South West Tasmania. As this area is on the Register of the National Estate it is therefore of national concern and your petitioners humbly call upon the Senate to conduct a Senate Inquiry into South West Tasmania. SPEECH.SPEAKER: KEEFFE

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 777 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:
The Great Barrier Reef is unique and is included on the World Heritage List.

Although the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act was to create a marine park to provide for the proper protection and management of The Reef, only 14 per cent of the total area defined in this Act as the Great Barrier Reef Region has been declared marine park.
The only insurance against an oil drilling blowout in Reef waters is to prohibit oil drilling in the Region and its vicinity.
This can only be effected by declaring the whole area of the Region a marine park under the above legislation.

Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Government to take action to hold a referendum together with the next Federal Elections on the question that:

'The entire area of the Great Barrier Reef and its surrounding waters, defined as the Great Barrier Reef Region in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975, as amended 1978, be immediately declared a marine park under the provisions of that Act'.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Crichton-Browne (from 38 citizens) and Reid (from 648 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Church of Mary Queen of Peace, Lithuania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That the Church of Mary Queen of Peace Klaipeda, Lithuania was the only church permitted (by the Soviet authorities) to be built in post-war Lithuania.
That the church was built by the Catholic parishioners from their own resources and with support from overseas Christians.
That upon completion of the church building in 1960, the church was not allowed to be consecrated and, in 1961 was resumed by the State for purposes other than religious.

That this resumption of the church and the subsequent persecution and arrests of the local clergy and other christians is contrary to the spirit and the letter of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the International Covenant on Human Rights.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled request the Australian Government to communicate most strongly to the Government of the USSR the sympathy of the petitioners for the plight of the Lithuanian Christians and ask that the Church of Mary Queen of Peace be restored to the Catholics of Klaipeda for the practice of their religion without interference.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned citizens of Australia, concerned about the high and increasing rate of divorce and family breakdown, convinced that the Family Law Act has weakened marriage by making divorce a trivial matter, the present Act paying scant regard to its own definition of marriage as a life-long union; and
believing that the legal bond of marriage should be strengthened
humbly petition for the Family Law Act and the Marriage Act to be amended in order to reject any moves towards divorce by post.
Restore the former prohibition of marriages between close relatives by blood or marriage.
Protect the rights and welfare of aggrieved partners of a marriage who are threatened with being divorced against their will.
Ensure that in divorce judgments paramount attention be given to whatever course will best serve the welfare of dependent children of the marriage.
Encourage counselling towards reconciliation.
Restore objective tests to irretrievable breakdown of marriage in terms of:
i. intolerable behaviour; ii. desertion for two years; iii. separation for three years.
And we pray that you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our nation .
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Sir John Carrick (from 66 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Arts Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. Federal Government funding to the performing arts through the Australia Council has declined since 1974 by 39 per cent in real money terms.
2. Unless this funding is substantially increased in forthcoming federal budgets, many companies will be forced to cease operations and the performing arts will eventually wither and die.
3. A healthy and variegated performing arts scene is vital to any country that claims to be civilised.
4. The people of Queensland, particularly, value the performing arts and believe that without them, their lives would be significantly impoverished.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the government will substantially increase funding to the performing arts and will not allow the decline to continue at the alarming rate that has characterised the past seven years from 0 .12 per cent of total government outlays in 1974-75 to 0.07 per cent in 1981-82. And that the present single line appropriations are rescinded and the distribution of federal arts funding is left in the hands of the Australia Council.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Importation of Marine Mammal By-products
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that:
1. Since the Australian Whale Protection Act 1980 provides for the banning of importation into Australia of all whale byproducts, and
2. the Prime Minister has stated that he and his Government support the international banning of whaling,
3. then consistent with (1) and (2), this Government should immediately legislate to ban the importation of all marine mammal byproducts, including the harp seal of Canada, and

4. through the Australian delegate in the United Nations General Assembly, the Prime Minister should state his Government's support for an international ban on the slaughter of any marine mammal for commercial reasons.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that consistent with legislation on whaling, this Government should ban the importation of marine mammal byproducts and support an international ban on slaughter of any marine mammal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tasmanian Wilderness Areas
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate, in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at proposed hydro-electric developments in South West Tasmania. As this area is on the register of the National Estate it is of national concern and your petitioners humbly call upon the Senate to suport the recommendations of the Select Committee of Inquiry into South West Tasmania.

Your petitioners also call upon the Federal Parliament not to allocate or allow funds to be raised for construction of dams in the South West of Tasmania but to provide such funds as would enable the preservation of this area. This is a national asset and Tasmanians should not be made to bear any financial burden resulting from its preservation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TOWNLEY

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I table a petitioning letter signed by 36 citizens of Tasmania calling for the Franklin River to be declared an inviolable national park. I ask leave of the Senate to have the text of the letter incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
14th October 1982.
Senator Michael Townley,
The Senate,
Parliament House,
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
Dear Senator Townley,
PRIVATE MEMBERS BILL. SOUTH-WEST TASMANIA As Tasmanians we are appealing to you to support the proposed private members bill, declaring the Franklin River ''an inviolable national park''.

When Mr Gray became leader of the State Parliamentary Liberal Party, he announced the No. 1 policy was an ''immediate start to negotiations with the Federal Government to have Bass Strait declared a strike free national sea road, backed by State and Federal legislation''. This was deemed essential to promote business confidence to invest in Tasmania.

After gaining Government this policy has been shelved in favour of the emotional appeal of the ''Dam is Essential for Survival''. (Examiner Oct. 11). The dam is to be a panacea which will automatically ensure business investment for the State.
While the World economy is expected to improve, will boom conditions in mining and metal industries return to Australia? These industries were the principal users of the State's electricity.

Experts have pointed out that a South-West power scheme has a longer lead time than a thermal power station. The Turnbull Report (Sept 81) is even more relevant today. ''The State could be faced with the bleak prospect of attempting to sell off an excess of expensive, non competitive power''.
We have a Premier who has tried to correct the former Labor Government's economic mismanagement, but he has shown his inexperience in his handling of the South-West issue.

We are a State of only 427,300 people, reliant on the goodwill of mainland people. Is it rational that Mr Gray should antagonise the media and people of the mainland inorder to safeguard jobs for hydro construction workers?

It is time the Federal Government took action concerning Mr Gray's barrage of public statements-the warnings to Mr Fraser to keep out of the South-West, and threats of secession from the Commonwealth. For how long should a Federal Government be subservient to a Premier representing only 3% of Australia's population?

If we accept World Heritage Listing, The South-West would become only the thirtieth natural area so listed. Surely this would benefit all Australia, and particularly Tasmania. Overseas people would become aware of Tasmania as a place of scenic beauty, worthy of inclusion in an overseas tour.
At stake is a power station with a small generating capacity (180 m.w.) which would cause desecration of an area of ''irreplaceable'' beauty and flood the Franklin valley caves.
Naturalists and Scientists throughout the world have proclaimed that if Australia allows this destruction to occur, it will be guilty of an act of gross vandalism.

We sincerely trust that the proposed Bill will not be shelved or evaded on any technical ground-but will gain the support of patriotic Government members, who place the future inheritance of Australians, above placating an inexperienced Premier who mistakes belligerency for strength.

The Young Liberal Movement expresses the concern of all thinking members of the younger generation. The Gray Government shows no respect for the Senate, and is proceeding with the power scheme regardless of what the Senate Select Committee may report.
These circumstances call for strong action by Federal Parliament now.
