TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government. Is it a fact that the allocation for the Government Information Unit this year is to rise to $1.4 m, an increase of $1m over 1981-82? Can the Minister say why such a large increase is occurring? Will he give the Senate an assurance that no officer of the Government Information Unit has undertaken or will be undertaking work directly for the Liberal Party?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter actually does not come within my jurisdiction, so I cannot comment directly with regard to the figures. I think it comes within the responsibility of the Department of Administrative Services but that may need to be checked. Therefore, I cannot be sure as to the actual figures. I understand that the Government intends, as previous governments have done, to use advertising to indicate to people in social security circumstances that the benefits for them should be known and should be known to be available. I understand that Australian Labor Party front bench senators have advocated that there should be more expenditure in terms of advertising social security benefits. This would apply also no doubt to tax benefits. Therefore, there is only good in what will be done. As to the rest of the question, I will refer it to the responsible Minister and ask him to give it consideration.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question. Is the Leader of the Government in the Senate not in a position to say whether the Government Information Unit, which is paid for by the taxpayers of this country, has been or will be used for Liberal Party propaganda purposes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, as you will distinguish, that is an entirely new question. Therefore, it is not one that I was asked before. I am in a position to say that the Government takes the view that government employees should be used for government purposes. I have no doubt that is the principle that will be adopted.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Is the Minister aware of a statement by the Western Australian Minister for Resources Development, Mr Jones, which appeared in the Australian newspaper on Monday, 25 October 1982, that the Federal Government's welfare policies were not working and should be reviewed and that food stamps and only a small amount of cash should be given to Aborigines instead of the dole? I ask: Will the Minister contact Mr Jones and inform him that Aborigines are Australian citizens and are entitled to the same benefits as all other Australians? Further, will the Minister inform Mr Jones that the Federal Government's Aboriginal Affairs policies are working because of successive caring and understanding Ministers for Aboriginal Affairs in the Fraser Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not familiar with the statement which is attributed to Mr Jones, the Minister for Resources Development in Western Australia. I do not think it is a communication to me. I would be grateful if Senator Bonner would let me have a look at the statement which is attributed to Mr Jones. As far as the Government's welfare policies and their application to Aboriginal Australians are concerned, it was true for a long time that social welfare benefits which were available to Australians generally were not available to Aboriginal people. One of the substantial changes which have occurred over the last decade or more has been the genuine effort to extend the same benefits to Aboriginal people in the social security field as are available to other Australians. Occasionally it remains a matter of some difficulty.

ANSWER.PARA: The employment of Aboriginal liaison officers in areas where there is a substantial Aboriginal population is one of the measures which have been taken to try to ensure that Aboriginal Australians do get the same benefits as other Australians from the social security system. In that sense, the Department of Social Security tries to do no more and no less for Aboriginal Australians than for any other Australian. Certainly, we do not discriminate between different sections of the Australian population. In general, the Government has taken the view that social security beneficiaries are entitled to receive their income maintenance in the same form as other Australians receive wages-in other words, as cash payments. It is not for the Government to determine how social security beneficiaries should use the resources which are made available to them. The general rule that is followed by the Commonwealth is to provide income maintenance in the form of cash, which gives the recipient the maximum freedom to exercise his or her own judgment on how to spend or use those resources. If Mr Jones did say something like that, he was probably referring to the fact that there are situations in which there is room for concern about problems which have followed the availability of cash incomes in some Aboriginal communities. There are areas where there are problems with, for example, excessive drinking, which is of great concern. This is an area in which this Parliament has made an extensive committee inquiry to try to find out some of the answers.

There are some Aboriginal initiatives in this area. In a number of areas the Aboriginal people have requested lump sum payments or an arrangement for social security benefits which enables a community administration of benefit. There is the Community Development Employment Project, which is a variation on the normal social security arrangements. In South Australia, again at the request of Aboriginal people, arrangements have been made for the payment of social security benefits to the Aboriginal Housing Board, which deducts rental payments and pays the balance of the social security payment to the beneficiary. The same arrangement is being developed or explored in Western Australia by a committee of the Aboriginal Housing Board. I spoke with housing Ministers in Darwin last week about the possible extension of that arrangement.

I am sorry to give such a long answer. I suppose I was not wanting to get to the point at which Senator Bonner was recording the fact that Aboriginal Affairs policies are working because of the wonderful succession of Liberal Ministers that we have had. Modesty prohibits my endorsing that with too much enthusiasm. But it is a fact, I think, that in this difficult area there are significant areas of progress. One is that in general governments, both Labor and Liberal, have tried to extend to Aboriginal people the same benefits as other Australians are entitled to. I believe that that is the rule which all Australians would wish us to follow.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Treasurer seen the report on the Australian economy prepared by the Commonwealth Bank for the Metal Trades Industry Association? Does this report, in part, lay the blame for the downturn in the metal trades industry, which is particularly severe in Newcastle and Wollongong, on the decline in the housing industry due to the Government's high interest rate policies, weakening consumer spending and deferred resource projects, all caused by the Government's inflation-first approach?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have not seen the report from the Commonwealth Bank. If it says precisely what Senator Childs has said, I think it overlooks the fact that interest rates reflect many things and not just government policy. The cost of money is something that reflects the economic circumstances which exist and the considerable assistance that has been given by the Government in the present Budget to those who are seeking home loans or those who have home loans ought to be taken into account in any statement of the kind that has just been made. I will see whether the Treasurer has any comment on the statement or whether there is an official statement along the lines that have been mentioned in the question.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. Is it not an irony that one day we have people clamouring for a shorter working week and higher wages and the next day they are fighting retrenchments? How does the Government propose on the one hand to implement a mechanism and to explain to the average working man that wages must be related to productivity and the capacity of industry to pay and, on the other hand, to ensure that industry maintains an efficient operation using up-to-date equipment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose one could say that there is some irony in a situation in which there is a very determined campaign to reduce working hours and hence increase the unit cost of labour-a campaign that has succeeded to some extent- followed by a period in which there is a considerable shedding of labour, in part because of the difficulty that many sections of industry have in profitably employing labour at the current cost. I suppose it is fair to point out that there is some irony in that situation. It seems to me that it is an irony that is likely, unfortunately, to escape many people. There appears to be very great difficulty in many parts of Australian society in recognising the significance of the cost of labour in determining just how much employment there can be.

ANSWER.PARA: I think that most of us welcomed the acknowledgement in difficult times that Australia had in 1974, when Frank Crean was Treasurer, when he made the point that one man's wage rise could be another man's job. That is a view which I am sure was not expressed by Mr Crean in a sense that was meant to be anti-labour or against the work force, but was simply an acknowledgement of the simple arithmetic that if labour cannot be employed at a profit, labour will not be employed, and if the price of labour gets beyond what will be produced by that labour, we shall get unemployment.

I make that point because as recently as this morning Mr Dolan, in an interview on the national Today show, was making statements which seem to indicate that he does not see the cost of labour as being particularly relevant. But that is a view which I think very few people in this chamber would share, if they express their honest views. I think that there is a growing understanding of the fact that the cost of labour is a significant element in Australia's ability to compete internationally and to maintain a growing economy. I think that the successive statements of members of the Government have been an attempt to bring home that reality to the Australian public. I think that all of us, though, have a part to play in trying to get that fact known and understood. It would be the wish of everyone in this chamber, without dispute, to have a much higher level of employment in Australia than we have today. There are disputes in this chamber about how we can bring about that higher level of employment, but there should be no dispute about the fact that one of the factors-I pick up one of the points that is made-in determining how many people will be employed in Australia is the cost of employing people at any time, including today.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to you, Mr President. Before continuing, I should like to express my admiration for the restraint and good sense shown by the officers of the Australian Federal Police in King's Hall and outside Parliament House yesterday. Mr President, I ask whether you would agree to table the current rules of police conduct in Parliament House. I further ask: Do the rules of police conduct agreed between the Presiding Officers of this Parliament and the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police suggest that police officers should not be armed in the precints of Parliament House without the express permission of the Presiding Officers? Was such express permission given to those members of the Police Force who were carying side arms during yesterday's demonstration in King's Hall? Finally, in what circumstances and under whose authority would the use of firearms be permitted in Parliament House?

—In response to your question, Senator, I shall obtain the guidelines with regard to the activities of police officers within the parliamentary building. Perhaps I may say that under normal circumstances police officers divest themselves of any firearms before they enter the building. I shall make inquiries into the matter that you have raised with regard to firearms in this building yesterday, and I shall report at a later date. I should like to add one other thing to your comment in leading up to your question, Senator. I would also, from the Chair, support the remarks that you made, and those of other honourable senators in response to your remarks, with regard to the conduct of the police officers yesterday. They are to be commended for the way in which they carried out their duties.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation. Is the Minister aware that commercial pilot examinations are held only three times a year and that it takes up to six weeks after such an examination for candidates to receive results from the Department? Whilst I realise that some people take those examinations purely out of a desire to obtain a supplementary licence, most people are wanting to become involved in flying for a livelihood and need the licences before they can do that. As the airlines have an upper limit for the age beyond which they will not accept applicants, the limited number of examinations and the slowness of the publication of the results limits a pilot's chance of being accepted by an airline. Will the Minister ascertain whether commercial pilot licence examinations can be held more frequently? If not, why not? Can the marking of such examinations be speeded up?

—I am not in a position to confirm or comment otherwise on the point made in Senator Townley's question in connection with the delay in receiving results from pilot examinations. I undertake to check that information and bring a reply down on that point. The essential element of the question relates to the need for people to have speedy results from examinations to put themselves in a position to be able to earn income and to take opportunities as they arise in the aviation industry. I believe that to be most important and I will certainly refer it to the Minister for his direct comment.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. It is a fact that Tasmania has the highest unemployment and also the lowest average weekly wage of any Australian State? Is this not a contradiction of the Treasurer's many statements that high wages are the cause of unemployment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I do not see any conflict in the statement of the Treasurer that high wages are the cause of many instances of unemployment because unless some commodities are produced at competitive prices they will not find their way into the market. Wage levels and productivity need to be looked at in comparing prices of similar goods processed elsewhere. It is a fact that Tasmania has low levels of employment and this is of great concern to all Australians. It may also be a fact that Tasmania has the lowest average weekly wage, but unless Tasmania is able to find markets competitively for goods which it is able to produce, there will not be opportunities for increased employment in that State.

ANSWER.PARA: A number of things that the State Government has been attempting to do in recent weeks and months are directed towards increasing employment opportunities . I do not think that taking the two factors mentioned by Senator Hearn together one could come to the conclusion that there is some conflict in statements that have been made by the Treasurer on the subject at large.

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate by drawing his attention to the remark attributed to the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Hayden, in Adelaide last Friday, that a Labor Federal government would at least maintain the real level of Federal grants to the States. I ask: What is the Liberal Government's policy as regards grants to the States and what is the Government's record in this area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not see a report of Mr Hayden's remarks. Those who today read the Australian Financial Review editorial of the analysis of Mr Hayden's policies would draw no consolation either for the States or for the community as a whole. The editorial said that the policy he has been advocating is one of disaster for the people of Australia. The Commonwealth Government's relationship with the States is one of revenue sharing. It is interesting that the former Premier of South Australia, Mr Dunstan, at a State Labor conference in 1974, said that the Federal Labor policy of centralised funding was wrong and that the only solution would be revenue sharing based upon a fixed percentage of income tax. That is in fact what this Government is doing. The fact of the matter is that it is the overall policy of government that counts. I commend to the people of Australia the comments on the quite outrageous policies that are being put forward which are, of course, recipes for disaster.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer, refers to my question to her of 21 September regarding the crisis in the film industry resulting from the failure of the Government's tax concession scheme, section 10BA of the Income Tax Assessment Act, to attract investment because of the continuation of schemes utilising section 51 of the Act to offer a 375 per cent tax concession for investment in American films. Is the Minister aware that since that time the crisis in the local industry has deepened and that yesterday Film Australia decided to postpone a feature film project which was one of the only two major feature film projects in Victoria? Given the massive confusion now surrounding the whole question of tax concessions and investment policy will the Government make a clear statement of its film investment taxation policy so that the Australian industry can be saved from total disaster?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I recall Senator Ryan's earlier question. I think we have seen a great deal of public comment on the difficulties of the film industry and the use of section 10BA and section 51 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. There have been features on public affairs programs on the matter. I think probably there is a fair understanding now of the difficulties that were referred to in the earlier question asked by Senator Ryan. As I understand it, representatives of the film industry recently met the Treasurer. I believe he undertook to set up a working party to look at the matters that were raised. Amongst them were those that Senator Ryan has now raised again. I am not aware of the stage the working party has reached, but I will make inquiries. I think the Treasurer recognises the urgency of the matters raised with him. I assume that that working party is collecting information so that some action may be taken by the Government. I am not aware of the Australian Film Commission's recent abandonment of a feature film. I will see whether I can get further early information on the matter from the Treasurer. It is a matter actively under his consideration.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs aware that Mr Laszlo Irhazi has been outside Parliament House now for nearly two weeks on a hunger strike? Is the Minister aware that Mr Irhazi is seeking from the communist Hungarian Government the release of his wife and children and that he asks that a passport be issued to them to enable them to come to Australia? As the Australian Government has issued the appropriate entry permits, will the Minister see that the Government does everything possible to influence the Hungarian Government to issue a passport to enable Mrs Irhazi and her children to come to Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I think we are all aware of the hunger striker and what has been occurring in front of Parliament House. As I understand it, he is attempting to induce the Hungarian Government to allow his wife and children to leave Hungary and to join him in Australia. The Australian Government sympathises with the frustration which Mr Irhazi must feel in being separated from his family but the Minister for Foreign Affairs does not believe that a hunger strike is the best way of overcoming this problem. The Minister hopes that Mr Irhazi can be pursuaded to discontinue this course of action.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Embassy in Vienna is presently making inquiries about the case with the Hungarian authorities. The Government will do whatever it can to assist the reunion of Mr Irhazi with his family. I repeat that it is tragic and distresses all those who are involved when hunger strikes are undertaken. However, the Hungarian Government must take action. The only thing that the Government can do is to make strong representations to try to assist the persons in Australia to have their cases dealt with by those in other countries. As I have said, we will do whatever we can to assist but we do regret that this means has been chosen to draw attention to the distress of this family.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Social Security whether the automatic adjustment to pensions will not take into account the September quarter increase in the consumer price index of 3.5 per cent until May next year. In view of the increased costs to be incurred by pensioners between now and next May could the Government make some interim adjustment to pensions to take the September quarter increase into account?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —For about eight years now-except in one year I think-there have been biannual adjustments of pension. In each case, the pension has been adjusted in November and May. To the best of my recollection, it has always been adjusted on the basis of whatever the rate of inflation was. The November adjustment reflects the rate of inflation up to the preceding June quarter and the May adjustment relates to the December quarter figure. Therefore, the answer to the first part of the question is, yes, it is a fact that that is when the adjustment will take effect.

ANSWER.PARA: I think, though, there is some false arithmetic in the sort of calculation which is made by Senator Colston and which, indeed, is made by many people who raise this point. If, for example, Australia experienced a constant rate of inflation of, say, 10 per cent and that figure was evenly 2 1/2 per cent per quarter, it would not matter which quarter one took in making those biannual adjustments because the result would be exactly the same. In other words, when we set the pension rate in August 1976 to take effect in November 1976 and said we would adjust it twice a year thereafter, if the inflation rate is constant it makes no difference which quarter or which half year we choose on which to make the adjustment. So, one is behind only if in some sense it is suggested that the initial setting of the pension was behind. I think that there is some false arithmetic there. If inflation is falling, the further back one takes the adjustment the larger the adjustment to the pension will be. If inflation is rising, there is some temporary loss to pensioners of whatever the difference is between the six-monthly rate to December and the six-monthly rate to the March quarter.

So, the answer to the second part of the question is that, whilst the Government could make an additional adjustment, I do not think that that is likely and I would not wish to raise hopes that would be likely to be dashed. In fact, the pensions have, as I have said, on a very regular basis now been adjusted twice a year on the basis of a six-month period of inflation. I think the fact that we have chosen for administrative ease a measure which is separated in time from the date of adjustment does give rise to the sort of unfortunate impression that is in the question. But I do not think the reality is there.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: EFFECT OF COST INCREASES ON EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations a question. Having regard to the fact that Australia is fundamentally a trading economy where we export rural, resource, secondary and tertiary items and import a wide variety of goods and services, I ask: Is it not true that every increase in costs, be it wages or others, both reduces our export opportunities and makes imports cheaper against our home manufacturers with growing, disastrous results on employment opportunities throughout Australia?
—With fixed world exchange rates.

—If the Minister is convinced that this is the case, could he arrange to have the matter explained as simply as possible to the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, Mr Cliff Dolan, who on television today said that no one had ever put facts and figures together for him so that he could understand this position?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question touches on a comment of Mr Dolan this morning which I mentioned in responding to a question asked by Senator Watson earlier during Question Time. Mr Dolan is reported as saying this morning-and I quote from a transcript:

ANSWER.PARA: I would think that the next figures will show at least 8 per cent, that means there are still 92 per cent of the workforce employed, and those people, as I say, are seeking to maintain their real wages and their standard of living even at this time. Now I'm, you know, nobody has ever been able to convince me, and all the rhetoric about wage increases meaning loss of jobs, no one has ever put facts and figures to show that this is the position, or that it would be the position, and that, you know, one job would be created by virtue of a reduction in wages.

That was the statement of Mr Dolan this morning to which I referred which does fly in the face of views put by Mr Crean during a period in which we were in similar difficulties in the sense of having sharply rising unemployment. The view put by Mr Crean was that one man's wage rise could be another man's job. I think the facts which are brought out by Senator Archer in his question are one of the illustrations of why that can be so. If Australia's cost of production increasingly rises as against the cost rises of our trading competitors, obviously our competitive position slips. An interjection was made by, I think, Senator Walsh that the basic proposition being put by Senator Archer in his question would apply only in a situation of fixed exchange rates. Of course, the movement of exchange rates does affect the competitive position of Australian goods overseas. But if we are to be constantly adjusting our exchange rate because of Australia's declining competitive position that, in itself, will affect the standard of living in Australia and the real incomes of Australians in a way that will be quite counter-productive. I believe Senator Walsh would agree that it is a fact that, notwithstanding exchange rate adjustments, if our competitive position generally is shifting against us we, as a very substantial trading nation, will suffer employment loss. I think the point of Senator Archer 's question was that he wanted a clear statement of that situation, and I will refer his request to the relevant Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is the Government aware of the report and editorial in today's Australian concerning the report of a committee of United States Catholic bishops which states, amongst other things, that any use of nuclear weapons is immoral and calls for immediate bilateral verifiable agreements to halt the testing, production and deployment of new strategic weapons? Has the Australian Government, as a constant and reliable ally of the United States, conveyed to the United States Administration any view concerning the proposed use of nuclear weapons as part of a deterrent strategy? If so, what is that view and, whatever the answer, will the Government take into account the factors outlined by the United States Catholic bishops committee in formulating future expressions of that view?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I may not be able to answer precisely the questions raised by Senator Tate but I am able to say on behalf of the Foreign Minister that the Government is committed to an early end to the nuclear arms race. This can be achieved only on the basis of balanced and verifiable measures of arms control which provide for militarily significant reductions. The most hopeful course towards this end is the negotiations that are under way in Geneva on the reduction of both intermediate range weapons and strategic arms.

ANSWER.PARA: There have been suggestions and discussions with regard to the concept of a freeze. I am able to say here that the Minister believes that a freeze would not of itself represent disarmament. Under present circumstances it would also perpetuate an unequal military balance, given the greater momentum of the Soviet weapons program and the asymmetries in the arsenals of the two super-powers. If a freeze were to be accepted by both super-powers as leading unambiguously to verifiable reduction of nuclear weapons to equal force levels this would be a major achievement. But it is not clear that an across-the-board freeze in the terms that have been advocated would provide the essential enhancement of security which must underlie any such proposal. Australia strongly supports the negotiations on strategic arms reductions between the United States and the Soviet Union which commenced in Geneva on 29 June. We see these negotiations as offering the most realistic approach to achieving a stable nuclear balance at the lowest possible level. I will refer the details of the question to the Foreign Minister to see whether he has any further comment to make on them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources confirm that last year, for the first time in more than 20 years, the value of world trade actually declined and that some 8 per cent of the world 's merchant shipping fleet is now lying idle? Is the Minister aware that in 1981 -82 some 51 per cent of claims on the Shipowners Mutual Strike Assurance Fund were the result of industrial disputes in Australian ports? Is it also a fact that in 1980, for example, workers in Western Australia's iron ore industry, accounting for 1.75 per cent of the work force of that State, were involved in 46 per cent of the man days lost through strike action and that last year strikes in Australia's coal mining industry accounted for nearly 51 per cent of the man days lost through industrial action in the mining industry as a whole? Given that these strikes affect two of Australia's major export industries, I ask: How long can Australia stand this loss of competitiveness and reliability of supply brought about by strikes? I further ask the Minister: In light of the fact that the rate of wage growth in the United States of America over the past year has been 6 per cent, that in both West Germany and Japan it has been 4 per cent, that the comparable figure for Australia for the year ended June 1982 will be 15.2 per cent, that Australia's inflation level is now 12.3 per cent while the average level of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries is 7.8 per cent and that of our major OECD trading partners 6.5 per cent, should we expect to be considered competitive in marketing our products? Finally, given Australia's readily accessible natural resources--
—Order! I ask you to hurry with your question. It is very long.

—I am bringing myself to the final point, with your indulgence, Mr President. Finally, I ask: Given Australia's readily accessible natural resources, highly skilled labour force and freight advantage over other raw material exporters in respect of our main customer for minerals, namely Japan, should Australia not be able to insulate itself--
—Order! The question is too long.
—From some of the worst effects of the present downturn in world trade, particularly given that Australia accounts for only about one per cent of that world trade?

—Order! Before I call the Leader of the Government in the Senate to answer that question, I remind honourable senators that I have appealed to all honourable senators on previous occasions to try to keep their questions short. Long questions of necessity encourage long answers. When we have long questions and long answers it cuts down the amount of time available for other honourable senators to ask questions in this place. I ask honourable senators to reconsider the situation with regard to the questions they present to Ministers in this place.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I heard it, there are some seven elements to Senator Crichton-Browne's question. The first thing he asked was about the decline in world trade. My understanding is that it fell by one per cent. He mentioned that there was some 8 per cent surplus of shipping. In fact Lloyd's of London has said 16 per cent, so there is a very considerable surplus of shipping. As to the figures given by Senator Crichton-Browne on industrial disputes, I am not aware of the precise nature of them but I am aware that the magnitude is so; that is, that a small number of people--
—What about the figures released yesterday?

—We will be very happy to get the figures and to confirm what Senator Crichton-Browne said. The fact is that in ministerial conferences in Japan and in Australia one of the most common things raised with Australia is whether Australia can guarantee continuity of supply and whether Australia is likely to have a high incidence of strikes. There is no doubt that our trading partners are very sensitive to the fact that we have disruptions. In a time of world recession this is causing very considerable trouble. It is true that the wage rates in other countries, the United States of America and West Germany, have fallen very considerably and that wage rises in Australia have costed us very significantly out of world markets. It ought to be possible for Australia, having the natural resources and all the elements around it, to be a leader in trade today, even in a recession. It is the extra weight that we put in our own saddle bags-the pressure for higher and higher wages and the industrial disruptions-that makes countries worry about us as a good trading partner. If we are to compete we will have to look to our merits on the points that Senator Crichton-Browne has raised.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: GOVERNMENT DEPARTMENTS: CONTRACTING OUT OF PRINTING WORK

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Does the Government have a policy of contracting out work to private printers instead of using the Australian Government Publishing Service? Does this involve in Hobart alone some several million pages a year being printed for his Department? At the same time, do the Finance Regulations and the directions under them call for public servants responsible for incurring expenditure to exercise economy in the purchase of goods and services? If so, does he not agree that there is a contradiction in the instruction to departments which apparently comes from the Printing Resources Rationalisation Group, which states:

QUESTION.PARA: The policy established by the Government that printing is to be contracted out to commercial printers does not depend however on whether it is cheaper to do so .
I wonder whether the Minister could inform the Senate how much this policy adds to the costs of administering his Department throughout the country. How can he justify this policy?

TALK.START.PARA: —Last year there were a number of general Government decisions relating to the contracting out of printing. I do not recall the full detail of those decisions but certainly it is true that my Department, I understand in common with other departments, is required to contract out printing. Questions of comparative costs can be difficult because determining the cost of something done by a government body is sometimes a little difficult owing to the difficulty in assigning all the relevant costs and overheads which might be incurred. One may, in many cases, be dealing with questions of marginal cost rather than a share of the total cost. So some quite complicated arithmetic can be involved. Whether there is any contradiction in the instructions is a matter on which I would have to check with the Department. My understanding is that there is a general requirement on the Service to perform its tasks as economically as possible. There is certainly an instruction with respect to the contracting out of some printing. I think a question has arisen in my Department as to the extent to which we can comply with that instruction within the amounts which are appropriated for printing. It is an area in which I know some questions have arisen. I will obtain a careful and defined answer for the honourable senator as soon as possible.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry to the Australian Fisheries Council rejection of a Northern Territory proposal for management of the northern prawn fishery aimed at creating a separately managed area west of the Wessel Islands. I understand also that urgent consideration has been requested for the imposition of gear restrictions in the Fog Bay section of the fishery. Can the Minister advise what arrangements have been agreed upon for the management of the northern prawn fishery in lieu of the Northern Territory proposals?

—I am advised that the Northern Territory did put a proposal with respect to the management of the northern prawn fishery which aimed to create a separately managed area west of the Wessel Islands. That matter was considered by the Australian Fisheries Council, which is the body of State and Commonwealth Ministers who have jurisdiction in these matters. That Council did reject the Northern Territory proposal, in the context of the fact that there is a review of the management of the entire northern prawn fishery in progress at the moment , especially in regard to the need for the introduction of measures to restrain existing and potential fishing effort. These matters are to be considered by the Northern Fisheries Committee and its industry advisory committee at meetings scheduled for February 1983. This is part of a continuing review of the fisheries management arrangements, which are designed to ensure that the fishery is operating on a sound biological and economic basis. I understand that the Fisheries Council is reluctant to see a great deal of fragmentation of areas and would need to be satisfied that there are very strong biological or economic reasons for further subdividing the fishing zones. I understand that the Council did not accept that there were compelling biological or economic reasons for complying with the Northern Territory Government's request. The matter is still under review. That review will be ongoing into February of next year.

—I ask the Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General whether the Government has been kept informed of all developments in relation to the compromising of allied security in Britain. Given the exchange of information between Australian and British intelligence services, can the Government assure the Senate that every possible action has been taken to isolate from harm and, if necessary, resecure Australia's defence after such damaging disclosures?
—I will take that question on notice and seek an early reply for the honourable senator.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General. Serious claims have been made in the recently released book entitled Rooted in Secrecy regarding vital evidence on the Hilton Hotel bombing which, due to the nature of the inquest, has been suppressed. As security arrangements for the Commonwealth Heads of Government Regional Meeting involved the Commonwealth Government, will the Attorney-General institute an inquiry into this event as a matter of urgency? Does there not appear to have been the possibility of a serious miscarriage of justice in which three young men have been given 16-year gaol sentences?
—I will refer that question also to the Acting Attorney-General for reply.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and relates to a survey of 18 countries recently conducted by the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organisation which suggests that Australia's sugar consumption per capita of 53 kilograms a year is the highest of any country in the survey and that Australian children had on average 11 decayed, missing or filled teeth-a close second to Finland. Will the Minister comment on this survey and the claim by Professor Elsdon Storey, Professor of Child Dental Health at Melbourne University, that 'two-thirds of the sugar consumed in Australia is contained in prepared foodstuffs and only a third is bought as sugar'? This is a complete reversal of Australian figures from the 1930s.
—It depends on where it is grown.

—Wherever it is grown it is a poison. Because of the rapid increase in the consumption of hidden sugar and the adverse effect which this is having on natural anti-decay factors in food, I ask the Minister: Firstly, will action be taken by the Government to place more stringent controls on the use of sugar in foodstuffs, particularly those consumed by young children; and, secondly, what measures will be implemented by the Government to encourage people to reduce their intake of sugar so as to promote nutritional health and to ensure that correct eating habits are fostered in the Australian community.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although I have not seen the survey referred to by Senator Missen I am aware of some of the facts about sugar intake in Australia. Senator Missen is quite correct when he asserts that Australia's intake is high by international standards. I understand that the per capita consumption of sugar in Australia exceeds 52 kilograms a year. Senator Missen is correct in saying that more than two-thirds of this comes from prepared foods. The difficulty in answering Senator Missen's questions as they relate to what action the Government might take rests in the fact that the constitutional responsibility for some of the lines of action is with the States. Although the Commonwealth can play a role in identifying the problems and in laying down standards, it is to the States and Territories that we must look for action on food composition and food labelling.

ANSWER.PARA: The National Health and Medical Research Council has taken some action to involve itself in advising the Australian public. It has recommended a reduction of the sugar content of baby foods and it has recommended that sugar content be identified on the labels of foodstuffs to put more information in the hands of consumers. A working party is now trying to develop recommendations to go to the States. The Council, through its nutritional education committee, has produced printed material. It has produced a number of dietary guideline publications, including one which recommends less sugar. An available publication entitled ' Dietary Guidelines for Australians' deals with this subject. The only other comment I make on the question asked by Senator Missen concerns dental caries. I make the obvious observation that those Australian communities fortunate enough to have flouridated water, especially those fortunate enough to have had it for a generation, have children growing up without dental caries, in spite of the dietary habits which we might care to criticise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Health aware that, despite radio frequency hearing aids being commercially available within Australia since 1974 for hearing impaired children, the National Acoustic Laboratories have failed to supply such aids, thus forcing parents who wish their children to benefit from their obvious advantages to purchase these aids at prices between $1,100 and $1,300? Is the Minister also aware that the National Acoustic Laboratories have been developing the Burgess aid for some five to six years in co-operation with Plessey Electronic Systems Pty Ltd at a cost reputed to be in excess of $1.3m? In view of the above, will the Minister authorise the National Acoustic Laboratories to purchase in bulk, direct from the manufacturers, sufficient radio frequency aids for those children deemed to require them pending the proven reliability and mass production of the Burgess aid? Will the Minister give a firm undertaking to the parents of hearing impaired children in Australia as to when, if ever, the Burgess aid will be readily available, thus enabling Australian children to enjoy the benefits of enhanced amplification available to children in other countries? Although my question has another section, I do not want to outdo Senator Crichton-Browne so I will leave it there.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Robert Ray no doubt was responding to expressions of concern from parents or friends of hearing-impaired children and hearing- impaired people. During the time that I acted as Minister for Health and during the brief time I was Minister for Health a lot of material came across my desk relating to the provision, supply, design and fitting of hearing aids for hearing-impaired people. A lot of concern is being expressed in the community and a lot of argument is occurring as to what is the most appropriate kind of appliance. A number of other concerns have been expressed as to how the supply can be improved.

ANSWER.PARA: I do remember from material I have seen-I do not have a specific briefing with me-that there is considerable disagreement and argument as to what is the correct way to go. The National Acoustic Laboratories have been trying to develop the best kind of appliance and to get them fitted as widely as they can. I am aware that they have been carrying out pilot trials of a new appliance-I think it was the appliance that Senator Robert Ray referred to in his question- but the problem is made more difficult by the existence of different degrees of hearing impairment which seem to call for different strategies in terms of the kind of appliance which is required and the problems which relate to it being fitted. I ask Senator Robert Ray to accept that some of the things that are asserted as fact and from which people then draw conclusions are really matters which are still testable and on which there are different opinions. I join with the honourable senator in wanting to have hearing-impaired people fitted with appliances which are appropriate, accessible, properly fitted and reliable. This is what the National Acoustic Laboratories are trying to do. I would like to pass on to my colleague the Minister for Health the points made by the honourable senator to see whether we can advance any of the points raised by Senator Robert Ray.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister of Defence Support, is about the comments of the Executive Officer for the Strategic and Defence Studies Centre at the Australian National University, retired Colonel J. O. Langtry, in a recent address in which he warned that Australia's capacity to mobilise industry for war was lower than at any time since World War II. I ask: Is it a fact that Australia no longer has the capacity to provide steel and aluminium to Australian defence specifications? Is it a fact that many of the advanced composite and petrochemical based materials now used in defence force equipment are not even produced in their crudest commercial form in Australia? Is there an inadequate number of machine tool manufacturers in Australia to meet the mobilisation demands of the Australian armed forces? Finally, when did the last review of the defence mobilisation of Australian industry take place?

—It is fair to acknowledge that some of the concerns that Senator Lewis has brought up in his question were the rationale for the creation of the Department of Defence Support on 7 May last. In fact, it is the Government's intention to highlight the Government's support and direction in increasing Australia's potential for industrial production in the area of defence. Certainly the kinds of considerations which Senator Lewis outlined in his question are of concern to the Government. As to the specific points raised by Colonel Langtry, I have no information on that particular matter. It does seem to me that some rather extravagant remarks were made in the article which Senator Lewis outlined. I would need to check the article and refer that to the Minister for a detailed reply. I will endeavour to get a reply for Senator Lewis . I think it is fair to say that, all in all, the Government recognises the need for the development of Australian industry so as to support Australian defence purposes and intentions. Consequently, it is one of the very important matters that this Government has firmly in the front of its mind. I think the Senate does owe a debt of gratitude to Senator Lewis for constantly drawing our attention to these particular points.

—I ask the Minister for National Development and Energy: Is it a fact that the Northern Territory Government has put forward a plan for the rehabilitation of the Rum Jungle-Finniss River area? Secondly, has the Government accepted this proposal even though it is $4.2m over the estimate for the job? Will the waters of the Finniss River be suitable for stock, agriculture and horticulture when the rehabilitation program has been completed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —A plan has been submitted by the Northern Territory Government and discussed with the Commonwealth Government. A sum of money was made available in this Budget as part of the rehabilitation program. I am not able to say what period will elapse before the full rehabilitation of the area is completed. I will seek out that information. Nor am I able to say when the river area will be suitable for stock agistment. I will find out both of those things. The intention is to restore the area completely.

—I ask the Minister for Social Security whether the Government has given consideration to allowing widows under 50 years of age whose children cease to be dependants, particularly those whose previous work experience makes it obvious that they would be most unlikely to obtain work, to receive a widow's pension or equivalent special benefit rather than the present situation in which they are compelled to rely on the lower unemployment benefit with the consequent awkwardness and harassment of job tests.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a matter which has been raised on a number of occasions. Some quite active lobby groups are working to extend the B class widow's pension , which at present cuts out between the ages of 45 and 50 if there are no dependent children involved. There is no proposal to extend that widow's benefit . The women in that category who may, depending on their work history, have difficulty in re-entering the work force have common characteristics with other people in the community who also may have difficulty in entering the work force. For example, a woman who stayed home to look after her aged parents may well have little work experience and be left without support at the same sort of age. There are many men who, after a lifetime of unskilled or semi-skilled work, find that current economic conditions leave them very awkwardly placed in relation to entering the work force.

ANSWER.PARA: The problem is currently being considered, not as a matter which is peculiar to those women who fall between the various widow's pension categories but rather as a problem of those people who will find it difficult to enter the work force and who may be in that category or in some of the other categories that I have mentioned. The matter is receiving attention. I would be reluctant to see a general extension of a benefit which was based on some prior status and which would simply give as a class women who had borne children the permanent right to maintenance from the state, bearing in mind that roughly half or more than half of women now have regular periods in paid employment. Many of those women are just as equipped to compete for available work as are men or, indeed, spinsters.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNEMPLOYMENT AND INFLATION: EFFECT ON WAGES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. I realise that one or two questions similar to my question were asked today, but I think mine might be a little different. It concerns the claims made recently by some Ministers that high wages are to blame for both Australia's high level of unemployment and the spiralling rate of inflation. I ask: If wages are to blame, why is it that South Australia, with the lowest average weekly earnings in Australia, recorded the highest consumer price index rise in the September quarter? Can the Minister explain also how it is that the two States with the lowest average weekly earnings figures-namely South Australia and Tasmania-have the highest unemployment levels?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —That probably has something to do with the nature of the industries which are important employers in those States. Those States which are able to rely on highly profitable industries may be able to pay a higher wage rate than some other States and still maintain employment. But I think the general view which I expressed earlier in Question Time and which, for the sake of the Opposition Whip, I will not repeat, hold true, whether we are looking at those States or at any part of Australia. The fact remains that if Australian manufactured goods, to pick an example which is of particular importance to South Australia, are manufactured by labour which is significantly more costly than the labour of competitors, obviously that affects the ability to compete with imports.

ANSWER.PARA: The questions which Senator Foreman has been addressing to me over recent weeks in the Senate related to Kelvinator Australia Ltd are, I suppose, a very good example in point. I think all of us in Australia who are in employment simply ought to accept that we should not be seeking a larger share of the available riches of this country. We should be prepared to see them spread as widely as possible. One would hope that by all of us exercising some restraint, in whatever area of the economy that we work, we might see an improvement in the employment situation in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — Yesterday Senator Missen raised the question of the Australian Government's refusal of a visitor's visa to Mr Ramos Horta. He also asked whether the Government was aware that, according to official returns for the Indonesian general elections of May 1982 for East Timor, the Government party polled 3,000 more votes than the total of registered voters. The Minister for Foreign Affairs has supplied the following information: Mr Ramos Horta applied at our Consulate-General in New York for a visa to visit Australia. I can confirm that a visa was refused in accordance with long- standing Government policy. Mr Ramos Horta is a representative of Fretilin, which is dedicated to gaining independence for East Timor, which the Australian Government regards as a province of Indonesia. With regard to the general elections in East Timor, the Indonesian Government has explained that there were 3,227 more votes cast in East Timor than there were registered voters in the province by the fact that a large number of persons originally registered in other provinces actually voted in East Timor. A similar situation also occurred in Sulawesi Tenggara province.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Grimes asked me a question about the changed interpretation of entitlement for sickness benefit, in particular the circumstances where a person could not be shown to have lost income due to sickness and hence would not be eligible for sickness benefit under the provisions of section 108 of the Social Security Act. In response to him yesterday, I said that I was awaiting advice from my Department. I can confirm that I have had advice from my Department. It was in my office, and I had not seen it at that time. As a result of considering the views put to me, I would now propose to bring the matter before the Government. I am not in a position to advise the Senate on what changes, if any, might be brought forward. Any change which might be made can have the disadvantage of bringing in people who traditionally have not been regarded as entitled to sickness benefit and, in particular, people who are without earnings on a permanent basis, such as housewives, who have not normally qualified for sickness benefits during a period of illness. But the matter will receive Government consideration as soon as possible.

ANSWER.PARA: I also wish to advise the Senate-because it is relevant to the matter raised- that as an interim measure all States have been instructed to provide for these cases by way of special benefit, payable at sickness benefit rates, and subject to a liberal income test; in other words, the amount of benefit payable is being reduced only where other income is being received. The normal hardship provision related to special benefit is not being applied. I mention that because Senator Grimes asked whether action would be taken during the current session. I indicated that I thought that that would be difficult. The fact is that the practice during the period of consideration should prevent hardship accruing in cases which have been caught by the changed interpretation of section 108.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal statement, Mr President.
—For what reason?
—It is in relation to an article in a newspaper. It is misrepresentation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I refer to an article in the Canberra Standard of 20 October 1982. The article is under the heading 'Canberra Bashing ''Sinister'' '. I shall read part of the article, which shows very clearly why I feel that I have been misrepresented. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: A Queensland senator has been accused of a 'sinister and crude' attempt at Canberra bashing. A.C.T. Senator Margaret Reid this week bitterly condemned Queensland A.L.P. Senator G. N. Jones for what she said was an unwarranted attack on Federal funding of sport in Canberra. She said Senator Jones had used the success of Australian athletes at the Brisbane Commonwealth Games 'for A.C.T . bashing and political purposes'.
I did not have my photograph taken, as do some gentlemen that I know. The article continued:
Senator Jones had implied that Canberra was the sole beneficiary of Federal Government sports funding.

I could read more of the article, but it only further shows that the facts contained in the article are completely untrue, and that Senator Reid, probably in her enthusiasm, spoke to some reporter but did not even check the Press statement that I put out or the details of the Press statement. What I claimed in my Press statement was that the sales tax increase on sporting goods, announced in the Federal Budget and expected to yield about $90m in revenue this financial year, should be made available to sports assistance programs throughout Australia. That was the basis of the Press statement that I issued. I also went on to say what a wonderful job the Institute of Sport had done in Canberra.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shameful!

—I do not know whether the Minister goes along with it. But in the statement made by Senator Reid-I would not say it, Mr President, because you ruled yesterday that to call it lies would be unparliamentary. I shall not call it lies, but it was untrue and as close to lying as one could get.
—You are getting very close to being unparliamentary. I would say that you have just made it.
—I seek the leave of the Senate to incorporate the Press release in Hansard so that Senator Reid will not make any mistake in future and will have the facts available to her.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
5 October 1982

Sales tax increases on sporting goods announced in the Federal Budget, and expected to yield about $90 million in revenue this financial year, should be made available to sports assistance programs throughout Australia, Senator Gerry Jones (Labor, Queensland) said yesterday.
He said out of an allocation for sport of $26.7 million in the Budget, only $3. 2 million was available for 110 struggling sporting organisations and about 4 million participants.

''While the allocation of funds benefits the 'glamor' sports such as tennis and swimming and the most promising sports stars, Australians, on a per capita basis , receive only 21 cents a year for the promotion of sport and a healthier lifestyle.''
''Per capita spending in the U.K. is double that amount, while the Canadians spend $1.30 per head-more than six times the expenditure of the Australian Government.''

''Almost 90% of the $26.7 million allocation for youth, sport and recreation goes to construction and maintenance costs and almost half the total funds, $12 million, will be spent in the A.C.T. alone.''
''Provision for top class sportswomen and sportsmen to have access to specialised training programs amounts to $4.8 million, $4 million of which goes to the A.C.T.,'' he said.

Senator Jones said that while the Australian Institute of Sport deserved such level of funding, many potentially top-class competitors were unable to train way from their homes, their work or their studies.
He said that these people should have access to first class coaching facilities in other centres.

''From $3.2 million, 110 national sporting bodies will have to pay for administrative and coaching positions, travel to international competitions, the hosting of major events and for the National Athlete Award Scheme for high performance athletes.''
''There was no increase in this year's Budget for assistance for sport and recreation programs for the disabled,'' he said.

Senator Jones said the Labor Party in government would provide co-ordinated sports programs in schools, sporting facilities in capital cities and regional centres, the development of programs to attract large numbers of people to take part in healthy exercise and would facilitate the progress of skilled athletes.

''Most Australian athletes have to make a choice between their sport or pursuing their career. And with the spectre of unemployment hanging over just about everybody's head, Australian sport is losing countless competitors.''

''The elite training provided by the superb Australian Institute of Sport in Canberra, catered to 153 trainees last year on scholarships. Thirty six of them coming from Queensland, and aged between 12 and 29.''
''But applications are being received from hundreds of athletes throughout Australia for scholarships at the A.I.S. and the numbers are limited and the entry standards high.''

''For hundreds of latent champions who are unable to live, study or work in Canberra and are starved of adequate local coaching facilities, the prospect of achieving success in competitive sport is dwindling.''
''Governments overseas provide extensive services for prominent athletes, including the back-up services of sports science and medical personnel during normal training.''

''Capital city and regional coaching institutes, with access to these services, are essential if athletes from all parts of Australia are to enjoy equal opportunities to achieve their ultimate sporting potential,'' Senator Jones said .
Further information: Senator Gerry Jones 07 353 2927, David May 07 38 4129.

TALK.START.PARA: —(Western Australia)-I seek leave to make a personal explanation, Mr President, to correct an inaccuracy of mine.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 August, during the debate on amendments to the Family Law Act, recorded in Hansard of that date on page 159, I referred briefly to a Mr Don McKenzie, Chief Counsellor of the Family Law Court, who had circularised a number of trade unions, expressing an extraordinarily biased view of domestic violence, and its causes, action which has subsequently been referred to the Public Service Board. At that date Mr McKenzie had been asked to relinquish his position on the Family Law Council not, as I then believed, by the Director of the Institute of Family Studies, Dr Don Edgar, but by the Chairman of the Family Law Council, Mr Justice Barblett. I take this opportunity to correct the record and apologise for the inaccuracy.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Grimes proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The disastrous failure of the Government's economic policies as demonstrated by the unacceptably high unemployment rate and increasing inflation.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Anyone with eyes to see or ears to hear would know the justification for bringing up this matter of public importance today. I feel that I need say no more about that. On 9 September 1974, the present Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), who was then shadow Minister for Labour, in an interview with the Age, said that he accepted the principle that as unemployment rose, so too should unemployment benefits. The principle would be designed to protect individuals who quite innocently are caught in the turmoil of a mismanaged economy. On 19 November 1976, addressing the Liberal Party Federal Council, the same gentleman, the present Prime Minister, said:

SPEECH.PARA: The strategy we are pursuing aims at a gradual and sound recovery. It is designed to achieve a reduction in unemployment by mid 1977.

These were fine words and fine principles, but both the words and the principles are empty, as are all the words and principles of the Prime Minister. Using the August figures for unemployment beneficiaries, one finds that the number of beneficiaries has increased by 118,300 in two years-103,400 in the last 12 months. The September figures have increased by 140,000 from September 1981, when there were 306,000 on unemployment benefits, to September 1982, when there were 446,300 on unemployment benefits. From August to September this year the increase in beneficiaries was 24,400-in a period in which unemployment has traditionally held steady or improved. If we consider previous year's figures it can be seen that a further increase comparable with the rise in the last few years will result in the number of people on unemployment benefits being over 500,000 by January or February, and no one expects an improvement in this time, especially not the Treasurer (Mr Howard).

In my home State, Tasmania, the situation is especially grim. On the latest figures available unemployment was 10.9 per cent, and the numbers have obviously increased since then. The number of people on benefits has increased by more than 6,000 in 12 months and in other regions such as the Illawarra and the Hunter Valley a similar disastrous situation applies. Unemployment has more than doubled under this Government. It has increased by 50 per cent in the last year. The Government appears to accept with equanimity the real life tragedies, the family breakdowns, the bitterness and the alienation which lie behind these figures; the Australian Labor Party cannot. More people are fronting up to the Social Security counters knowing that they will be dependent on unemployment benefit cheques indefinitely. More of them, which is very important, are not our older workers who have difficulty re-entering the work force, nor our teenagers who have never been able to find jobs, although plenty of them fall into those categories. They are workers with families who have been our taxpayers, our producers of goods and services, our most stable members of society. I give a few comparisons. On 30 June 1975 fewer than 20 per cent of unemployed workers had been on unemployment benefits for more than six months. On 31 May 1982, 41 per cent, more than double the number, had been on unemployment benefits for more than six months. The average duration of receipt of unemployment benefits is now 39 weeks. The benefit is no longer, as the Government has continued to argue, a temporary benefit. As the economy closes in it has become a way of life for too many people.

The proportion of recipients of unemployment benefits for more than six months was higher for married persons than for single persons, yet the married unemployed made up less than a quarter of the total number of unemployed on benefits. Between May 1981 and May 1982 the proportion of under 20s and over 45s on unemployment benefits dropped. The age range of people on unemployment benefits which increased was the 21 to 44 year olds. One cannot blame the education system for this situation, as the Prime Minister has tried to do. These people are workers, not new applicants to enter the work force. The parents cannot be blamed, as the Prime Minister has tried to do. It cannot be said that these people had unrealistic expectations, as the former Minister for Social Security, the present Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle), has said. It is not only the young unemployed whom the Government must answer to, as witnessed by the intense anger of the workers who marched on Parliament House yesterday. We are looking at an industry crash which is affecting more and more families with mortgages and with children who are looking at nothing in the future under this Government because it has nothing to offer them.

The Government attempted to disguise the extent of unemployment by abolishing the publication of the Commonwealth Employment Service figures. All it has done has been to cloud the implications of one set of figures while all the other indicators of unemployment have taken off. The CES figures would at least have given some indications of State and regional unemployment so that remedies could have been taken, perhaps by more local authorities, but because the Government ran scared of publishing the figures we have no local information. I am pleased to hear that the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Macphee) is taking another look at that shortsighted decision of his Government. In previous years some 75 per cent of CES registrants were on unemployment benefit. On that premise today there would have been around 600,000 registered for work with the CES-probably more.

When the Government stopped publishing CES figures in March 1981 there were 25, 000-odd unfilled vacancies. In the last Australian Bureau of Statistics survey of August 1982 there were only 21,500 job vacancies and right now I think most people would be surprised if the number reached five figures. While the Government has hidden the CES statistics from view we are still left with the ABS survey figures and the Department of Social Security unemployment benefit statistics, and each of these tells a very sad tale. For instance, the most recent labour force statistics published by the ABS show a drop of 72,000 in the full time work force between September 1981 and September 1982-72,000 fewer jobs and more and more people desperate for them. The September ABS survey of unemployment notches up an unemployment rate of 7.4 per cent, with 504,800 people estimated to be looking for full time and part time employment. We all know the deficiencies in the ABS criteria. They exclude job seekers who have worked for more than hour in the previous week and people who, because of illness or family circumstances, had not taken steps to find work in the preceding weeks. Yet still the figures reach more than half a million.

The unemployment benefit figures are even more stark. I point out that these figures represent real people who have had to fit every one of the stringent tests of the Department of Social Security. They exclude men or women whose partners are in work and people who have been taken off unemployment benefit for alleged infringements of the work test. Yet they show that last month a record 446,000 people received unemployment benefits, a rise of 50 per cent over the September figures of last year. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table demonstrating this change.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —These are not notional figures as the ABS survey statistics are. They represent real people who have addresses, work histories, or a lack of them , and who put in income statements to the Department of Social Security. Otherwise they are not paid. Their numbers will take an enormous leap in October as the workers of Newcastle and Wollongong-and Tasmania-who were retrenched last month start collecting their first unemployment benefit cheques. They will take another large jump in November as the workers whose redundancy payments which lasted a month-including many of the workers who were here yesterday-start a career on social service benefits, which the Labor Party fervently hopes will be short lived. The figures will go up again in December as industries which have depended on the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and some major industries close down and as tertiary students who have finished their courses join the lines at Social Security. The figures will go up by a staggering amount in January and February as school leavers take up their entitlements of unemployment benefits because they have no work offered to them. If the Government believes the situation will get better then I, for one, would like it to tell me and these unfortunate people how.

SPEECH.PARA: The numbers on unemployment benefits do not include those whose spouses are working or those who have given up-the hidden unemployed. Who knows what the true figure is? They do not emphasise the catastrophic situation with youth unemployment where the rate is a startling 25 per cent to 30 per cent, and even higher in some areas. The figures also do not include the underemployed, those who want full time work but who are on a four-day week in the mining industry and manufacturing industry-such as the car components and white goods industries . In addition to these workers, throughout Australia many people are in a state of anxiety about the future of their jobs because of the decreasing viability of the firms they work for.

I think we should remember that there is savage discrimination against people on unemployment benefits. Some of this discrimination comes as a shock to those who are newly on benefits. If they are paying off a mortgage they will get no corresponding tax rebate if they are not paying tax. If they are paying rent they are ineligible for the $10 a week supplementary assistance. If they or their families are ill they will get a disadvantaged person's health card but no free pharmaceuticals and no entitlement to dental or optical treatment. They are expected to look for work but in most States do not get transport concessions. They do not get telephone concessions. The States will not give them rate, electricity, car registration or other concessions in general. They are out in the cold, hard world on their own and below the poverty line.

In the area of unemployment the Government had its chance for seven years and, to use the vernacular, it has stuffed it. We have this situation in industry as a result of contractionary economic policy which is aimed at fighting inflation first. It is therefore worth while looking at just what has happened to inflation. There has been a complete lack of ability to control inflation. In the year to the March quarter of 1982 the consumer price index rose by 10.5 per cent. In the year to the June quarter it rose 10.7 per cent. Now the figures for the September quarter show a rise of 12.3 per cent. In other words, inflation is accelerating. Even Mr Fraser, the Prime Minister, admits that this is a national disaster.

We are entering a period of economic disintegration with our worst inflation rate for 5 years. That is very much higher than that experienced by our major trading partners. Inevitably our international competitiveness will be further eroded. Exporters and primary producers will pay a heavy price for this Government's failures. Mr Fraser cannot even find a scapegoat for this disastrous performance. Clearly, overseas inflation is not being imported. Mr Fraser can no longer blame the Whitlam Government-that was seven years ago. The 12.3 per cent rise to the September quarter 1982 is higher than the comparable rate in the last year of the Whitlam Government. Mr Fraser in fact has only one scapegoat left, one legitimate source of blame-himself and his Government's own lamentable policy failures.

In 1975 Mr Fraser took office on the basis of a claim to superior economic expertise. Since then, inflation has continued apace, unemployment has soared to record highs and economic growth has faltered. On all the criteria Mr Fraser has claimed superiority he has failed. These failures are not surprising, I suggest. They flow directly from the Government's incompetence as an economic manager, its inconsistent policies and its single minded pursuit of irrelevant goals- particularly the striving for a small deficit at any cost. That was so until the most recent Budget. That inconsistency has again been demonstrated by another U- turn. One wonders whether we are now asked to look forward to a deficit-led recovery. It seems to be about the only sort of recovery which has not yet been promulgated by these desperate men and women in the Government.

The Government's own actions have helped to fan the fires of inflation. The largest components of the September quarter CPI increase were due to government policy. Import parity pricing and new taxes of course have forced up petrol costs. Hospital charges and health insurance rates have risen because of the health insurance shambles. The States have had to raise charges in many areas because of Commonwealth fiscal stringency. These are not new developments but have been occurring since the Fraser Government took office; they are a major reason why inflationary pressures have intensified.
