The Government has also contributed to inflation by encouraging the abandonment of a successful system of centralised wage fixation. The wage increases Mr Fraser now points the finger at were the inevitable outcome of this Government's push for decentralised wage bargaining. Mr Fraser abandoned or sabotaged the supporting mechanisms that would have allowed the continuation of a viable system of wage indexation with an anti-inflationary impact. He dismantled Medibank and artificially boosted the health component in the CPI. He dismembered the Prices Justification Tribunal. He abandoned tax indexation, which was necessary for the maintenance of real wage levels. He allowed a thriving tax avoidance industry to grow and prosper, thus undermining public confidence in the overall fairness of our fiscal system. This combination of fiscal haemorrhage and deficit fetishism was the basic cause of rising indirect taxes and government charges, all of which fed back into the inflationary spiral.

In 1980-we all very much know about it in the Senate-Mr Fraser and his Ministers talked up the economy on the basis of a resources boom that never materialised. He engendered an attitude of resource boom euphoria amongst employers and citizens generally in the community with resulting distortions in the economy. Nowhere did we see that more frequently and more vigorously pursued than by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Sir John Carrick). The Government's 'fight inflation first' strategy has therefore amounted to no more than a policy of deflating the economy while almost everything else it has done has contributed to undermining any benefits that might have been derived by way of reduced inflation. It is small wonder now after seven years in office the only material outcome is a level of employment which is the highest since the Great Depression, while inflation remains as high as when the Government took office. These policies not only have failed but also have been disastrous for the living standards of Australians and particularly for the unemployed who face a bleak future. Taxes have risen in relation to incomes, but social benefits have fallen. Our growth performance has been lamentable.

Australia now ranks eighteenth among Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries in terms of per capita output; we were fifth in 1950. This decline is entirely due to the failures of successive conservative governments in this country. In fact, during the Whitlam Goverment years gross domestic product per head rose at an average annual rate of 1.9 per cent in Australia- significantly higher than the OECD average of 1.2 per cent per annum. Since 1975 that situation has reversed to where we now have an average growth rate of only 1.2 per cent per annum in Australia compared with 2.7 per cent per annum for the OECD as a whole. This Government has no solutions. The 1982-83 Budget holds out the abysmal prospect of negative growth in 1982-83 with unemployment rising to 9 per cent or more. We believe that this is a policy of despair.

We have a situation where despite the abject failure of policies the recipe is for more of the same. Economic policies will continue to bear down most on wage earners and the disadvantaged. The unemployed are told they must bear their plight until market forces cause a recovery. Worst of all, we are to continue with the combative approach of the Prime Minister exemplified best when he accused the secretary of the Miners Federation yesterday of fomenting revolution as a result of yesterday's demonstration. Mr Macphee, a normally compassionate man, on AM this morning said despairingly 'there is nothing else we can do'. The Government has not only failed but also is bereft of ideas because it cannot overcome its ideological hang-ups.

Something can be done. Instead of confrontation we can have co-operation. Instead of economic stagnation we can stimulate sensibly economic growth instead of nineteenth century laissez-faire policies and have a sensible intervention in the economy. It is possible and can be seen as possible. Instead of taking as our models the monetarists such as Margaret Thatcher and Ronald Reagan, we can look further afield to those countries which have eschewed monetarism and instead have sought co-operation though a sensible prices and wages policy--

TALK.START.PARA: —Like France.

—Such as Austria, Senator Martyr, and Sweden and Norway. Above all we can instil a feeling of hope and concern in the community. Senator Martyr , who has been in every party except the Nazi Party-which puts him a cut above Senator Lajovic-has been changing his economic policy for a long time.
—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order.
—Senator Grimes, I think you should withdraw that remark.

—Mr Deputy President, I withdraw. What happened when the Australian Council of Trade Unions suggested a co-operative policy of wages and job protection? Its members were described as lunatics by the Acting Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations and condemned by the Prime Minister. The time has come for government, unions and business to get together, but they cannot do so because they are frustrated by intransigent and blinkered hierarchy in government. It is for this reason and for the good of the country and every citizen in the country that the Government must go because I am afraid the time for it to change is too late.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened with some interest to the remarks of Senator Grimes in putting the matter of public importance relating to economic policies, high unemployment and increasing inflation. I have something to say as far as the Government is concerned on those matters. I am not in disagreement with some of the figures which Senator Grimes has cited but many of the conclusions which he draws would sound very different from the Government's point of view. The Government fully recognises the serious labour market situation facing Australia. It is something about which we have been talking very strongly on every possible occasion. Any claims that the Government is seeking to avoid its responsibilities in regard to the difficult economic and employment situation are totally unfounded.

SPEECH.PARA: The labour market has deteriorated substantially this year reflecting difficult economic circumstances, not only in this country but also in many parts of the world where we trade. The deterioration is particularly reflected in the recent spate of large-scale job losses in areas as diverse as insurance, steel, the motor industry, meat processing and agricultural machinery. We could go on and on. It is expected, as has been noted in recent surveys, that heavy job losses will continue to occur in a number of key industries at least until the end of this calendar year. The recent rises in unemployment have fallen disproportionately on adult males. I noted that Senator Grimes made that same point. That indicates that the recession is attacking the very core of the Australian labour market. In addition to those adult males who have been disproportionately affected in recent months, Australia has a high level of youth unemployment and other disadvantaged groups are facing difficult labour market problems. However, Australia is not alone amongst industrialised countries in experiencing high levels of unemployment. For instance, the current level of unemployment in the United States of America is above 10 per cent, in the United Kingdom around 13 per cent, in Canada over 12 per cent, in West Germany 8 per cent and in France around 9 per cent. The latest seasonally adjusted figures for Australia indicated an unemployment rate of 7.4 per cent in September.

The adverse labour market situation results from a number of factors. The international recession has reduced Australia's export opportunities and led to a phasing back in new resource investments. A very serious drought is now beginning to have a major impact not only on rural centres but also on metropolitan based industry. I think it has often been said that if there is a healthy rural sector in this country there is a spin-off from that into other manufacturing and service centres. As I have said, we are now experiencing a downturn in metropolitan based industry as a result of that rural drought.

The impact of excessive wage increases over the last couple of years has also been significant and I will return to this crucial area later in my remarks this afternoon. Excessive wage increases cannot be ignored when we look at unemployment, inflation or the economy as a whole. These developments required the 1982-83 Budget, which is before the Senate at present, to be prepared against a particularly difficult economic background. Within that context, the Government did all that it could do to provide relief, assistance and incentive consistent with a responsible economic policy. I would want to say something about that a little later on and contrast the policy of the Opposition with that of the Government.

The policy of the Government remains firmly directed to the containment of inflation and to the encouragement of sustained growth in the private sector. An important aspect of the Budget is the increased assistance to those groups most disadvantaged in securing work. The Government recognises that increasing unemployment requires further emphasis on manpower and training programs, particularly for young Australians. The Budget makes available over $250m in this coming year for manpower and training programs of the Employment and Industrial Relations portfolio and that is a 21 per cent increase on last year's figure. The form of the Government's program reflects its commitment to young people, its commitment to a better trained and more flexible labour force and its commitment to bringing about an increase in permanent and long term job prospects. The available evidence shows that most unemployed young people have left school early and are generally ill-equipped to take their place in the labour market. They have few skills; they have few educational qualifications; and in many cases they have no work experience at all.

The Government's program seeks to overcome these difficulties by providing young people with the opportunity to learn vocational skills and to develop work skills. The emphasis on youth programs is one that the Opposition does not deny. In fact, I believe we have support for the programs which involve training, work incentives, opportunities to gain work experience and things of that sort. The Government's commitment to long term job prospects can be seen through the type of program offered. Our programs are not short term creation schemes. Rather, they are schemes designed to lead their participants on to permanent employment and to provide them with wider employment opportunities and skills which they would be able to use in the employment that they seek.

A basic problem for the Australian economy at present is that our costs are out of line with those of our major trading partners. Wage settlements and rates of inflation are tending to moderate in our major trading partners. As measured by consumer prices, the rate of inflation in Australia's major trading partners fell from 8.6 per cent over the year to August 1981 to 6.5 per cent over the year to August 1982. That is a considerable fall measured in any terms. In some cases, wages in those countries are increasing less quickly than prices. The Australian situation is quite different from that. In the last two years, earnings have risen far more quickly than prices. Average real earnings increased by 3.5 per cent in 1980-81 and 3.8 per cent in 1981-82. As a consequence of those increases, our rate of inflation has been rising while the rates of inflation of our trading partners have been reducing.

Not only have wage rates increased rapidly, but there was also a general movement to shorter working hours which further increased hourly labour costs. The plain fact of the matter is that, in the last two years, we gave ourselves wage increases and improvements in Australian working conditions at a rate far beyond that which the economy could sustain without creating inflationary pressures and destroying jobs. I do not think it could be argued that attention was not drawn to that factor by the Government, by Government spokesmen and by anyone who seriously looked at the claims that were made for wages and changes in employment conditions compared with what could reasonably be afforded by industries and what could reasonably be expected to create jobs or at least to maintain jobs for people already employed. The Australian economy clearly needs a period in which to digest the wage increases that have already taken place. I do not know that this seems to be understood.

The Treasurer (Mr Howard), in responding to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) yesterday, remarked on Mr Hayden's almost total refusal even to acknowledge the possibility that wage increases may be an element in the high level of inflation that we are experiencing in Australia. A censure motion was debated in the other place yesterday and I think the comments of the Leader of the Opposition and the Treasurer make very interesting reading, particularly in view of the way in which Senator Grimes has brought forward this matter of public importance today.

It is very strange for the Leader of the Opposition not to acknowledge the importance of the relationship between wage increases and the rate of inflation, given remarks that he made as Treasurer of Australia in his Budget speech of 1975. Let me quote Mr Hayden in 1975. He said:
If wages and salaries continue to outstrip productivity increases the productive capacity of the economy will decline and we shall all eventually be worse off.
I remind the Senate that these remarks were made by the present Leader of the Opposition in 1975 when he was Treasurer of Australia. Mr Hayden further said:

Meanwhile, however, it is clear that some wage and salary pressures are unrealistic and, when successful, harmful. It does employees generally no good to get higher and higher money incomes if the results are just higher prices, a severe squeeze on profits, a slump in new investment and a contraction of job opportunities.

I think the Leader of the Opposition should re-read those sentiments that he expressed in 1975 and place them into the context of today and the wage increases that have occurred. Mr Hayden also said in his 1975 Budget Speech:
Some sacrifice and patient restraint is called for from all of us in our demands for more resources, whether it is additional public services that are wanted or higher personal incomes.
Again, I would suggest that the Opposition re-reads those sentiments and places them into the context of the present state of our economy.

The 1982-83 Budget was constructed in such a way as to provide a basis for the exercise of wage restraint by wage and salary earners. A number of actions were taken in this Budget to increase people's real disposable incomes. For instance, the burden of taxation for the ordinary pay-as-you-earn tax earner was reduced, family allowances payable to everybody with children were increased and tax advantages were provided on housing mortgages. As an example of the benefits that will flow from this Budget, an average fitter with a dependent spouse and two dependent children and with an average mortgage will benefit very considerably from the provisions which were made in the present Budget and which are due to take effect from 1 November. He would require little more than a 10 per cent increase in award wages to gain the same benefits as are being provided in this Budget.

These actions represented a direct response to the views that were put by the Australian Council of Trade Unions and by the Confederation of Australian Industry at the tripartite economic conference which was held in July of this year. It was an important conference and one in which very firm recommendations were made to the Government as to the forthcoming Budget. The Government's response in regard to a number of areas in respect of which it will extend a direct benefit and give assistance to the average working man and his family is, I believe, well known.

In addition to meeting the immediate problems of low to middle income earners, the Government has set out as an example to other wage and salary earners, to restrain salary increases for more highly paid Government office holders and officials. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), the former Minister for Industry and Commerce, Sir Phillip Lynch, and the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Macphee, have all written to industry leaders urging their support for a similar approach with regard to those who are in the higher salary brackets. It is imperative that, in order to retain as many jobs as possible and to set the economy on the soundest possible foundation to take advantage of the world economic recovery when it occurs, we obtain the lowest possible wage outcomes over the next 12 months. I think that the next 12 months represents the resting period from wage demands that we must have so that, as there is economic recovery and as our trading opportunities expand, we will be ready and will have a sound foundation on which to expand our trading.

The Opposition seems unable to recognise the need for wage restraint at this time. The proposals announced yesterday by the Leader of the Opposition would be a certain recipe for higher rates of inflation and further losses of jobs; that is, more unemployment and greater hardship. The hard fact of life is that for wages to be increased in line with prices, at a time when business is finding it difficult enough to operate at present cost levels, would be a recipe for real disaster. The Leader of the Opposition appears to think that his proposal about forgoing productivity increases represents moderation, but that is an absolute illusion. There are likely to be few, if any, productivity gains while the present difficult economic situation persists. In any case, in the last two years real wages have increased in excess of productivity. That is precisely why the economy needs a breathing space in the next 12 months. Real progress in the fight against inflation and unemployment will not be made until such time as the union movement and the Opposition face the facts realistically and understand the important role that excessive wage increases have played in our current economic difficulties.

Part of the matter before us today concerns inflation and the Government's economic policy. I will say one or two things about that because the Government is committed to the achievement of a substantial and sustained reduction in inflation.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have been saying that for seven years.

— Yes, and economic circumstances are not the same year after year; they change. Our commitment to a substantial and sustained reduction in inflation is still very firm. To that end it has been the policy of the Government to pursue anti-inflationary fiscal and monetary policies. Even allowing for additional expenditures on drought relief and unemployment benefits under the Budget, the Budget deficit appears to be about one per cent of gross domestic product. The Government is committed to financing that deficit in a non -inflationary manner by the sale of securities to the non-banking sector. In the September quarter of 1982 the non-bank take-up of securities was $884m, compared with a rundown of $114m in the comparable period last year. That is a turnaround of about $1,000m.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has indicated its intention to restrain the average year on year growth in the M3 money supply to between 9 per cent and 11 per cent. It is currently running at near the top of that range. The Government is attempting to encourage a more responsible system of wage determination and in this regard notes that the metal trade employers have called for a six-month wage freeze in light of their current profitability and competitiveness. I stress that from 1 November the net take home pay in the pockets of average Australian salary and wage earners will be greatly improved by the reduction of income tax and the introduction of other benefits that, as I have said, are in this Budget. This should surely provide a basis for some moderation in the wage claims of Australian workers.

The consumer price index for the September quarter is certainly most disturbing to the Government and should be disturbing to all who are able to read the signs of the difficulties within the economic climate. It highlights the serious inflationary problems facing the Australian economy. Perhaps the most worrying aspect is one that the Government and the Opposition have referred to-that our inflation has been accelerating while inflation abroad has been declining. Consumer prices in Australia's major trading partners increased at an annual rate of only 6.5 per cent over the year to August. Our competitive position is being seriously eroded by the differences between our inflation rate and those of our trading partners. It ought to be obvious that unless we can restrain our inflation level we will have little chance of benefiting from any upturn in overseas activity when it occurs and of restoring economic growth and employment levels in this country. It could well be argued that inflation in this country ought to be lower, but in view of the problems that have occurred and some of the reasons for the present rate, we ought to be considering seriously what should be done to restrain it.

I refer first to the serious drought in Australia, which inevitably has an impact on food prices. In the September quarter the drought contributed to higher prices: Fresh fruit and vegetable prices went up by 12.9 per cent. These were offset partly by lower prices for lamb and mutton, which were down by 4.8 per cent, and a moderate rise in beef and veal prices-up 0.7 per cent. We may expect some upturn in meat prices once the drought breaks and restocking commences. Perhaps it should be recognised that drought is a serious difficulty about which we are not able to do a great deal except alleviate the distress that occurs as a result of it.

But we ought to be able to do something about excessive wage increases. While they have been accelerating in Australia they have been slowing down in other countries. Last year wages in this country grew by some 3 per cent or 4 per cent more than the rate of inflation. Some measure of the size of recent wage increases can be obtained by the following figures for the all-persons average weekly earnings index. In the December quarter of 1981 these rose by 3.4 per cent; in the March quarter of 1982 by 5.3 per cent; and in June quarter of 1982 by 3.4 per cent. The increase in award wages continued to run at well over 13 per cent in July. One indication of the importance of wage increases is given by the fact that the services component of the consumer price index increased by 18 .8 per cent over the year to the September quarter. Whilst possibly we ought to be getting together and talking about these things, as suggested by Senator Grimes, it ought to be recognised that unless we get together to restrain wage increases and help to contain inflation we will not be in a competitive position to take advantage of trading opportunities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —If there is one element of consistency in the arguments of successive Fraser governments it is surely to be found in its blaming of the workers and the trade unions for wage increases and its insistence that all of the current evils-inflation, unemployment and so on, and perhaps excepting the drought-flow from the faults of the workers and the trade unions. Many Australians who are listening to this debate must wonder just what country they are in. They are being told endlessly about excessive wage increases. They look at their pay packets and say to themselves and to each other: 'Just who is getting these excessive wage increases?' We hear reference made to the average weeky earnings and the earnings of the average fitter or the person with trade qualifications. We very rarely hear reference made to the earnings of a person who is on or near the average weekly wage rate which, in August 1982, was $233 a week for men and $213 a week for women. Most people would not believe that to be an excessive wage rate.

SPEECH.PARA: I realise that the point that is being made is about the very rapid increase in those wage rates in comparison with other economic measures. If the Government were as conscientious in its attention to price increases and to its policies which are responsible for those price increases; if it were concerned in its policies and through the State governments to control rents; if it were concerned to control profits; if it were also concerned to be as conscientious about collecting taxation, I believe that the vast majority of Australians who are on very low wages would be a little more impressed. The 1983 predictions for unemployment are for at least 10 per cent of the work force. Since 1945 the rate of unemployment amongst women has been higher than that for men. The rates are often underexpressed because unemployment amongst women is largely hidden. They lack opportunities in the work force and have access to a much narrower range of occupations. If all the mature women who are presently in the work force were to leave the work force, their jobs would immediately be taken by all of the mature women who would work if work were available for them.

Schools are stll churning out girls who are streamed into a narrow range of occupations. If in fact there were equal opportunities for boys and girls in our education system and in our industrial system, there would be no difference in the rates of their unemployment. However, of girls between the ages of 15 and 19 years, 20.7 per cent are unemployed as against 15.6 per cent of boys in that age group. Yesterday, when the demonstrators were here from Wollongong and from south-east New South Wales, demonstrating and putting to us the problems that they have in that area, we met women who came with them and who were working for the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd at Wollongong. As a result of their having taken a class action under the State's equal opportunity legislation they were able to get jobs there that women do not normally do. These are amongst the very few women who have been able to break the gender barrier-one as a welder, others as fitters' mates, some as machine operators and several of them in labouring jobs. These are amongst the people who will lose their jobs in the next couple of weeks. Amongst the other people at Wollongong who will lose their jobs are apprentices-males and females. All except about 15 of the fourth year apprentices will be put off.

The availability of jobs for older women is totally inadequate. This stems from their lack of education and training and, in many cases, because of their lack of encouragement and lack of confidence in themselves. Many of those who have been able to go back to the work force are in jobs that in many cases are threatened because they are in manufacturing industry. Obviously, within the job market, where very little formal training is required and where very little is required in the way of formal education, such people are very easily replaced. They are very well aware of the fact that they are easily replaced. The result of these inequalities is the high number of women receiving welfare payments. In June 1982 women constituted 61.2 per cent of social security pensioners and beneficiaries. If we exclude those on unemployment benefit, the percentage reaches 67.3 per cent. Over 95 per cent of people on the supporting parent's benefit are women and very many of those women would be delighted to be able to find employment. In fact, we have been told that the majority of women on the supporting parent's benefit stay on that benefit for as short a time as possible . If they are able to get work they certainly do not stay on the supporting parent's benefit.

The majority of pensioners living solely on welfare are mainly women, partly because of the relative lack of opportunity for employment and the greater longevity and earlier retirement of women. The total picture that these figures represent is what some analysts have referred to as the feminisation of poverty. We know that the Government has taken some measures to ameliorate the effect of the recession on these people. However, a close look shows how inadequate these measures are, especially when they are considered together with increased hikes in sales tax. Increased indirect taxes show up in increased prices for consumer items. Low income households are particularly hard hit by escalating electricity charges, rentals, rates, transport costs and other State and municipal charges. Within most of these families it falls upon women, either as family heads or as partners, to stretch the minimal income to meet these rising costs.

Part time work has greatly expanded in the past 10 years. This has hidden the extent of unemployment, representing as it does in very many cases involuntary unemployment and under employment. Between July 1981 and July 1982 only 3,000 new jobs were created in Australia. In that time there was a decline of 19,400 in the number of full time jobs and an increase of 22,400 in part time jobs. This represents an enormous amount of underemployment and waste of skills and, for the female sector of the work force, it represents a great increase in lack of security, increasing technology which threatens jobs, and the deskilling of those who have taken a pride in their work. The average number of hours worked by part time workers in Australia is 15.

I referred earlier to weekly wage rates and the fact that the rate at August this year was $233 a week for men and $213 a week for women. That translates into not quite $6 an hour for men and a little over $5 an hour for women. Very many of the people who are working part time are being paid at casual rates which gives them the princely amount of an extra 20 per cent on top of those hourly rates to compensate for causal employment. These are the people I referred to earlier-the ones who are absolutely stunned by, amazed at and disbelieving of the continual references to rapidly increased wages for which they are being blamed and which, if the Government is to be believed, are at the root of all the economic problems of this country.

During the demonstration yesterday, I spoke to two young women whose husbands are coal miners at Kemira 'sitting' in the coal mine for two weeks. The women came with their little children on a very long and uncomfortable journey to Canberra to take part in the demonstration. I asked those women whether there was work available for them as their husbands are now unemployed. One of them told me that yes, she had a part time job. Last week she earned $34. That did not go very far towards paying off a heavy mortgage. This is the situation of very many families in Australia where the second income is simply a small amount which tops up the family's income keeping that family out of poverty. The loss of the second income, whether it be the primary one or that small supplementary one, can be a great tragedy.

Over the past 18 months we have seen a number of demonstrations outside Parliament House. Until yesterday all of them were by people who could fairly easily be ignored. They included pensioners, people concerned about child care- the people protesting about women's refuges were a little noisier than the rest- the handicapped and Aborigines. Yesterday, however, brought to Canberra a group of people who in a physical sense could not quite so easily be ignored.

When they came into King's Hall we heard from the chamber what sounded like a dull roar; when I went into King's Hall I found that the demonstrators were singing-it still sounded like a dull roar. The song they were singing was written for them by the people who were staging a sit-in at Kemira. I wish to read the two verses of this song. I will not sing it; I will not inflict that on the Senate or the listening public. For a start, I do not want to get into trouble with the musicians union! The song went as follows:
How many jobs must a man hold down Before you can call him a man?
Yes, and how many times must a man get the sack Before he is branded for life?
How many days must we stay underground Before BHP sees the light?
How many times must we go outside Before we can see our wives?
Yes, and how many ears must the BHP have Before they can hear people cry?
And how many jobs will it take till they know That people need work to exist?

What that song lacks in literary merit I suggest it makes up for in poignancy. It would not be of any satisfaction to any of us, the people listening to us or the miners themselves that the miners will have a lot of time on their hands in which to indulge in choir practice, in the near future. The miners were not just calling on BHP to solve their problems. They were calling on the Government to give them back their jobs, to assert its authority over BHP, to stop further sackings, to obtain and disclose information on BHP's future investment plans and to ensure rational planning of the coal and steel industries. I think it would be reasonable to suggest that the requests of the miners would apply to very many industries throughout Australia. These are exactly the sorts of approaches that should be taken by the Government. It is fruitless, specious and dishonest to go on blaming the wages workers of Australia for Australia's current economic ills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: — Today the Senate is debating a matter of public importance proposed by Senator Grimes in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The disastrous failure of the Government's economic policies as demonstrated by the unacceptably high unemployment rate and increasing inflation.

This is a serious matter. The Government accepts that unemployment at the moment in Australia is at an unacceptably high level. As a matter of interest, however, it is at a level that is still below that of countries such as West Germany and France, which are presumably the democratic socialist models we are being invited to follow. Nevertheless, we do accept that unemployment is unacceptably high. Furthermore, the September consumer price index figures show increasing inflation which is, unfortunately, frighteningly out of step with our trading partners. Therefore, it is quite reasonable to ask whether there is, in fact, an alternative better economic strategy for this country. I give credit to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) because yesterday, at least, he was prepared to put an alternative strategy. That is good because it gives this Parliament and the Australian people an opportunity to look at the Government's economic program and the Australian Labor Party's alternative to it. I intend to deal with that in a little while, but first I wish to set the scene.

Australia is a trading nation. Thirty per cent of our gross domestic product is comprised of revenue from trade. We are in the midst of a major world recession- probably the worst recession in the last 50 years. Unfortunately, it is a recession that is getting worse internationally. Our exports comprise largely minerals and primary produce and, to a lesser extent, manufactured items. Unfortunately, and most regrettably, at the same time we are in the midst of what is possibly the worst drought in Australia's history. The international depression has slashed out the markets for our minerals. The drought in Australia has slashed the opportunity for our rural exports. It appears that this year Australia of all places, will need to import wheat to feed its sheep. Thirdly, our exports of manufactured goods struggle because of the high cost of Australian labour and transport. We do not hear cries from the Labor Party to reduce the high cost of labour in Australia. The cry is quite to the contrary; rather that it should be maintained or increased. Even the Labor Party would not claim that the Government is responsible for the world recession and the collapse of the mineral market. Nor, I suspect, would the Labor Party claim that the Government should be held responsible for the drought and, therefore, the collapse of our rural economy this year.

Great difficulties face government at the moment. It is impossible to look at the economic circumstances of this country outside the context of world economic difficulties. It is also a mistake to assess economic performance over too short a period. The growth performance of this Government over recent years has been better than that in most other countries. Last year in Australia real personal expenditures rose by 3 per cent, gross domestic product by 3 per cent and non- farm sector growth by 2 per cent. That should be compared with the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development area generally in which real gross national product increased by only half a per cent.

The economic policies of this Government and Australia's relative energy endowments have sustained our economic growth beyond that of others. We have until now been able to cushion ourselves against the international recession, but such cushioning can be of only a temporary nature. As the Treasurer (Mr Howard) said in the other place yesterday, the recession hit us later but it is not hitting us any less because of the timing difference. When international circumstances are running against us is it a time to exacerbate rather than reduce those adverse international circumstances? That is what the policy package of the Opposition would do. It is a somewhat familiar recipe. The Leader of the Opposition said that the answer lies in increased capital works, higher pensions and benefits, maintained protection levels and a freeze on all State and Commonwealth charges. It is interesting to reflect what was said in this morning's Australian Financial Review about that package, the Australian Financial Review being a newspaper that has not always been kind to this Government. The editorial states:

In this climate it is easy for the Labor Party to make grandiose promises about spending stimulus through tax cuts or higher pensions and benefits, to avoid the need to increase government charges at a time when government enterprises are running huge deficits, to make capital grants for job creation, to maintain industry protection regardless of the viability of industries, and to maintain real wages.

This is what the Leader of the Opposition proposed in Parliament yesterday. It is a recipe not only for economic disaster, but also what is worse, given the need for a strong democratic system, for the ignominious collapse of yet another Labor Government if the ALP should win the next federal election.
Those are very harsh words. The editorial continues:
This leaves the Labor Party with a fiscal program which promises nothing-
I repeat-

This leaves the Labor Party with a fiscal program which promises nothing but unemployment and inflation on a larger scale than we have now, and the prospect of further involuntary devaluations of the Australian dollar as we are locked into a devaluation/inflation spiral. From his public comments so far it seems that the shadow Treasurer, Mr Willis, has learnt very little from his sojourn in France.

That reference to his sojourn in France is interesting also because one thing that came out of the recent International Monetary Fund meeting in Toronto was an agreement that the first step in the recovery of Western nations had to be the control of inflation. It was agreed that the control of inflation remains the single most important objective for industrialised countries. One can refer particularly to people such as Prime Minister Trudeau, whose policy in the past has favoured the expansionary theory as a solution to economic problems. On this occasion, he said:
Inflation is not consistent with growth and stability.

I refer also to the Minister of Finance in France. We know that France went the way that the Opposition is recommending to the Australian public that our economy should proceed. Already, even after such a short period of government in France, the Finance Minister, at the International Monetary Fund meeting, said:
We must not give in to easy temptations of unrestrained public expenditure or the deceptive, transient attractions of inflation.

So even in France there has been a major change in attitude, a change away from what was recommended yesterday by the leader of the Australian Labor Party. The Government also says that the Opposition's proposed package is economic nonsense . It will not work.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are running at a slightly higher rate of unemployment than us at the moment.

—Yes, in France the unemployment rate is 9.1 per cent as opposed to the rate in Australia-which we accept nevertheless is unsatisfactory-of 7.4 per cent. If honourable senators want to compare unemployment rates I point out that the rate in the United Kingdom is 13 per cent and in the United States of America it is 9.8 per cent. It is an unfortunate fact that throughout the Western world rates of unemployment are far too high but, relatively, Australia is not as bad as some. The Government does not attempt to use that as any form of excuse. We say that the Labor Party's proposition is economic nonsense. We require policies to keep inflation down, to encourage greater production and growth and to increase economic efficiency. It is only by real economic growth and economic efficiency that we will be able to absorb the unemployed in long term employment, not just some form of temporary employment, the cost of which itself will delay recovery. Artificial schemes have been tried before and they have failed. If they are attempted again they will fail again. It is easy to redefine employment and solve the problem in that way but it does not mean that the community is better off. An extreme example is the Soviet Union. By definition, it has full employment but nevertheless there are food queues and a low standard of living. So employment in itself is not the total answer.

SPEECH.PARA: The real concern now must be whether we will be in a competitive position when the world comes out of the current recession. As the Treasurer said in his Budget Speech:
The plain, inescapable fact is that Australia has priced herself out of many world markets.

The high inflation figure just released in part results from the fact that we in Australia, we the wage earners, are giving ourselves increases that simply are beyond the capacity of this country currently to withstand. One has only to look at increases over recent years. In 1973-74 the increase in average weekly earnings was 16.2 per cent; in 1974-75 it was 25.4 per cent. I will not be so unkind as to remind the Opposition who was in government at that time. Increases for the following years are: 1975-76 14.4 per cent; 1976-77, 12.4 per cent; 1977 -78, 9.9 per cent; 1978-79, 7.7 per cent; 1979-80, 9.9 per cent; 1980-81 13.5 per cent; and, in 1981-82, something around 14 per cent. That situation has to be contrasted with the rate of wage increase in the countries that make up our markets. For last year the increase in Germany was only 4 per cent. Japan had an increase of somewhere between 3 per cent and 4 per cent, the United States of America 6 per cent and the United Kingdom 7 per cent. We are severely out of step. This was recognised recently by the Commonwealth Banking Corporation in a commissioned study for the Metal Trades Industry Association when it said:

In the current climate of depressed corporate profitability, declining international competitiveness and flat market conditions, both domestically and internationally, failure to achieve a marked deceleration in wages growth will inevitably lead to a deeper and more prolonged downswing in the economy.

In the same survey the bank indicated that, unlike what the Labor Party says, the degree of increases in prices is not in step with increases in wages and is not contributing to inflation to the same extent. I remind the Senate of what the Treasurer, Mr Howard, said in 1981. It turns out to have been something of a profound warning. He said:
. . . if unchecked the pressure for higher wages will not only lead to higher inflation but reverse the falling trend in unemployment and put at risk both investment and employment growth.

Of course that is what has happened. Someone recently said that there is too much concentration in Australia on the politics of consumption and not enough on the politics of production. Perhaps that is right. However, in recent times the Government has made a number of changes to facilitate economic growth and they are worth referring to today. They seem to have been rapidly forgotten by the Opposition. In the field of assistance to industry I remind the Senate of the package delivered last July which included accelerated plant depreciation provisions to encourage efficiency, investment and growth. We remember that it included for the first time depreciation of income producing buildings, an increase in export market development grants in recognition of our trading needs and continued support for industrial research and development through a realisation that to survive in a competitive world we must be technically competitive.

I remind the Senate that the Budget decisions reduced income tax rates in order to increase incentives. The retention allowance for private companies was increased, as were rebates on dividend income to encourage investment. Rebates are now allowable for employee share acquisition schemes to encourage workers to become more involved in the companies for which they work. All these measures demand credit. I remind the Senate also of the employment encouraging schemes funded in the last Budget. There has been an increase in the Commonwealth Rebate for Apprentice Full-time Training Scheme to assist another 226,000 Australians. There has been a 36 per cent increase in youth training programs. Unemployment and training program expenditure has been bolstered by 20 per cent to a figure of $250m. I remind the Senate also of the 20 per cent increase in capital expenditure in the Budget, and what is now being advocated is an even greater figure. In conclusion, I remind the Senate of what Mr Hayden said in his 1975-76 Budget Speech when he was Treasurer. He said:

It is not possible to provide more and more Government services or transfer payments from the Budget without ultimately having to pay for them through cutting back after-tax earnings via increased taxes. It is not possible to get quarts out of pint pots.
On this occasion it is worth reminding the Opposition of what its leader said when he was Treasurer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, put forward the Government's attitude to the current economic problems which we are now debating. She said, in effect, that we have to wait for an upturn in the economies of the Western world, we have to wait for the drought to break and we have to wait for tax cuts to take effect. I believe there are two consequences of the Government's economic policy, of the Government's approach to managing the economy, which cannot wait for one day longer. I refer to unemployment and to the balance of payments on current account. These two problems, taken together, are now so serious that we have got past the point of economic debate. We cannot discuss or talk or argue about what will happen in these two critical areas; action is required immediately.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to examine in some detail these two factors of Government economic policy. I refer first to employment. It is important for the people of this country to realise that unemployment is not inevitable. Senator Hill pointed to unemployment levels in other countries. I am not concerned with those countries; I am concerned about what happens in Australia. We are 15 million people living on an entire continent. If we cannot fully employ our work force under these conditions, we do not deserve to inhabit this continent. Unemployment, it must be realised, is not a technical problem beyond the control of governments. Unemployment is a government responsibility. The Government must be forced to take action. It will take action if sufficient people say that they are not prepared to tolerate for one day longer these levels of unemployment.

Essentially, unemployment is a moral issue. It is wrong. It is bad. It is an outrage on the dignity of the individual. It creates impossible stresses for family life. If this country were at war, there is no doubt that we would find the money to fight that war. I suggest that we are facing a crisis of unemployment which is every bit as serious as this country being attacked. We have to develop an attitude that we are on a moral crusade. We have to adopt an attitude that the unemployment problem has to be solved, and solved immediately, or we run the risk of breaking the social fabric of our society. Money has to be found to be directed carefully into efficient, labour intensive industries. I do not pretend to list what those vital industries should be. It is up to the Government to arrive at a consensus among the parties. The need for consensus is one aspect of the speech of the Minister for Finance with which I do agree absolutely. There has to be a consensus as to what the long term goals of this country are to be. Money then has to be found to be directed into those areas so that the problem of unemployment can be solved quickly.

We have to develop a renewable energy source. We have to develop water conservation. We have to build roads and we have to build houses. We have 270, 000 people living in caravans in Australia right now. We have 100,000 people waiting for emergency housing. Above all, we have to develop small business enterprises which are efficient and are wealth producing enterprises. Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle said: 'Let us wait for the tax cuts to take effect'. We might be waiting a long time if the American experience can be taken as a model. What has happened in the United States with the much heralded tax cuts in that country is simply that the money has gone straight into savings. When there is massive unemployment, that is where tax cuts will go, of course. People are going to build up their savings as quickly as possible because of the constant fear of unemployment. Tax cuts are not necessarily going to solve our problem. There is only one way really to stimulate consumption, that is, to get goods to the public more cheaply. That can be done in a variety of ways. We could reduce payroll tax which is the tax on labour. We could reduce sales tax. Somehow cheaper goods have to get to the public.

The second fundamental problem with the Government's economic management is that we have a critical balance of payments problem on current account. Unless there are policy changes so that our continuing current account deficit is arrested, there is no doubt that Australia will become internationally insolvent within only a few years. Last year, our current account deficit was $9.1 billion . That was made up of exports for which we earned $19 billion. We spent $22 billion on imports. The balance of those two figures was $3 billion in deficit. The invisible trade deficit was another $5.8 billion. That trade deficit, the invisibles, is made up of interest rates on foreign loans and paying dividends on investments for multinational companies in this country. We simply cannot go on putting the country into hock at this rate.

What should we do about the problem? There are various policy initiatives that we could adopt to erode this run on our foreign exchange. I simply point to our history, to go back to the years 1950 to 1953. As honourable senators will recall, there was a change of government about that time. The Menzies-Fadden Government came to power in 1949. It had only just come to power when it found that suddenly inflation was running at the rate of two per cent a month, which is at the rate of 24 per cent per annum. It found that the balance of payments had suddenly deteriorated and that unemployment was rising rapidly. To the eternal credit of those two men, they took action. This Government has to do likewise. The Menzies-Fadden Government adopted a positive and flexible attitude towards short term economic policies.

This Government can no longer sit back and adopt the comfortable monetarist approach which says that a government does not need to interfere in the management of the economy: Just control the rate of supply of money, and everything else will fall into line. That policy has not worked. It is patently obvious that it is not working. There has to be a change of approach by the Government. What did the Menzies-Fadden Government do? It introduced import quotas. It brought down a moratorium on imports from the United States. It immediately controlled interest rates. It used taxation in a counter-cyclical manner to stimulate the economy. It is not my place nor is it my party's place to say precisely what the Government's economic policy should be; but I am saying that, if honourable senators look at our history, they will find that previous conservative administrations were prepared to act in a positive manner in relation to emergencies which arose. This Government has to do likewise.

I conclude by pointing out that the two basic problems of unemployment and balance of payments are matters which the Government cannot wait to rectify. I believe that, if the Government were prepared to approach all parties in this Parliament in order to get a consensus, it would be surprised at the degree of co-operation that it would receive. Nobody in this Parliament wants to see a repeat of what we saw yesterday when we had armed police walking the corridors of this Parliament, probably for the first time in the history of our Federation .

My message is also to the Australian people. I believe that they have been hoodwinked into believing that unemployment is inevitable and that the Government cannot do anything about it. The facts of the matter are that if governments are prepared to accept unemployment as the first priority, if they are prepared to put people first, if they are prepared to say that nothing else matters and that the unemployment problem has to be solved first, they will very quickly arrive-particularly if they attempt to arrive at a consensus-at policies that would solve the unemployment problem. Coincidentally, the same policies would probably solve the balance of payments problem. The answer is not to tighten further the economic screws. The problem will not be solved if the Government sits back and hopes that something will happen overseas. Action has to be initiated right here and now. If the Government is not prepared to take action, if it cannot see what policy initiatives should be taken and if it is not prepared to attempt to arrive at a consensus of action, I suggest that it should not occupy the seat of government for one day longer. In the words of Shakespeare:
Stand not upon the order of your going; But go at once.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to contribute briefly to this debate about the condition of the economy, unemployment being the principal thrust of the matter which is before the Senate. I want to look at the question of unemployment in the context of the Government's general management of the economy. Let me say at the outset, to paraphrase something that Senator Siddons said, that this Government has had a policy of fighting inflation first for seven years, and I do not think that the Government has been very successful. In fact, in that fight the Government is now getting hell beaten out of it and it is probably time it picked on something smaller than the current inflation rate rather than continue to fight inflation with the degree of success it is having as a government.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to talk about this seven-year period of disaster of the Fraser Government and, in a sense, set it in the context of the last 33 years of Australian politics, 30 of which have been presided over by Liberal-National Party governments. What has been happening to this country over the last 30 years is that it has been going down the hit parade very steadily in terms of economic performance and growth. That process has accelerated over the last seven years. The acceleration has been due to mismanagement, ad hockery and broken promises. The whole question has been compounded by the Government's penchant every year prior to an election for manufacturing some fictitious recovery, such as the resources led recovery before the 1980 election and the consumer led recovery in 1977. All of these things which were going to happen were distractions before an election and were quickly abandoned and forgotten about after the election was over.

In recent days the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has been very anxious, one might even say desperate, to try to paint Australia's economic performance as being in some ways quite good when one compares it with that of other countries. I want to go through, as a matter of fact, what the situation is in respect of some of the main indicators of economic management. I shall deal first of all with the question of unemployment. Unemployment has been high in Australia for a number of years. It is now at its highest level since the Great Depression, with 7.4 per cent of the work force unemployed. This figure is in fact higher than the level recorded in the 1933 census when the Depression was drawing slowly to a close. Let me compare the present level of unemployment of 7 .4 per cent in Australia with that of other countries. In New Zealand the level of unemployment is 4 per cent; in Sweden, 4 per cent; in Japan, 2.4 per cent; in West Germany, 6.6 per cent; and in Italy, 10 per cent. Italy always has a higher unemployment figure than Australia. In the United States the level of unemployment is 10.1 per cent. In Mexico it is 8 per cent; in Canada, 12.2 per cent; and in Britain, 14.8 per cent. The disaster areas are Canada and Britain. It is not a very good comparative record for Australia which, as we are all reminded from time to time, is a resource rich country.

The same sort of comparison can be made when one looks at the consumer price index which, for the year ended September, showed a 12.3 per cent increase over the last year. For the September quarter of this year it showed a 3.5 per cent increase. I do not need to deal with the multiplying factors which previous Ministers of this Government have used about inflation figures. I just draw the attention of the Senate to the actual figure. At the end of the September quarter the growth in the CPI was 12.3 per cent. Up to August of this year the average annual rate of all Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries, compared with Australia's 12.3 per cent, was 7.8 per cent . In July only France and Canada, amongst all OECD countries, exceeded Australia 's rate of inflation. In the month of July, Japan's annual rate of inflation was 1.7 per cent; the United States, 8.5 per cent; the United Kingdom, 8.7 per cent; and West Germany, 5.6 per cent. The real concern is not these comparative figures but the fact that inflation is going down in the majority of OECD countries while in Australia it is going up. The inflation rate is now back where this Government started from and worse. The average rate of the European Economic Community was 10 per cent and falling, while the OECD rate was 7.8 per cent and falling. At the same time, if one looks at interest rates, the long term government bond rate in Australia is currently 13.2 per cent. In July, the equivalent rate in Japan was 8.3 per cent; in the United States, 13.9 per cent; in West Germany, 9.3 per cent; and in the United Kingdom, 12.1 per cent. Again, that is not a very favourable comparison for Australia.

Similarly, the Australian dollar continues to fall against the United States dollar. The figure published a week ago is Australia's lowest rate ever against the United States dollar. One can go through other indicators, such as housing approvals and the incomes of Australians. The average income of Australians has fallen significantly in the last seven years. Two million people are now said to be living on or around the poverty line. Consumer confidence is at its lowest in nine years and working families are now some $30 a week behind the living standards of seven years ago. I mention those things which, of course, can be the subject of dispute. That does not add up to a very impressive record for a government which has had three chances and should be denied any more if this country is to make any progress and get out of the current economic malaise which it is in.

A number of excuses are offered by the Government for this position. This Government is one of the world's experts in finding scapegoats and excuses for its own abysmal performance. The first excuse, of course, is that wages in Australia are too high and that there were large increases in wages in 1981. That is true and it is most undesirable. It is most undesirable that there should be any significant wage increases at the present time. But where does the explanation for all that lie? Where does it lie in terms of a government which promised to maintain the Prices Justification Trubunal, which is relevant to the question of wage fixation? Where does it lie in terms of a government which said that it would maintain wage indexation and in July of last year just abandoned it? This Government has no wages policy. I am not the only authority for that proposition. Mr Peacock, the new Minister for Industry and Commerce, argued the view quite recently that this Government has no wages policy except to say that wages are too high. In the absence of a wages policy, a government which assumes responsibility for the economic management of a country cannot get out of it by simply blaming wage earners and trade unions for the wage explosion of last year . This Government has had no success in negotiating towards a proper prices and incomes policy in this country and it will have no success. There has been a lot of talk of consensus in this debate. There is no person in this country who has done more to fracture the possibility of social consensus on these issues than the Prime Minister. The absence of the capacity to obtain a consensus because of promises made and readily abandoned is relevant to the whole question of a wages policy. The second thing is that this Government has said that it does not believe in having a centralised wages policy. Until it gets that fundamental question resolved it really has no hope of dealing with this issue.

The second excuse of this Government is that State charges are responsible for the increase on the consumer price index and the increase in inflation in Australia. State charges have increased, as have national government charges. I make the point that one of the reasons why State charges have increased, and probably the most significant reason, is the very fact that the present Government has embarked upon a policy of new federalism and it has not been prepared to meet its own obligations under its own stated policy of new federalism. The essence of the new federalism policy, which was enunciated with such fervour in 1976, is that governments should raise the money which they intend to expend. That is the simple proposition involved in all of that. There is much to be said for that view. But the Government has not done anything about carrying that view into effect. I do not wish to be an authority for that proposition, but Senator Chaney's friend, Professor Russell Mathews, has put it in these simple terms:
It is clear that the reason why no State has legislated for a surcharge--
He was talking about a tax surcharge-

Is that it would have to be superimposed on an already high and inequitably distributed burden of income taxation. If the Commonwealth had been sincere in its professed intention of permitting State personal income taxes, it should have made tax room for the States by simultaneously reducing its own tax rates and the level of tax sharing entitlements.

That puts it in a nutshell. It is one of the reasons why the States have had to raise charges. It is one of the reasons why the States are in their present budgetary positions. One could go on documenting, as it were, this Government's failures and crises in economic management and failures and crises in a resource -rich country which has seen a steady decline of its manufacturing industry, a steady growth in unemployment, and no hope for the future from this Government in respect of any of those things. What I suppose, personally, that I resent most about this Government is that it has turned the lucky country into the land of lost opportunities. It has had seven years of opportunities to do something about these issues which are now confronting it as nightmares. The progress in terms of encouraging new industries to this country, the progress in establishing or helping to establish high technology industries here, the progress in boosting the fortunes of manufacturing industry by sensitive restructuring programs, has not gone on at all. Nothing has happened. That is why it is a land of lost opportunities, after seven years of the Fraser Government. Unless we do some of these things, we are absolutely right in concluding that there is no hope. That is the greatest failure of this Government in terms of seven years of bad economic management-that none of these things has happened and that there is no promise for the future. These things have not happened because before each election the Government has been content to rely on some mythical boom that is about to take place, as a means of stimulating its own fortunes in the election, for the morale of the troops, and that sort of thing; but the booms and talk-ups of the economy have had no relation to reality. Any debate in this Parliament and any debate about the future of this country and the state of the economy must surely, now in present circumstances, be conducted on a basis of starting from realities. There is no agreement about starting from a basis of realities, and there is very little capacity now, after these seven years of experience, to obtain any agreement on those questions. I know that Senator Martyr will take the usual line, saying: ' the Whitlam Government was bad; look at the inflation rate in 1975'-or something like that.

TALK.START.PARA: —How did you know that he was going to say that?

—The simple answer to that question is that I have never heard honourable senators on the Government side say anything else, because they have nothing else to say. What they say is: 'We are awful, we look awful, because all the figures prove that. But the other people were awful, too.' That is a childish, pathetic argument from a government which assumed power on the basis that it would do better. It is a childish, pathetic argument which is raised here day after day by Senator Sir John Carrick, the Leader of the Government in the Senate. That is why the country is in the present mess-because the Government resorts to phoney booms and the sort of argument that goes 'things were crook years ago, so we are all right.' That is its alibi. That is a shocking alibi for a government in the present economic situation, for a government with a people so desperately concerned about the future of this country and about the immediate future economic management. Yesterday's proceedings here, in King's Hall, upset people a bit. All I can say is that it is the shape of things to come-that is very sad in this country-unless there is a change of direction. We shall let Senator Martyr have the opportunity to tell us where that is going to be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martyr Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin where Senator Button left off. When he prophesied that I would be saying something about the years of the failed Whitlam Government, of course he was right, because that is the only example in recent years that the people of this country have had to judge the now Opposition. It was an utter and complete failure. No one denies that, not even some of the people in its own ranks. I make two points immediately in regard to Senator Button's assertions about the prices and incomes policy. He does not understand that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has the job of balancing all the difficult and unreliable variables. If excessive demands are made, he must reject them firmly. That is his duty to the whole of Australia. So he is accused, because he is firm, of not looking for consensus.

SPEECH.PARA: Lord preserve us from this stupid and silly word 'consensus', which has appeared just recently in the vocabulary of the image makers. Consensus is not necessarily the answer to the problems of this country. It is another slogan word. It is like the subject matter of this debate today. It is just a slogan. We have heard it day after day and week after week, the same old thing. The Opposition feels that if it shouts this weekly from the house tops, someone will hear it. It is like the sower scattering his seed-except that in this case it is the blind hoping to give sight to the unsighted. Someone out there might believe it.

All Australians know that we have problems, but they know that the answers are difficult. They know that the economic anarchy that the Australian Labor Party proposes will make matters worse. That well known supporter of economic anarchy, Senator Grimes, always conveniently forgets the saying-it is one that we should all remember-of his former colleague, the former Treasurer, Frank Crean, that one man's wage rise is another man's job. That is true. The cost of labour is relevant in all economic argument. Minimum wage awards in this country are one of the greatest bars to the maximum utilisation of youth in the work force. If the trade unions will moderate demands somewhat, employment prospects must improve.

There are other reasons for unemployment. There were two news items today concerning the matter. One is about Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd refusing a request by the Federal Government to delay the retrenchment of nearly 400 colliery workers at Wollongong. The second is a mining union official saying that protests by coal mine workers would continue until the unions are satisfied that retrenchment by BHP and its subsidiaries is the only avenue left. In present circumstances, I believe that that is probably the only avenue that is left. There is no demand for the coal. Australia cannot produce steel economically. If we wish to preserve our markets for iron ore and coal to Japan and other cheap steel producers, we must be prepared to buy back some of the steel product. I realise the difficulty of employment around Newcastle and the Hunter Valley. But should not the unions have fought the conservationists who denied other employment opportunities of new industries which will not now be in the Hunter Valley?

As Senator Button mentioned, there is a connection between this matter of public importance debate today and the debate in the House of Representatives yesterday, both of which, I hope, are only coincidental with the disgraceful incidents that occurred here yesterday. There is no excuse whatsoever for the demonstation which damaged the doors of this building. I hope that Senator Button, in his speech earlier, was not threatening us with any more of the same. It does not need much logic to appreciate that pulling down this building will not solve any of Australia's problems, or any of the wreckers' problems either. Those who quietened the mob yesterday, whether they are from this side of the house, the other side or the police, deserve our thanks. I repeat that it should never have happened. I would have thought that the Opposition would have had enough of this sloganising after yesterday's caning it got in the House of Representatives, particularly the Leader of the Opposition in that place. However, Senator Grimes, Senator Button and others are gluttons for punishment. They keep coming back for more. They repeat the hyperbole of their colleagues in the other place.

We acknowledge that the problems exist. We have never run away from that, but we are doing as much as we reasonably can to solve them. Senator Grimes and others act and speak as though the Australian economy were nothing but a money tree-that if they just give it a shake it will solve all of the country's problems. Even the Leader of the Opposition in the other place, Mr Hayden, concedes that we have problems. I quote from his speech yesterday. He said:
One freely acknowledges that it is extremely difficult to handle a national economy at present, given the state of the world's economy.

I could not ask for a better basis on which to make my speech. I could not ask the Opposition in this place to do any more than to read those words of the Leader of the Opposition in the other place. But not all of the members of the Opposition agree. Some difference of opinion was expressed today from the views of the Leader of the Opposition in the other place. In a television interview on 25 October Mr Willis, the shadow Treasurer, was asked by the interviewer: 'Do you think any other government could have done better?'. He replied, naturally: 'I think we should have done better. I think we would have done better, yes'. Now let us see how well the Opposition performed when it did have the chance. At this stage I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table of figures on the consumer price index and average weekly earnings year by year for the last 10 years. The table was in the hands of Senator Button when he was at the table earlier. I understand he did agree to its incorporation.
Leave granted.
