TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Those figures show that it is ludicrous for the Opposition to say that the Government's anti-inflation policy has failed. On looking at the figures it will be seen how the Government has significantly reduced the inflation rate. Labor allowed it to rise by nearly 7 percentage points in 1973-74. The Governemnt has kept control over the pressures in the economy. It has kept control as best it could over the CPI and the AWE figures, unlike the Labor Government. Under Labor average weekly earnings shot up. They rose at a rate of 25 per cent in 1974-75, which naturally pushed up the inflation rate. We are now seeing a resurgence of wage pressures and we are all sorry about that. Average weekly earnings rose by nearly 15 per cent last year but the rise was 13.5 per cent in 1980-81. I repeat that this will have a bad effect on employment.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Giles said that we-the Government-blame the ordinary wage earner for economic troubles. Never. We blame those who mislead the workers, such as Senator Grimes and Senator Button. They create expectations which cannot be gratified, and so do some union leaders-not all of them-some of whom were here yesterday. Australia's problems are the problems of the world, as Mr Hayden has said. But we have a very high home ownership rate and a social security net with mesh so fine that hardly anyone goes wanting. Our social security system contains a policy of almost guaranteed minimum income for everybody in this country. These are the big differences between this country and some of the other countries that the Opposition has been speaking about. Remember that the home ownership rate in this country, as high as it is, is one of the greatest distinguishing factors between Australia and other countries. Certainly we have unemployment but by world standards, as some of the other Government speakers have demonstrated, it is not the worst. As I have said, the social security system is so good that no one is yet suffering-and never will-as people did in the 1930s Depression.

Opposition speakers in the Senate do a disservice when they raise the spectre of the 1930s. No one in government wants worse unemployment than we presently have. Opposition speakers laud European socialist parties and the governments that they form. My recent experience, having visited the nordic countries during the recess, is that they doctor their unemployment figures. Their deficits are far worse than ours as a proportion of gross domestic product. Senator Hill's description of France as a financial failure is quite right, and for one sound reason-it has gone in for huge public expenditure as the solution for its problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now it is going the other way.

—That is right. President Mitterand has recently confessed that the direction is wrong and that France must pursue a direction more in line with that which this Government is taking. Australia's troubles are linked, as Mr Hayden said, with world problems. Australia is employing similar methods to those outlined in the most recent issue of the Economist, from which I will quote. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: If inflationary expectations can be conquered, that might allow a return towards the happy-and technologically actually less promising-two decades after 1948 when in most industrial countries a 6 per cent rise in money demand used to bring something like a 5 per cent growth and one per cent inflation. Since 1968, and especially since 1973, a 6 per cent rise in money supply has more usually brought 6 per cent inflation and 0 per cent growth for the logical reason that it has been more profitable to use any extra money to buy an inflation hedge than to invest in industry.
The Economist is one of the most authoritative economic journals in the world. I think it is worth quoting. It further states:

Economic growth depends on all four of (a) new technology; (b) the existence of entrepreneurial business mechanisms; (c) the absence of gross inflationary expectations; (d) whether the recent macroeconomic policies of government and banks have been prudent or potty.

In America, more than in Britain and probably in Australia too, the forward prospects of new technology and the existence of enterprise and business mechamisms look remarkably good. The prospects in the world at the moment, in the absence of gross inflationary expectations, are improving and the rapid fall in interest rates suggests that Reagan and Thatcher macroeconomics have not been entirely potty. This is an accurate assessment of the present world situation. On looking at the present macroeconomic policies of this Government it will be plain that they fit more broadly into that context than into any other. I submit that we are on the right track. We are locked into a world situation and we must rely on exports to pay our way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—It may not suit Senator Walsh, but we are locked into that world situation. If world markets are difficult Australia suffers and we have to make the necessary domestic adjustments, unpleasant thought they are. Unrestrained increases in public expenditure, as in France, will destroy our fight against inflation, which will not assist the quest for full employment. As world conditions improve, so will the Australian economy. Labor's plans, on the other hand, summed up in the Australian Financial Review today, and summed up very well-
—How would you know? How could you possibly know? You have been in all the other parties but not Labor.

—I have learnt a lot in the other parties. I learnt a lot when I was in the honourable senator's before he was, and that was a long time ago. The Australian Financial Review summed up the Australian Labor Party's policies very well. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: This leaves the Labor Party with a fiscal program which promises nothing but unemployment and inflation on a larger scale than we have now-

That is absolutely tragic. It is a shame that such a great party that once had such great men has to rely on people of the low calibre which it has at the moment. Indeed, the Australian Financial Review stated that there are ' occasional disastrous short periods of ineffectual and disintegrating Labor governments'. That is a magnificent summing up of the failure of Labor in its three years of government. The Government has answered every single assertion of the Opposition today. We have shown that the Labor Party's policies will not solve the problems that we have today. Its policies will run us into greater and greater debt. The Labor Party will use once again-if it ever has the opportunity -the printing press to buy its way out of the difficulties that confront this country. Let us hope it never has the opportunity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Mason) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to give effect to the Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage.
Bill presented, and-by leave-read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate my second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The introduction of this legislation marks a significant turning point for environmental law in Australia. This Bill proposes that effect be given in Australia to the International Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage-'World Heritage Convention'. In doing so this Bill does nothing more than put into legislation the responsibilities that this Federal Government has accepted by endorsing the World Heritage Convention. It would create for the first time in Australia truly national parks. The World Heritage Convention was adopted by the General Conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation on 16 November 1972. Australia ratified and thereby became a State Party to the Convention on 22 August 1974. The Convention came into force on 17 December 1975, three months after the twentieth instrument of ratification was deposited with UNESCO. The Convention is aimed at identifying and protecting the world's cultural and natural heritage .

Cultural heritage includes: 'sites . . . areas including archaeological sites which are of outstanding universal value from the historical, aesthetic, ethnological or anthropological points of view.' (Article 1) 'Natural heritage' is defined as: natural features consisting of physical and biological formations or groups of such formations, which are of outstanding universal value from the aesthetic or scientific point of view: Geological and physiographical formations and precisely delineated areas which constitute the habitat of threatened species of animals and plants of outstanding universal value from the point of view of science or conservation; natural sites or precisely delineated natural areas of outstanding universal value from the point of view of science, conservation or natural beauty. (Article 2) Each State Party to the Convention is required to identify those properties situated on its territory which form part of the world cultural and natural heritage; it then submits an inventory of those properties to the World Heritage Committee, which may include each property on the World Heritage List.

To date, Australian property on the list includes sections of the Great Barrier Reef, the Willandra Lakes Region and Kakadu National Park, while the Wilderness regions of South-West Tasmania and Lord Howe Island have been nominated. By becoming a party to the Convention, Australia recognises that '. . . the identification, protection, conservation, presentation and transmission to future generations of the cultural and natural heritage . . . situated on its territory . . .' is primarily its own duty; further it undertakes that: it will do all that it can to this end, to the utmost of its own resources . . . ( Article 4) Article 5 of the Convention sets out a number of more specific obligations which the Australian Government assumed when it ratified the Convention; these include: to take the appropriate . . . legal administrative and financial measures necessary for the identification. (Article 5 (D)) The Australian government has also agreed to . . . endeavour by all appropriate means . . . to strengthen appreciation and respect (by the people of Australia) of the cultural and natural heritage . . . keep the public broadly informed of the dangers threatening this heritage and of activities carried on in pursuance of this Convention. (Article 27)

This Bill is being introduced at a time when Australia is engulfed in the most significant and controversial environmental battle for some time-the battle to save the Franklin and Gordon Rivers in Tasmania, and the wilderness of South- West Tasmania. It is an unequivocal policy of the Australian Democrats-at both State and Federal level-that the magnificent and scientifically significant environment of South-West Tasmania be preserved for all time. The end result of this Bill would be to ensure that South-West Tasmania would be saved for future generations in accordance with Australia's obligations under the World Heritage Convention. Importantly, it would also enable those other areas already on the World Heritage List, and those areas that could be nominated in future, to be given the full protection of Commonwealth Law as required.

The Commonwealth has long recognised the unique place of the South-West as part of Australia's natural heritage; this recognition was made concrete in 1980 when the South-West wilderness was entered upon the Register of the National Estate.

Tasmania has also recognised the value of the South-West by what was until recently a continual expansion of the areas of wilderness dedicated to the public in the form of conservation areas and national parks. On 13 November 1981 the Commonwealth, acting on the recommendation and with the approval of the Tasmanian Government, officially nominated the Western Tasmania Wilderness National Parks for inscription on the World Heritage List. The World Heritage Committee will consider that nomination at its meeting in December 1982. The fact that Australia has nominated the South-West for inscription on the World Heritage List is an express recognition by the Commonwealth that the South-West forms part of the world cultural and natural heritage.

Having recognised and identified a part of this heritage, the Commonwealth immediately becomes subject to the obligations of the Convention in relation to that part of the heritage. It is not necessary for an area to be inscribed on the World Heritage List before the obligations imposed by the Convention come into play: although inscription on the World Heritage List gives an area an ' official' recognition and status, the Convention applies to all identified and delineated areas which fall within 'cultural heritage' or 'natural heritage' as defined by the Convention. It is thus vital that not only areas included upon the World Heritage List, but also those nominated for it, are fully protected. This Bill provides for that. Clearly, obligations are imposed on the Australian Government by the World Heritage Convention. For our support and promotion of this convention to remain credible we must act now to give the Convention effect in Australia. Support for this Bill will accomplish that. The general position, under the Australian Constitution, is that the Commonwealth Government does not have legislative authority in respect of land use control. However, there are exceptions to this proposition and the question must always be resolved by reference to the heads of power set out in section 51 of the Constitution.

If, in relation to a particular matter, there is a relevant head of power then the Commonwealth Parliament has the constitutional authority to legislate and that legislation over-rides any inconsistent legislation of a State-section 109 of the Constitution. This was the basis which enabled the Federal Government to introduce the Defence (Visiting Warships) Bill 1982 and over-ride the Victorian Government's proposed ban on nuclear warships. The Australian Democrats concurred with the Federal Government in this move. Section 51 of the Constitution provides that the Commonwealth Parliament shall have power to make laws with respect to external affairs. This power was recently considered by the High Court of Australia in the case of Koowarta v. Bjelke-Petersen (1982). The Court, by a majority, held that the Racial Discrimination Act 1975, enacted by the Commonwealth Parliament, was supported by the external affairs power. The legislation was a statutory implementation of the Internal Convention of on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination (1966). The Court rejected arguments that the external affairs power should read down to exclude areas otherwise within the concern of the Australian States. The majority pointed to the significance of the fact that a particular matter had been the subject of an International Convention.

The approach taken in the judgments in Koowarta appears equally applicable to the World Heritage Convention. This was a Convention entered into by a large number of countries under the auspices of an agency of the United Nations. It deals with a matter regarded as being a matter of international concern. It follows that the Commonwealth Parliament has power to enact legislation to implement, within Australia, its obligations under that Convention. It would certainly apply to areas nominated by the Australian Government, and accepted by the World Heritage Committee, as meeting the criterion for inclusion on the World Heritage List namely 'having outstanding universal value'. The Commonwealth Parliament has already recognised its entitlement to legislate in respect of the Convention. The National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975 contains a provision section 69, empowering the Governor-General to make regulations for and in relation to giving effect to various specified agreements . These include the World Heritage Convention. It is quite possible that the Federal Government could regulate to preserve the South-West. All people concerned with the environment would welcome such a move so long as it achieved the aim of full preservation. Unfortunately we have waited and waited for the Federal Government to act.

For the sake of the wilderness we can wait no longer. Every day that the Government delays is another day in which more destruction will be wrought on the environment. Roads are being gouged in to the proposed dam site. Quarries are being excavated and camps are being built. This activity has resulted in a serious fire in the area. In order to live up to the obligations we have imposed on ourselves as a nation, by ratifying the World Heritage Convention and nominating South-West Tasmania, we must enact the Convention. The political and economic arguments have little place in this debate. The essence of this debate is that firstly, South-West Tasmania is a magnificent wilderness area that has been explicitly recognised as such by both State and Federal Governments and secondly, Australia has ratified the World Heritage Convention which gives us, as a nation, an obligation to ensure those areas of our natural and cultural heritage we have nominated are fully protected. There is an obligation that we have accepted and must act upon. I urge all those who are concerned with the preservation of our environment to support this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robertson) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like some indication from the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) as to when in fact the debate on the Appropriation Bills will resume. We were informed last week that the Supply Bills-the all important Supply Bills-were to be introduced yesterday. The Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats agreed to that change in plan and agreed to expedite the passage of the Supply Bills notwithstanding what has been said publicly by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony). The Bills have now been introduced a day later than the Government indicated. We would like some indication as to when the Supply Bills will be listed for debate in this House.

SPEECH.PARA: I think at this stage it is significant that I raise this matter because rumours are flying around this Parliament to the effect that the House of Representatives will be rising tomorrow night and will not be recalled for the remainder of the year. Yet we have the Appropriation Bills, or the Supply Bills, brought into the Senate today-a Wednesday-with no indication from the Government as to when they are to be debated. Do I take it that the Government wishes the Supply Bills to be debated and passed by this chamber tomorrow? This means that the Senate would then be asked to undertake the extraordinary course of passing, in a matter of two or three hours, Bills that normally take the Senate when it is working at full speed something like 17 or 18 hours. Do I take it that if the House of Representatives rises tomorrow for the year and the Governor-General grants a double dissolution in the week off to the Prime Minister the Senate will be asked to resume on 9 November to pass the Supply Bills without any debate at all?

Frankly I am surprised that our colleagues in the Labor Party are not concerning themselves about this matter. If the scenario that is being rumoured in Parliament House at the moment comes true it is possible that, unless we get a guarantee from the Government, the Supply Bills will not be debated at all by the Senate when it rises tomorrow night and that a double dissolution will be announced the following week or the day after the South Australian election with the result that the House of Representatives would have been adjourned for the year and the Senate would then need to be recalled, after a double dissolution has been granted, and told that it has half an hour to pass the Supply Bills which deal with hundreds of millions of dollars of expenditure. I raise these matters because I think they are serious. In having the Bills listed on the Notice Paper for future debate I think that the Senate is entitled to some indication from the Minister as to when in fact this debate will be resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply- In moving as I did 'that the resumption of the debate be made an order of the day for the next day of sitting' I think Senator Chipp would accept that the motion is the usual form of words, and that that means any next day of sitting, not necessarily tomorrow. As I understand it, it is not contemplated that the Appropriation Bills will be debated tomorrow.
—It is not?

— No. They will be listed for debate when we resume after the week up next week. As far as any arrangements that were made for the introduction of the Bills are concerned, they were passed in the House of Representatives late last night and this is the earliest opportunity at which a message could come to this House introducing the Bills. Now that the adjournment has been moved on the first reading the Bills will be placed on the Notice Paper. I would expect that subject to arrangements made between the Whips with regard to the arrangement of business the Bills would be listed for early debate in the week we resume after the week's recess next week.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The purpose of this Bill is to appropriate moneys for the service of the Parliamentary Departments for the year ending 30 June 1983.

The Bill seeks appropriations of the Consolidated Revenue Fund in 1982-1983 totaling $30,208,000. Of this amount, $10,902,000 was authorised by the Supply Act (No. 1) 1982-83, the balance of $19,306,000 being authorised by this Bill.

The Bill arises from the Government's consideration of, and response to, the report of the Senate Select Committee on Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing which was tabled on 19 August 1981. Two of the principal recommendations of the report dealt with the provision of a separate parliamentary appropriation Bill and with the Parliament's control of its funding.

Honourable senators will recall that the Government agreed to the provision of a separate appropriation Bill which, consistent with the Select Committee's recommendations, will not be treated as a Bill for the ordinary annual services of the Government. Honourable senators will also recall that the Government recognised that detailed control over individual expenditure items for the Parliament was not necessary. Accordingly, the Government proposed that it would approve the overall recurrent and capital expenditure provision of the Bill. This has been done and the amounts included in the Bill have been agreed to between the Leaders of the Houses and the Presiding Officers.

The Schedule to this Bill is the same as that contained in the document ' Particulars of Proposed Expenditure for the Service of the year ending on 30 June 1983 in relation to the Parliamentary Departments' which was referred to the Senate Estimates Committees on 24 August 1982 for examination and report. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT BILL (No. 5) 1982 [No. 2]
Debate resumed from 21 October, on motion by Senator Messner:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I call Senator Walsh.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Walsh-On a matter of procedure, I understood that the Government wanted to have a cognate debate on the tax Bills.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Senate agree that that course should be followed?

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Chipp-I take a point of order. Do we not need the formal agreement of the Senate before such a course can be undertaken? I was proposing to say a word or two about these Bills being debated cognately.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted for the Bills to be debated cognately? There being no objection, leave is granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: -The package of Bills-six or seven in all-currently being debated involves changes in taxation laws pursuant to the measures announced with, and as part of, the Budget. Major changes are proposed in respect of the threshold and the rate at which personal income tax is payable . This, of course, will be trumpeted by the Government over the next couple of weeks as a major tax cut. Indeed, the Government has filched $1 1/2m from the taxpayers through a one-line appropriation in the estimates for the Department of the Treasury to advertise at public expense, to conduct a political advertising campaign and to maximise its political gain from these changes to the tax law. I use the term 'changes to tax rates' quite advisedly because it is misleading and it misrepresents the facts to call these changes 'tax cuts'.

SPEECH.PARA: What these changes do is effectively to apply the principle of indexation. In other words, as a result of these changes being made, what the Prime Minister ( Mr Malcolm Fraser) used to call the secret tax of inflation and what economists call fiscal drag are to be cancelled for this year. But, in real terms, the amount of income tax paid by individuals will be the same this year as it was in the previous year barring only changes in real levels of income. If anything, of course, real incomes are likely to go down because the economy is now in the tail spin of a depression. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard-I apologise for not having shown them to the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) yet-tables which are the same as those Mr Willis had incorporated when this legislation was debated in the House of Representatives.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. These tables demonstrate the amount of tax payable in real terms as a proportion of income by taxpayers in various categories. The broad conclusion that can be drawn from those tables is that 98 per cent of taxpayers are paying more tax than they did seven years ago and that taxpayers overall will pay the same real level of taxation this year as they paid in the previous financial year.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point I make about these changes, which the Government misrepresents as tax cuts, is that if there were to be an election this year and if as a result of some unforeseeable circumstance this Government were returned to office, we could be quite certain that these so-called tax cuts would be cancelled as they were cancelled in 1977. It is apparent and quite clear that there is going to be a $1 billion-or thereabouts-shortfall in revenue. A major reason for that shortfall is the very substantial watering down, indeed the near emasculation, of the proposed recoupment legislation which is designed to recover company and Division 7 tax evaded by people who sold companies with current year profits to so-called bottom-of-the-harbour operators. In the Bill as it was represented to the House of Representatives last week, some 700 companies-about one-sixth of the total-are to be completely exempt from the recoupment legislation. The amount of current year profit, and therefore of forgone revenue, involved is likely to be very much greater than one-sixth. Indeed, in that amendment alone, in that cave-in to the tax cheats alone, the Government has forgone one-third to one-half of the revenue it had previously aimed to recoup through this legislation.

The second change with equally important ramifications for this financial year is that, provided the vendor shareholders make a downpayment of 25 per cent, they will have 12 months to pay the other 75 per cent. These, remember, are the people the Prime Minister was describing only last month as recipients of stolen money. They are the Prime Minister's words. Recipients of stolen money are to be given 12 months to pay back the money which they stole. Are we to anticipate that the Government will bring in legislation to give bank robbers and thieves in general 12 months after they have been caught to pay back money they have stolen? The money which the Prime Minister says was stolen and which people now will not have to repay will not even carry an interest charge.

Even Mr Sinclair pays interest on the money that he says his father stole from the Walsh companies, some of which he still has. He pays only 10 per cent and has done so since August 1980, whereas at least some of the funds, according to the documents that the Minister himself provided to the House of Representatives , were misappropriated a decade before that; but at least he is paying something . These tax cheats, these recipients of stolen money, as the Prime Minister has designated them, have not to pay the money back for 12 months. Some have not to pay it back at all. Even those who have to pay it back eventually will not have to pay interest between the time when they receive the assessment and the time by which they will have to complete repayments.

The Prime Minister has linked what the Government chooses to call tax cuts with the additional revenue that at one time it was claimed would be gained as a result of this recoupment legislation. The Prime Minister said that they were mirror images of each other, two sides of the same coin. On one side we had the recoupment legislation and on the other we had what he called tax cuts; the one was to finance the other. What now will finance these so-called tax cuts? More importantly, if the Government had not sat on its hands, or twiddled its thumbs for five years after it found out about this massive tax evasion, we could have had real tax cuts every year. The Prime Minister knew in 1977 that these schemes were in operation but it was not until 1982, after the publication of the Costigan and McCabe-Lafranchi reports, that he was stricken with an attack of retrospective morality-induced, obviously, not by any moral outrage, since he had known five years earlier what was going on, but by fear of electoral retribution.

The second most important taxation change contained in this package of Bills- although to some extent that is a matter of judgment-is that which provides a rebate of 30c in the dollar for interest payments above a 10 per cent rate on the first $60,000 of a housing loan when the subject house is the principal residence of the taxpayer. It had been the intention of the Opposition to seek to amend this provision in both Houses in order to restrict the benefit to taxpayers who owned only one house; also, to phase it out in respect of loans exceeding $60,000 until, at the $80,000 level it disappeared completely. There were technical problems in doing that and I do not propose to go into them at this stage. However, an expression of opinion that that should be done has been incorporated in a proposed second reading amendment which I shall read shortly. First, I will explain why we propose to do that.

The Opposition does not believe, especially in a time of alleged economic stringency, as it certainly is for very many people, that tax subsidies should be made available to people with loans in respect of luxury houses totalling from $100,000 to $500,000 or, as in one specific case of which I am aware, $3m. Such people are already treated with undue favouritism by the tax laws. We do not believe an extra concession should be extended to them, nor do we believe that people who own multiple numbers of houses should be entitled to such a concession. I will cite one example of the way in which the legislation which the Government has introduced will operate. The Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) is having a luxury unit built alongside Telopea Park. If he declares it to be his principal residence, he will qualify for a tax rebate in respect of all interest payments in excess of 10 per cent on the first $60,000 of the loan. He may still keep the second house that he owns in Canberra, on which he has a 4 .75 per cent government loan which he granted to himself in 1964, 80 per cent of which he has still not repaid. I repeat, he has a 4.75 per cent government loan in respect of that house in Canberra. Provided he declares the proposed luxury unit in Canberra to be his principal residence he will receive a tax rebate on the first $60,000 of the loan therefor. I have no idea how many units or houses he might own elsewhere. That is the kind of thing this Bill permits. No wonder people who have lost their jobs because of this Government's mismanagement were yesterday battering the front doors of Parliament House. In contrast, the Deputy Prime Minister is treated in the way I have described. Despite this, the Prime Minister has the chutzpah to talk about governing fairly in the interests of all Australians.

I will summarise quickly the other major measures which are contained in this package of Bills and the changes they will make. The tax rebate for a dependent spouse or daughter-housekeeper is to be increased by $200. There will be a rebate for pensioners to ensure that those who are overwhelmingly dependent on a pension but also have some outside income will not pay income tax. Those provisions are to take effect on 1 November as, indeed, I believe are all of the provisions before us. I have already mentioned the housing interest rebate. There is also to be a rebate on the first $1,000 of dividends received by shareholders in companies and an easing of the Division 7 tax rules to permit proprietary companies to retain 80 per cent of operating profit, not distributing it to shareholders, without incurring a tax penalty. Previously the limit was 70 per cent. Since it applies to income already earned, this is a retrospective benefit. Significantly, I have not noticed any protest from Senator Crichton-Browne or anyone else about a retrospective benefit being given , vocal though some honourable senators are about the alleged injustice of what they claim to be retrospective penalties.

But more important than the inconsistent standards of assorted Liberal Party politicians-something to which we have become accustomed-is the fact that the use of proprietary companies was a key factor in the sort of tax evasion and avoidance that was the subject of the McCabe-Lafranchi report. The greater the extent to which proprietary companies can keep their income within the company, the greater is the scope and the potential for tax avoidance and evasion in the future. It is no doubt true that there are some companies which operate quite legitimate businesses, socially useful businesses, and which find it difficult sometimes to carry on, or more often to expand, if they are required to disburse as dividends a high proportion of company income. However, there are other options. They are not pie in the sky options. They are options which are already operating, at least in the United Kingdom and the United States of America, under which the Commissioner of Taxation is given discretionary power to waive the tax penalty on undistributed profits which would otherwise apply if the company is facing genuine hardship or has a legitimate commercial reason-as distinct from a tax evading reason-for retaining a greater proportion of its profits within the company. That is what should be done here.

But what this Government has chosen to do at the same time as it claims to be cracking down on tax cheats-recipients of stolen funds, as the Prime Minister calls them-is to water down the legislation aimed against the tax cheats who have already been caught and to open up loopholes for the next generation of tax cheats to exploit in the future. Legitimate business could have been protected without that being done.

There is also a provision in the Bills to extend the list of organisations to which donations are deductible from taxable income. The Opposition will seek to remove one of those organisations from the list. That will be the subject of a Committee stage amendment. The organisation is the Centre for Independent Studies. I will explain the reasons for that action when we come to the Committee stage. There is a change in the basis by which provisional tax is calculated, designed to pad the revenue for this year, and there are a few other minor or machinery matters. Since these are Budget measures the Opposition, in accordance with the broad declaration of policy made two months ago, will not oppose them. However I will move a second reading amendment which encompasses most of the objections to the legislation that I have already raised. I move:
At end of motion, add ', but the Senate is of the opinion that-

(a) the home loan rebate is unduly generous to wealthy home-buyers and open to exploitation in that it provides benefits to persons owning more than one residence and is available on large loans in excess of $60,000;
(b) the further increase in the retention allowance to 80 per cent will widen avenues for tax avoidance;
(c) the introduction of a tax concession to shareholders through a rebate on the first $1,000 of dividend income is inequitable; and
(d) the Bill should provide mortgage assistance to those home purchasers not in receipt of taxable income such as the unemployed and pensioners'.

In summary, the most important component of the Bills is that which changes the rates at which personal income tax will be applied. That change is a de facto indexation of last year's rates. In other words, it will maintain the same real level of taxation as prevailed last year. Of course, it will be misrepresented by the Government as a tax cut. For that misrepresentation $1.5m of public money has already been filched through the Treasury estimates-at least the Government has attempted to filch it through the Treasury estimates-to be used in a political advertising campaign to mislead the public.

The second point is that those tax changes will not last if Malcolm Fraser remains Prime Minister. We know that he went through that exercise in 1977, of making changes before the election which reduced the amount of money which people paid in tax and then, after the election, increasing it over and above the rate which had prevailed previously. There is little doubt that he had that in mind in any case. The fact that the revenue will fall short by around $1 billion, due to a substantial extent to the Government's servile surrender to the tax cheats over its proposed recoupment legislation, guarantees that the tax cuts would be cancelled after an election if this Prime Minister were returned.

The Budget figures in general show that, despite all the talk about tax cuts, the estimates of total tax collections as a proportion of gross domestic product , as contained in the Budget Papers, showed an increase in that figure from 25.5 per cent to 25.7 per cent. Notwithstanding the fact that tax collections will fall well short of the estimates provided in the Budget-for, among other reasons , as I said, the backdown in the tax recoupment legislation-there will not be a commensurate fall in tax collections as a percentage of GDP because GDP will clearly be significantly lower than was forecast at the time the Budget was brought down. It will be lower for at least two reasons: Firstly, because the level of umemployment, on the Government's admission now, will be substantially higher than was forecast in the Budget Papers and, secondly, because the drought is substantially worse than would reasonably have been expected when the Budget Estimates were prepared. So, even though there will be an absolute decline in the tax actually collected compared with what the Government had forecast, the tax paid as a proportion of GDP will fall by less than that amount suggests because GDP growth will be negative. In other words, total GDP will fall this year, on present indications, by something between one per cent and 2 per cent.

Of course, this package was designed not with the intention of providing a taxation system which was equitable or which was efficient; it was designed to give the Prime Minister some chance-at least he thought it would give him some chance-to retain government in a premature election which, without any doubt, he had planned to call some time this year. Two months ago the Opposition gave the undertaking, based on the policy statement that 'this is Malcolm Fraser's Budget and he can live with the consequences of it', that it would not oppose Budget measures. We will not oppose them. But I trust that the Australian Democrats and Senator Harradine will join us in expressing, by way of a second reading amendment, our disapproval of a number of specific inequities in this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak very briefly. I wish to acknowledge three worthwhile changes to our tax laws that will arise as a result of the Budget and the income tax Bills. These changes have been called for by me , and no doubt others, in the past. I think it is only fair that now they are being implemented the Government should receive the credit it deserves for the changes. Unfortunately, in these difficult times the Parliament and the media have been distracted from what has appeared in the Budget and these Bills. They are most worthwhile reforms for which the Government deserves credit. The first relates to the income tax relief which the legislation will implement. There is to be both an increase in the taxation threshold and a reduction in income tax rates. Specifically, the Bills provide an increase in the zero step from $4,195 to $4,595; an increase in the top of the standard rate step from $17,894 to $19, 500, and a reduction in the standard rate of tax from 32 per cent to 30 per cent .

SPEECH.PARA: In a speech I made in the Senate on 23 February this year I argued at some length the desirability of changing the tax mix in Australia. I argued that there should be a reduction in income tax in favour of a corresponding increase in and broadening of the indirect tax base. I do not propose to canvass in detail the reasons I gave then. However, I did indicate that such a better tax mix would lessen tax avoidance, encourage incentive and, if well structured, could improve equity. The Government has, by these Bills, taken a small step towards achieving that better tax mix. I want to acknowledge that step because I am sure that it will lead to a better tax system for all Australians.

The second matter I raise concerns the granting of rebates on dividends. The Bills provide a rebate at the standard rate of tax of up to $1,000 on dividends received by resident individual shareholders from resident companies. On 27 May this year I urged reform in this area, an area which has been commonly referred to as double taxation of dividends. It is regrettable that although that reform had been widely called for before the Budget, since the Budget there has not been the public recognition of the change which I think is due. Again, I do not want to canvass the reasons which I detailed on the occasion of my earlier speech, but I did point to the inequities of the previous double taxation of dividends-that is, the lack of neutrality and the disincentive to small shareholders to invest directly in the share markets and, therefore, in the nation's growth. I indicated that there would be no better time to introduce the reform than in what was then the forthcoming Budget. It is pleasing to me that the reform was contained in the Budget, albeit at this stage in a somewhat limited form. Nevertheless, it is a major reform and a major step in the right direction. I believe it is a reform which should be applauded.

The third matter I want to mention on this occasion is that on 4 May this year I spoke of the need for an accelerated depreciation allowance on plant and for the Government to consider for the first time allowing for depreciation of income producing buildings in order that Australian business might be in a position to compete on equal terms with its overseas competitors. These reforms were announced in a statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) on 19 July 1982 as part of the Government's package of assistance to industry. The measures were described by the Australian Financial Review as a major reform. That is a reform which I wish to give recognition to on this occasion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a package of income tax Bills which give effect to the income tax changes which were included in the 1982-83 Budget. These tax changes are to operate from 1 November. Three of the Bills are of a purely machinery nature and I do not intend to discuss them in any detail. However, two of them are important and I want to make one or two points about them. As previous speakers have pointed out, it is very plain that the tax cuts that these Bills will introduce were intended as a juicy carrot for an early Federal election. We may still have an early election, although I am sure that such a cynical abuse of power would be treated by the Australian people with the contempt it deserves. We will have to wait and see. I believe there is little doubt in anybody's mind that the tax cuts were put in essentially as an incentive to the electorate in the event of an early election.

SPEECH.PARA: In earlier debates on the Budget I indicated the Australian Democrats' attitude to the Budget in general and I pointed out that the Budget was essentially contractionary when adjusted for cyclical factors. It is true that tax cuts represent a step in the right direction, but I must point out that they have been skilfully adjusted to benefit the most politically sensitive area as far as the Government is concerned. The wealthy will benefit most from these measures. I am afraid that the poor will have no reason to be thankful to the Treasurer, Mr Howard. The Bills also allow the proposed Home Deposit Assistance Scheme to go ahead. This scheme has been debated at great length in this chamber and I do not propose to discuss it further.

However, I would like to highlight briefly one aspect of the Bills which I believe is significant. It was mentioned by Senator Hill just a moment ago. I refer to the significant gesture which the Government has made regarding the elimination of double taxation on dividends. The total elimination of double taxation on dividends is Democrats policy. It is outrageous that there has been double taxation for so long in this country. We would like to see it totally eliminated. We believe the double taxation on dividends is one of the principal reasons that there has been a marked lack of entrepreneurial capital available in this country. Essentially, companies are taxed twice; they are taxed on their profits and the profits are taxed again in the form of a tax on dividends in the hands of the individual. It could well be argued that there is a third tax in the sense that some companies have to sustain a tax on their undistributed profits. There is no doubt that this triple whammy on companies has been the reason that no major manufacturing companies have been established in this country in the last 10 years. Some manufacturing companies have been established as a result of overseas initiatives but there have been no indigenous manufacturing companies established here. Unlike the Australian Labor Party, we will be supporting this measure. We think that it is very much a step in the right direction. It has been Democrats policy ever since our formation. The fact that the large investor will benefit as well as the small investor is unfortunate. We would have liked to see some special incentive for the smaller investor, but this is the way the Government has dealt with the matter so we will let that be.

I would like to make some very brief comments on taxation generally. I point out that in Great Britain companies that have earnings of less than #100,000 get a significant tax rebate. Only by a measure such as this, or some other similar incentive to small business, can we expect this vital sector of the economy to be stimulated. We believe that the innovative and labour-creating initiatives in the economy are to be found within small business and much more attention should be given to it. I also give notice that we will not be supporting the Australian Labor Party's amendments for the deletion of the special tax grant deductibility for the Centre for Independent Studies. Whilst my own political sympathies are not in keeping with those which have been associated with the Centre, I agree with Voltaire, who said:
I disapprove of what you say, but I will defend to the death your right to say it.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you won't pay it, though. It is not quite the same as what Voltaire meant.

—We have investigated the Centre to some degree. It has put out a reasoned critique from time to time of the way the Australian economy works. It has arrived at conclusions with which I personally disagree very strenuously but it has done work in an investigatory manner and I believe it has to be recognised as a body able to perform such work. Perhaps the Government's magnanimous gesture in this respect to the Centre for Independent Studies could be counterbalanced by a similar grant to the Melbourne University Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research.
—Or even the Fabian Society.

—Or even the Fabian Society. We have indicated that we will not interfere with the passage of major money Bills. This package of tax Bills is basic and fundamental to the Government's economic strategy. We welcome two aspects of this legislation: The reduction in taxation is a step in the right direction and the elimination of double taxation on dividends has been Democrats policy since our foundation. So, like the Opposition, we will not be opposing these Bills at all. We support them and wish them a speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate for the speedy passage of the Income Tax Bills. As has been said, they are Budget measures providing benefits, adjustments to rates and the range of things that was announced in the Budget and about which we have been talking for the last couple of months. I have noted the Opposition's amendment moved to the second reading and state that the Government does not accept it. Part (a) of the amendment refers to the home loan rebate. The Opposition's criticism is that it is unduly generous to wealthy home buyers as it gives a rebate to persons with more than one home and on the first $60,000 to persons with a loan of over $60,000. I respond on behalf of the Government by saying that both the existing scheme-the first five years of owner occupation-and the new scheme apply to the sole or principal residence of a taxpayer situated in Australia, notwithstanding that the taxpayer may own other houses. That it applies to the sole or principal residence is not something that has been introduced in this new scheme. That is the same as the existing provision.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point made by the Opposition was that mortgages could be shifted from other houses to the sole or principal residence and that mortgages could be arranged to be on the sole or principal residence instead of on other houses owned by the taxpayer. I respond to that by saying that a qualifying loan has to be applied to the construction, extension or acquisition of the sole or principal residence, and that is a matter of fact to be determined in each case. It will not be, as indicated by the Opposition in its amendment, a matter of choice for the taxpayer to exert. The loan cannot be switched from another property to the dwelling in question, nor can a new loan using an already owned home as security qualify for the rebate unless the loan is for the purpose of extending the home. The suggested opportunity for exploitation does not exist and, as I have said, the Government does not accept the amendment to the second reading moved by Senator Walsh. I have a Government amendment, and I understand there is an Opposition amendment, to be moved in Committee. At this stage I commend the Bills to the Senate.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be added (Senator Walsh's amendment) be added.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Government, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 4, clause 5, lines 29 and 30, leave out 'the armed forces of Israel', substitute 'foreign forces'.

The amendment was foreshadowed by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) in his second reading speech on the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1982 [No. 2]. Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 4, clause 5, sub-clause (1), paragraph (a), proposed sub-paragraph 78 (1) (a) (lxxv), line 43, leave out the proposed sub-paragraph.

This amendment appears to be fairly meaningless because it refers to various identifying marks in the Bill. Perhaps it would be better if I were to explain in simple English what the amendment means. The amendment proposes to remove the Centre for Independent Studies from the list of organisations to which contributions are tax deductible. The reason why the Opposition has decided to move this amendment is that it is firmly of the view-I think any fair minded person who examined the literature put out by this organisation would agree-that the Centre for Independent Studies is a very political organisation, not just in the discussion of politics in an academic sense but political in a very partisan way. We do not believe that it is appropriate that donations to an overtly and very partisan political organisation should be tax deductible.

I am not saying that the Centre is aligned to the Liberal Party per se although its views are in harmony with the right wing of the Liberal Party. It is certainly a partisan political organisation. We believe that, if the Income Tax Assessment Act were opened up in this way, it would set an unfortunate precedent which could be extended to cover a whole host of very partisan and also very extreme political organisations. We do not believe that is an appropiate use of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not accept the Opposition's amendment. The decision to admit the Centre for Independent Studies followed representations to the Government by the Centre and a number of members of Parliament. In taking its decision, the Government determined that the objectives of the Centre were worthy of support. The following are pertinent extracts from the Centre's objects clause:

SPEECH.PARA: 3(a) to undertake and prosecute scientific research and enquiry into the fundamentals and theory of a free society including but not thereby limiting its application, the philosophical, historical, economic, legal and social aspects of such society with particular relevance to the Commonwealth of Australia.

(e) the Centre shall be non-political, non-sectarian and non-racial and shall not take any step or make any decisions whereby it shall in any manner whatsoever align itself with any political party religious philosophical or other group.

I suppose that there are differing views with regard to certain representations that are made for tax deductibility and assistance. But, in general terms, other economic research bodies attached to universities, for instance, could qualify for deduction by virtue of the eligibility of gifts to universities generally in Australia. It was decided that the representations that were made on behalf of the Centre would be accepted by the Government. For those reasons, we do not accept the Opposition's amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to comment briefly. I understand that the Australian Democrats will not vote for our amendment, so I will not be calling for a division.
—They have not heard the debate yet. I hope that I might be able to convince them.

—Perhaps I can clarify that later. On the understanding that the Australian Democrats will not support the amendment, we will not call for a division. I think it is fair to place on the record that if, at some stage in the future, a Labor government decides to add the Fabian Society to this list, the precedent has been established that would legitimise such a course of action .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think what we are doing tonight is in fact establishing a precedent which the Government will regret. I have taken the opportunity of obtaining information about the Centre for Independent Studies from the Parliamentary Library. I would like to regale the Senate with some of its publications. The first publication that is referred to in the Centre for Independent Studies journal for June 1982, is a book entitled Wage-Price Control : Myth & Reality. It was edited by Mr Shenoy. The list of contributors includes a number of very interesting and important people. It also includes people with very fixed ideas-people who could not be regarded as giving a balance to this particular reading. Under the heading 'Policy Monographs' at another page of that journal, it is stated:

SPEECH.PARA: 4. Free to Shop by Geoffrey Hogbin introduces economic analysis into the ongoing debate about shopping hours. The cost to consumers and to retailers of having to use and provide services in limited time periods-especially given changing work patterns-are seen as not efficient, nor do they provide for the legitimate requirements of the consumer.

Even the description, short though it is, of that monograph does not put into the scales of that question the rights and responsibilities of employees in the retail industry. Yet here we are, as a parliament, opening up a Pandora's box to provide taxpayers' money to an organisation such as this which, as appears from the material that I have before me-at least the matters I have referred to-has a very narrow and limited view of the economy and the methods of running the economy. I would not mind if this organisation were able to open its mind to a broader view of economic problems and the solutions thereto. We are doing this on the run but, for example, I would not have been opposed to a genuine independent body receiving some encouragement from the taxpayer if the studies were genuinely undertaken. That is no reflection on some of the people who are named as either sponsors or advisers to this body. I notice that a number of those advisers are well respected and very fine Australian citizens. But I would suggest that the policy monograph in the case of the publication Free to Shop ignores completely the problems associated with those who are employed in the retail industry and really argues only from the basis of costs in respect of the efficient use of material and plant.

If the Senate would give me a couple of minutes, I would be inclined to read some of this material into Hansard. A point about Mr Friedman caught my eye. Referring to another publication, the CIS document states:

Taxation, Inflation and the Role of Government by Milton Friedman, with comments by Michael Porter, Fred Gruen and Don Stammer, is the paper and commentary from the Centre's second Occasional Seminar. Friedman discusses the role of government in some of the important policy issues of today and also examines the impact of the changing pattern of ideas.

That is very good, but why should the taxpayers' money be provided for a one- eyed and single-minded approach to the economy? I hope that the Australian Democrats will give consideration to this matter. I hope that the Australian Labor Party will also divide on this issue. I have not been convinced, by anything that the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) has said in either her second reading speech or in the Committee stage of the Bill, to support this proposal. Nothing whatsoever has been advanced which would indicate that this organisation intends genuinely and independently to pursue a thorough-going examination of all aspects of the economy and to give due regard and weight in particular to the employees who are most affected by some of the economic ideas and theories that are advanced in its monographs.

The other reason that I would oppose the extension of the tax rebate to this organisation has nothing to do with the organisation but it has a lot to do with the fact that a number of requests have been made to the Government from organisations which have far greater claims to assistance from taxpayers than does this organisation.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is debating an Opposition amendment to withdraw from clause 5 of the Bill the provision for the Centre for Independent Studies to be a tax deductible organisation. Prior to the suspension of the sitting for dinner, as would have been obvious to everyone, I was rather stalling for time. In the interim, I have attempted to obtain as much information as I could from the resources in this Parliament about the origins of the Centre for Independent Studies, about the quality of its work and about the availability of its work. A number of very reputable economists and persons of scientific excellence are on the advisory council of the Centre for Independent Studies. I note also that the list of trustees of the organisation, as at 1980, in a publication 'Centre for Independent Studies', mentions as trustees-some honourable senators may know these gentlemen-in Western Australia, Mr Agnew; in South Australia, Mr Bonython; in the United States of America and the United Kingdom, Mr Fisher; in Victoria, Mr Hugh Morgan; and in New South Wales, Mr Maurice Newman and Sir William Pettingell. They are all well-known figures in Australian business or academia. But that is not the point.

SPEECH.PARA: The point is that, if I were any of those gentlemen, I would be concerned about the inclusion of their organisation in this Bill for the purpose of tax deductibility because, as was said prior to the dinner break, it will open up a Pandora's box. As Senator Walsh said, what is to stop a future Labor government from including, for example, the Fabian Society as an organisation which would attract tax deductibility? Let me refer briefly again to the Centre's publication of 1980. It states:

Economists and other social scientists who work for the Centre are encouraged to follow their analysis to its conclusions even if regarded as 'unpopular', ' politically unacceptable', or 'administratively impractical'.

That is an excellent academic approach. The authors are asked, in the words of the document, to act as analysts of scientific truth. I shall not delay the Senate-I do not have the time-with an examination of what is scientific truth, but it appears, from the context in which that is stated, that the Centre appears to clothe scientific truth with some sort of metaphysical character. I give an example. I come back to the publication Free to Shop. According to the Centre:

The cost to consumers and to retailers of having to use and provide services in limited time periods, especially given changing work patterns, are seen as not efficient, nor do they provide for the legitimate requirements of the consumer.

Is that an analysis of scientific truth? What about the effect that it has, the cost to shop assistants in providing services outside those limited time periods ? What about that equation? In that particular study, did the author canvass the inquiries that had been held in Queensland, New South Wales, South Australia and Victoria, all of which came to the conclusion that there was a need for some intervention at that particular time? Leaving that example aside, I return to the Centre's 1980 publication. Let us see what it says about itself. It states:

Since its establishment, the CIS has avoided government funds and sought support wholly from sales of its publications, revenue from activities such as conferences and from voluntary contributions from individuals and companies. In this way it can retain maximum freedom to examine matters which governments neglect or which might be sought in conflict with the prevailing preconceptions of politicians and government departments. For a free society, where economic activity is nevertheless significantly controlled or influenced by the bureaucracy, independence of this kind is all the more important.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it a bit difficult to understand why the Australian Labor Party is willing to move an amendment to this clause when it was not willing to support us on a much more substantive matter that Senator Siddons moved in relation to local government-the explanation being that it was a Budget measure. I should have thought that the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill was certainly a Budget matter, yet Labor senators are willing to look at something of this nature for the Centre for Independent Studies. I shall support the Government on this matter, but I want to make it clear that in casting my vote that way, it should not be taken, as Senator Harradine has intimated, I believe, that in doing so I would be supporting the Centre for Independent Studies.
—It is not necessary to do that, is it?
—That is what I have just suggested. In saying that it could be included here, in no way would I be casting a vote to support its work or the types of publications that it puts out.
—You are, because you are paying taxes.

—I put to the Centre the very issue that Senator Harradine raised. I saw it as incongruous that a centre that puts out the type of publications that this Centre does would seek to have that made tax deductible. It seems incongruous with most of its publications and its philosophy. However, it seems in some way to have convinced the Government that it is an organisation worthy of support. What I seek from the Minister is precisely why, and upon what criteria, the Government accepts any organisation into this category. The Minister has an obligation to say why, because I believe there are many other groups. For example, the Fabian Society, having seen this happen, may very well be interested in getting in on the act, and why not?
—The Harradine publishing company?

—I do not know. If the honourable senator has one he might like to apply. I am also interested in the clause which states:

SPEECH.PARA: the Boy Scouts Association or the Girl Guides Association.
Is that an exclusive 'or'? If not, I am not sure why it is in there.

TALK.START.PARA: —It could not have 'and/or', surely.

—I wonder whether one can claim for both or only one. For example, if one claimed for the Girl Guides would one then be excluded from claiming for the Boy Scouts? If that is not the case, I am not sure why all the others have the conjunction 'and' and this has the conjunction 'or'. There is a logical difference between those.
—To keep them prepared.

—To keep them prepared, is it? I see. Perhaps the Minister can tell us why the word 'or' is in that clause. Lastly, I welcome the Government's move to include Amnesty International which I believe has been the most deserving organisation amongst all those groups to receive the recognition it has and to receive assistance from the community. I would be interested to listen to the Minister's reply on the criteria to be satisfied to get into this exclusive group of organisations listed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the exclusion of the Centre for Independent Studies and take up where Senator Harradine stopped because of lack of time. He was reading from the 1980 report of the Centre for Independent Studies and showing that in its publication the organisation sought to indicate its independence. The reality is, of course, that the organisation refers to the fact that it seeks voluntary contributions from individuals and companies. It then indicates that it is not going to be dominated by politicians and government departments. Senator Harradine did not have the opportunity of going further into the document produced by this organisation where it makes a strong point. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Centre's independence thus rests on:
Its freedom from government subsidy.
Its widespread sources of private financial assistance.
Sales of its publications . . .

Its freedom from government subsidy is the point that I think should be made. This organisation, which is one of the most extreme political organisations in terms of the material it has produced, is now coming to this dreaded Government that it has so often criticised to seek subsidisation in this way. For this reason I support the proposal that it should not be given this subsidy because the logical extension of this is that every political attitude in this country should receive tax exemption. The Fabian Society has been mentioned. The whole thing is ludicrous. Because this organisation has an extremist political philosophy it is supported by the Fraser Government. In this circumstance we find that this Government is trying to whip into this clause with the Boy Scouts and the Girl Guides an organisation which is the architect of the most extreme conservative philosophy in this country. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macklin asked a couple of questions. In the reference he made to the Boy Scouts Association and the Girl Guides Association I inform him that they are not exclusive. In the clause sometimes 'and' is used and sometimes 'or' is used. Anyone may seek deductibility for donations to the Boy Scouts and the Girl Guides, or the Girl Guides, as the case may be. As far as the particular-
—What would you recommend?

— I think it would be very worthy to give donations to both. Deductibility could be claimed and it would show an interest in both the young girls and the young boys. The ones I have noted particularly state that it is a centre to:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . undertake and prosecute scientific research and enquiry into the fundamentals and theory of a free society including not thereby limiting its application, the philosophical, historical, economic, legal and social aspects of such society with particular relevance to the Commonwealth of Australia the Centre shall be non-political, non sectarian, non-racial and shall not take any step or make any decisions whereby it shall in any manner whatsoever align itself with any political party, religious, philosophical or other group.
