SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to intervene for the moment on this important clause because I do not think the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) has really touched on the chief objection of Senator Walsh and, in particular, Senator Harradine. I do not think anyone here believes that the Centre for Independent Studies represents other than an extreme, conservative political viewpoint in this community. I do not hear anyone getting up to argue to the contrary. Senator Siddons said that he supported this clause because he agreed with Voltaire. Although he may disagree with the organisation' s views he will defend to the death its right to express them. I share that view . But what is in fact happening here, as Senator Childs said, is that we are providing a subsidy for this organisation from the taxpayers by way of revenue forgone, which is just as much a subsidy as if we paid out a subsidy directly to it from Consolidated Revenue.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle read to us the aims of this organisation which seem to justify, in her view and in the Government's view, the provision of tax deductibility to this organisation. The chief point in those aims seems to me to be that the organisation claims first of all to be independent from any individual political party, and secondly that it has a philosophy which is concerned with the scientific investigation of our society within the bounds of maintaining what it calls a free society. Indeed that is exactly the sort of thing one hears repeatedly from Mr Jeremy Lee and company from the Australian League of Rights. It claims that it is conducting a scientific analysis of our society within the concept of a free society, as that organisation sees it. I suggest that it is the sort of thing one hears from Marxist organisations, which are continually saying that they are conducting scientific analysis of what goes on in society. If the term 'independence' in the organisation's terms of reference or aims is the important thing I suggest that every Sunday night on my local television I hear what is an independent news commentary by one B. A. Santamaria. Therefore I ask whether in fact we are going to provide tax deductibility for the National Civic Council? Again, are we going to do it for the Fabian Society or any other such organisations?

I believe the most serious thing is that if organisations such as these carefully word the terms of their aims and constitutions to state that they are indulging in scientific inquiry and that they are non-party political, they will get away with it. As Senator Harradine said we have set a precedent whereby any future government in fact can provide tax deductibility to organisations such as the Fabian Society and the National Civic Council. Also Senator Sibraa mentioned the organisation that keeps an eye on the trans-nationals and everybody else. I think this is a serious thing. In fact, it is a precedent. How in fact is any government in the future, whether it is Labor, Liberal or anything else, to refuse any organisation which comes along with a nice set of aims and constitution and which claims it has no affiliation-

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the AMWSU?

—Senator McIntosh asked what would happen if the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shiprights Union set up a study such as this. The important thing is that once the precedent is set it will make it difficult for any future government to refuse this sort of subsidy. Let us not get away from the fact that it is a subsidy. For any organisation such as this it is a subsidy for revenue forgone. Those of us who may have some association with the Fabian Society or the National Civic Council will be very hard put to refuse such a subsidy in the future. These organisations are not like the Girl Guides or Boy Scouts associations and certainly not like Amnesty International. I urge the Government to consider seriously what it is letting itself in for.

—I am totally dissatisfied with the reply of the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. I did not ask for the memorandum of association of the Centre for Independent Studies because I have it here. I have the monographs of that organisation and also its small up to date brief. I know what the organisation is doing. I have done my homework. What I was asking for was the Government criteria for organisations getting on this very valuable list. Anybody can draw up a list of memoranda of what they are about and make it look good for whatever reason they want. But I wonder whether the Minister can tell us what criteria the Government uses for organisations wishing to get on the list. Surely that is knowledge that any group within the community is entitled to if in fact we are to broaden the criteria. Certainly I would agree with Senator Harradine and Senator Grimes that the criteria are broadened to include groups dealing with quasi-political matters. Nobody has yet denied that the Centre is indeed looking at that particular issue. I am quite happy for it to have a different viewpoint as I am for the Fabian Society to have a different viewpoint. I believe that all bodies in the community are entitled to know upon what criteria the Government makes its judgments so that they can see whether they can make an application which might have a chance of success.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make it perfectly clear that I wish to dissociate myself from any remarks made by any honourable senator concerning the work of the Centre for Independent Studies. Some of the publications of the CIS are very highly reputable works and have assisted not only members of the parliament but also bureaucrats and economists in an understanding of various subjects. For example, whether honourable senators like it or not, the examination of the airline policy is a case in point. Very good work has been done by the Centre; there is no doubt about that. The work is of a generally high quality except, of course, the work I mentioned before which related to the publication Free to Shop. I have not had the opportunity of reading that work. I have had the opportunity only of looking at the summary of the work in the document before us. I made my observations having regard to that summary. I have attempted to get the work from the National Library of Australia and the Parliamentary Library but neither has it.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not keep the Senate long but I make it very clear that I support the work of the CIS as an organisation which has advisers who are reputable academics and which seeks from academics and economists research papers on various issues. As such that can only advance our knowledge of those subjects. The Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) is playing with words in saying that that organisation eschews philosophical groups. I will quote from a paper which was printed in the Institute of Public Affairs Review Journal of April-June 1979. The article was entitled 'Rekindling the Flame: the Revival of Liberalism' and written by Greg Lindsay. Greg Lindsay was the first full time director of the Centre for Independent Studies. In a preparatory comment to his statement on the foundation of CIS he said:
Some of the positive signs of a growing awareness of Liberal values can be traced to a number of sources. Perhaps the first great boost came with the visit here in 1975 by Milton Friedman.

The influence of monetarist economics has been growing for a number of years and Friedman's visit focussed attention on the monetarist sources of inflation in a way that had not been possible previously. Inflation after Friedman became a matter of open public concern and ever since governments have seen the dangers that lie within it and have attempted its control, though with varying degrees of success.

Time and again the philosophical approach of the current Government in respect of the economic ills of this country has meant an over-concentration on controlling inflation. Of course, to that extent we have a blow-out of the unemployment rate. I should certainly like to see the Centre for Independent Studies focus its total attention for a period on how to overcome the unemployment problem in this country. The article in the IPA Review, written by the first full time director of the CIS, continued:
The following year saw the founding of the Centre for Independent Studies.
The article continued with the names of those in the organisation and then stated:
Late in 1976 Australia was visited by Professor Hayek.
This visit helped to complete the germination of thinking begun when Friedman had been here the year before.

Compare that with what the 1980 progress report of the Centre for Independent Studies says. I ask honourable senators: Has the Centre a philosophical basis which transcends the sort of economic basis which is claimed? The Centre's report says:

The CIS, established as a private institute outside the traditional mainstream of research and inquiry, intends to redirect attention to free enterprise, the market economy, and private property as solutions to many of our present day problems, not-as much as current literature would have us believe-the sources.
The report continues:

The CIS thus intends to focus attention on the role of microeconomics-the study of individuals as buyers and sellers, lenders and borrowers, employers and employees, etc.-and the role of personal liberty in an economy free of people.
This has been largely obscured over several generations by the influence of the Keynesians and the doctrines of the Fabian socialists.

I suppose one could agree with that, but one does not have then to hold on to the coat tails of Milton Friedman and Professor Hayek to get the solutions. All I am saying to the Government is that it is a worthwhile development for Australia to have seen the establishment of the Centre for Independent Studies. There is no doubt that this is a very worthwhile development because the Centre has an attitude which transcends pure economics.

In summing up, let me give two simple reasons why I believe that the Senate should not go along with the Government and provide the Centre with taxpayers' money in effect for its operation and also why this arrangement is not in the interests of the body itself. The first reason is that such provision would open a Pandora's box. As has been asked in debate, once we open that door, how do we stop other organisations coming in for their chip of the taxpayers' dollar? Let me make it very clear that we are giving taxpayers' money to organisations listed in section 78 of the Act. Does the Centre for Independent Studies really want taxpayers' money, having regard to what it said in its publications, namely , that the basis for its freedom of thought and ability fearlessly to present before the people of Australia the economic solutions as it sees them depends on its freedom from government support. I suggest that there would be very few, if any, of the distinguished advisers to the Centre who, on reflection, would agree to the acceptance of taxpayers' money under those circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call Senator Robert Ray.
—For God's sake!
—I am sorry to upset Senator Chipp.
—Where were you for the debates on air navigation charges, the diesel fuel proposals, the students loans legislation? Those are the big issues.

—I just wish to answer Senator Macklin's question; maybe the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) will not. Senator Macklin asked: What criterion does the Government use? I think the answer is patronage. It is a very ad hoc method of choosing who gets tax deductibility and who does not. On this occasion, it is simply Mr Cliff Walsh who happened to be closely associated both with the Centre for Independent Studies and with the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). He got in the Prime Minister's ear and this was slipped in between the boy scouts and someone else, hoping that no one would notice. I hope that answers Senator Macklin's question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish only to make a few brief remarks. Again, I wish to answer the question that was put by Senator Macklin. The honourable senator asked: What criteria are used for the Centre for Independent Studies to get tax deductibility? I would say that the criterion is to be a friend of this Government. We in the Australian Labor Party know how difficult it is to get this sort of tax deductibility. I say that because I remember that, when the Menzies Foundation was started, it was immediately announced that there would be a government grant and tax deductibility would be allowed. When the Labor Party set up the Evatt Foundation, we had to put a great deal of pressure on this Government to try to get tax deductibility for donations to that organisation. I might point out that we did not get a grant, as did the Menzies Foundation. SPEECH.PARA: I do not believe that the Centre for Independent Studies is a prestigious organisation as is, for example, the Brookings Institute in the United States of America. Even though it is trying to assume that sort of prestige, I believe it is a front organisation. The Government has created a precedent in this legislation. It is a precedent at which I am sure a future Labor government will look. I would hope that a future Labor government would fund foundations which engage in research into the history of political parties as happens in West Germany where the Friedrich Ebert Foundation which assists the Social Democrats is funded privately and by government. I would hope that the major political parties and perhaps even the Australian Democrats would qualify for some sort of political funding from a Labor government. But we would certainly be looking at a number of organisations. We would be looking, for example, at organisations such as the Fabian Society and the Foundation for Labour Studies. I can assure the Government that if it has opened the door for the Centre for Independent Studies we will make sure that we keep it open in the future for some of our own .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few remarks on the Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1982 (No. 2). I think it is worth while commenting on some of the aspects of the legislation which relate to social security. As we know, the legislation in fact lowers the rate of tax and increases various rebates for spouses and sole parents, introduces a new pensioner rebate and standardises the tax treatment of the new rehabilitation allowance. These are all matters of vital interest in the social security area. The legislation also introduces some rather generous provisions quite unrelated to social security. For instance, it allows a rebate on tax of up to $1,000 on certain dividends. It provides a new and virtually open-ended rebate for home buyers and liberalises the dividend distribution requirements of private companies.

SPEECH.PARA: I just wish briefly to contrast the generosity of these latter measures with the tax treatment of the disadvantaged of our community. As Senator Walsh has said, we support the reduction in the standard rate of tax and the increases in the other dependent rebates because the income tax burden has become an increasingly oppressive one during the term of this Government. This has arisen in large part, I might suggest, from its toleration of large scale tax avoidance . This relief is long overdue. We also support the principle that increases in the spouse rebate, for instance, should be limited to those with dependent children. About half of that rebate at present benefits couples who have no children and there seems to be little case for extending the benefit in this area.

Also we support the new pensioner rebate, but it is important to recognise that the need for the rebate results from the Government's failure to index the income tax threshold for inflation during a period when pensions have been indexed. Under the income tax rate structure that was introduced in 1975, a single pensioner would have paid no tax so long as his private income did not exceed $540 per annum. Expressed in 1982-83 dollars, that is about $21 a week. The level of the effective tax threshold became even higher under the 1976-77 tax structure but because the threshold, along with other components of the rate structure, has been only partially indexed, if at all, over the years it has fallen steeply in real terms.

The situation reached the point at which a single pensioner, even with no other income, could have become liable in 1982-83 to the payment of some tax. Labor's spokesmen on Treasury matters, Ralph Willis, and I, with others, warned of this danger and finally the Government acted. But pensioners should not be deceived. The combination of the general threshold rise and the new pensioner rebate will not even restore them to the real position they enjoyed in 1975-76. The effective tax threshold for a single pensioner will still be only $19 a week in 1982-83. The special pensioner rebate will be taken away on incomes above that level, so a considerable net disadvantage will remain.

I believe another factor that should be noted is that the taper on the rebate, 12 1/2 cents in the dollar, will further accentuate disincentives to earn much more than the pension-free income level. I know that the full year effect of the new provisions will not take place until 1983-84 and the figures that I have quoted for 1982-83 include only the seven months effect from November 1982, but pensions will also rise in 1983-84 and it it hard to perceive that, in real terms, pensioners will be any better off. The Government likes to talk about giving full benefits while actually giving only a small part of them. That con trick is frequently employed by it. The figures presented in the Budget incorporated that deception. Even though the net gains to pensioners are problematic, they are at least something more than nothing, which is what sickness and unemployment beneficiaries will get from this Bill. Their group is presently in greatest jeopardy as a result of this Government's callous attitude towards the victims of its own economic policies.

Additional benefits in respect of children and supplementary rent allowances are, unlike the similar payments to pensioners, taxable in the hands of recipients. Thus, the more children one has, the less extra income one may receive on top of one's social security benefits before tax becomes payable. In the case of a married couple with two children, the benefit payment alone suffices to take income above the tax threshold. That is a matter that the Government and the Treasury should review. Even if such people receive throughout the year no income other than their benefit, their income in 1982-83 will be about $105 above the tax threshold and therefore they will be liable to the payment of $32 in income tax. If they have three children their tax bill will be about $192 and, in larger families, an extra $160 will be owing for each additional child. In the case of a sickness beneficiary who receives a rental allowance, an additional $150 will be owed. These are no mean sums for people who have been subsisting over the course of the year at a sub-poverty income level. Few actually would have the wherewithal to find the amounts owing. I suggest that their liability for tax represents a gross aberration which can and should be rectified.

A couple of other anomalies should be noted. A single sickness beneficiary who receives a rental allowance for the whole of 1982-83 will find that taxation of about $20 will be payable. The situation will worsen in 1983-84. Of course, payments for the single unemployed are so much lower because of an inability to obtain this allowance, that under the circumstances the particular problem to which I have referred does not arise. Another anomaly arises from the different treatment accorded to de facto marital relationships by the social security and taxation systems, a matter that was raised by Senator Martin earlier. The Department of Social Security will pay a higher benefit when there is a de facto spouse who has no income of her own. However, the taxation system will not allow any rebate in such cases. The only solution for claimants is to file separately at the single rate, but that is often less than half the married rate. The situation represents an absurd imposition at a time of record high unemployment.

I believe that all honourable senators have had brought to their attention distressing cases in which a de facto couple which have received unemployment benefit throughout the year have been sent at the end of it tax bills of up to $ 400, which they cannot pay. We really should look at what can be done to remedy these injustices. I suggest that three measures are needed to remedy the immediate problems. Firstly, the additional benefit for the children of this group should be made non-taxable. That would be consistent with the proposed tax treatment of the family income supplement and the existing treatment of payments for pensioners' children. It would remove the tax liability of married beneficiaries with children.

Secondly, the rental allowance also, consistent with the treatment of supplementary assistance for pensioners, should be made non-taxable. If that raises problems of equity vis-a-vis the position of those on low wages, surely the solution is to extend some form of rental assistance to them also, not punish beneficiaries as happens now. Finally, benefits for both married and de facto couples should be equally split between partners in the same manner as for pensioners. If that were done the benefit for each partner would be below the tax threshold and no problems would arise. Alternatively the tax system should be changed so as to recognise de facto marital relationships.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why not talk about the sex life of the Argentinian bull frog? That would be just as relevant.

—I am talking about some of the poorest people in the community- those on sickness and employment benefits whose extra allowances are taxed. I know that is far beyond the understanding of someone such as Senator Chipp, but it happens to be important.

—I rise to a point of order. Mr Temporary Chairman, with great respect to you, how you can allow an honourable senator to speak, as Senator Grimes has done, for 10 minutes on a subject that is virtually irrelevant to the Bill passes my comprehension. The subject matter of what he is saying is very important and relevant to both the economy and those who receive social service benefits but, with great respect, I suggest that if as a Temporary Chairman you allow this to happen any honourable senator will be able to speak on any subject when the motion before the Chair, under your interpretation of the Standing Orders, is that the Committee's report be adopted or some such motion. I do resent the remark made by Senator Grimes and would not have taken a point of order unless invited to do so by his making such a provocative remark.

—In regard to the point of order, I point out that I made no remark concerning Senator Chipp until he interjected. The Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1982 contains a number of provisions relating to social security pensioners and beneficiaries. We are dealing with the Bill as a whole and, as is any other honourable senator, I am entitled to speak to its clauses. I have no objection to any honourable senator speaking at the Committee stage of any Bill. I must say that I am surprised that Senator Chipp has. I suggest that his point of order is out of order.

—I do not think there is a point of order. Senator Grimes's remarks are rather wide-ranging, I will concede, but they are relevant to the Bill. I draw his attention to the fact that they are rather wide-ranging.
—I take your advice, Mr Temporary Chairman. I am surprised that you consider that the tax treatment of social security beneficiaries,which is the subject--
—I draw your attention to the fact that we are in Committee.

—The subject of this legislation is all that I have been speaking about. I am sorry that Senator Chipp was not listening. I make the final suggestion to the Government that in fact the rental allowance for these people should also be non-taxable, consistent with the treatment of the rental allowance for pensioners. If this raises problems of equity, then we should do something about the low income earners instead of punishing the present beneficiaries. All I have done, much to Senator Chipp's annoyance, is to plead for equity in the treatment of unemployment beneficiaries and sickness beneficiaries in this community who, along with single parent pensioners and some low income earners, are the poorest people in the community and are becoming more and more poor as the present Government's economic policies continue and as our economic situation gets worse. At a later time I will advocate this on second readings and in the Committee stage of Bills, despite the harassment of those who apparently think they have more important subjects.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1982 is important legislation. In essence it consists of two broad parts. The first part of the Bill is composed of legislation introduced to carry out measures that the Government announced in this area in the Budget-namely, the legislation extends the eligibility for health benefits to sickness beneficiaries; it extends pensioner health benefits to those on the new rehabilitation allowance; it extends the health care card for 12 months to those on invalid pensions and rehabilitation allowance recipients who are starting employment; it ensures that the new mobility allowance and the family income supplement are not counted as income for determining entitlement to the health care card, and it also introduces a new three-tiered pharmaceutical benefits scheme. The second broad part of the legislation represents a direct attack on the Victorian Government in that it seeks to disallow the Victorian Government's outpatients levy. We do not argue against the Budget proposals except on their inadequacy. We consider that the pharmaceutical benefits charges are excessive and unnecessarily complicated, but we believe the opposition to the Victorian out-patient levy is the result of ideological bloody-mindedness of the worst type.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall deal with the pharmaceutical scheme first. Under the present system there is a charge of $3.20 per item for pharmaceuticals. For pensioner health benefits card holders there is no fee. We are to have a new fee of $2 for disadvantaged persons. The unemployed and social security pensioners who do not have the pensioner health benefits card will also receive this benefit. The legislation also provides for an increase of 80c, or 25 per cent, for all others , bringing the charge for other items on the list up to $4 each. As I have said, we now have a three-tiered system. I suggest that this system is administratively complex. It is discriminatory in that people with similar degrees of economic or social disadvantage are treated differently and unfairly. The unemployed are discriminated against as compared with other disadvantaged groups, adding to the discrimination present in all other legislation which deals with them.

The increase of 25 per cent to $4 per item generally means that ordinary citizens, but in particular sick citizens, in this community will have experienced an increase of 170 per cent in the cost of pharmaceuticals since 1975, compared with the consumer price index increase of about 100 per cent in the same time. They will now have to pay 70 per cent of the average cost of prescriptions compared with 40 per cent in 1975. This means that those with chronically, or recurrently ill children-asthmatics, those who have repeated respiratory infections, those who suffer from epilepsy, et cetera-will have to bear more than their fair share of the burden of health costs. Those adults who have chronic or recurrent illnesses are in a similar position. They will have to pay more than their fair share of health costs. The Government-in particular the Minister for Health, Mr Carlton-calls this the user pays principle. The users are the sick, particularly the chronically sick and those who have illnesses with recurrent episodes.

The matter of the Victorian Government levy is very serious. It has nothing to do with the Budget. It was not announced at Budget time and is quite divorced from the Budget. It is being tacked on to this legislation in an attempt to get it through in association with the beneficial parts of the legislation. In July this year the Victorian Government, in an eminently sensible move, described so by all the media in Victoria, decided that a better way of collecting money for out-patient services-rather than by going through the administratively costly and inefficient method of individuals having to go to their health funds and organise payments back to the hospitals-was to introduce a levy computed on a membership basis, using Federal Government figures, to do away with this complicated method of collection, enabling hospitals to provide out-patient services free of charge at the point of service. We are talking about more than 2 million out-patient services costing about $2m to collect. The method proposed is simple, cost-efficient and overcomes many of the problems caused by delays and accounts. It will release bill collecting staff and the costs of collection so that they can be used for the provision of health services, which is what hospitals and health services are about.

What is the justification given by the Government for its action? What sort of arguments have we heard for this extraordinary action by the present Government? The first argument used by the Minister for Health is that the action of the Victorian Government goes against the user pays principle. That is nonsense. The problem is that the Government, and in particular the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser)-this is shown by his repeated speeches-has a pathological hatred for, and a pathological and ideological difference with, the Cain Labor Government in Victoria, and this has become an obsession with the Government. The Minister takes action against the Victorian Government because it allegedly cuts across his concept of user pays but he takes no action at all against the Queensland Government which does exactly the same thing in its free hospital policy. The only difference is the political complexion of the two governments. No greater example of political bias or hypocrisy can exist. Apparently the Government, like so many of my colleagues, believes that medicine should be practiced as much as possible on what is called the gypsy principle-each service should be accompanied by crossing the palm of the giver with silver. I suggest that this a medieval concept which is insulting to both the doctors and the patients involved.

The second argument used by the Minister-it is the worst and only other argument-is that the levy introduced by the Victorian Government is too high and the cost to the insured will be too high. In fact, as has been pointed out by the Minister of Health in Victoria, by my colleague in another place, Dr Blewett , by the Age newspaper and by everyone who has taken an interest in this matter, the levy is calculated on the Commonwealth Government's own figures and on what the Commonwealth says Victoria should raise from insured out-patient services. Surely the Commonwealth, through the Minister, cannot complain if the figures are based on its own calculations. I can understand the funds complaining because they benefit from the inefficiencies of the present system. They benefit from the fact that some people do not go and claim, they benefit because of the inevitable delay in many people claiming and they benefit because there is an inevitable delay in their paying the State hospitals in these circumstances. With inflation and the interest rates they can get on their funds, they are at an advantage. But I suggest that the Commonwealth cannot complain, because it set the levels. The Commonwealth imposed the levels on the States, and the Victorian Government just used those levels. It may be some of those funds, which are quite unscrupulous in their practices, have convinced or forced the Government to take this step, but I cannot help believing, on hearing the arguments of the Minister and the Government, that the step is ideologically and politically motivated. Therefore the Australian Labor Party will oppose these two provisions in the Bill. They are not part of the Budget legislation; they should not be in this legislation. They are quite separate from the rest of the functions of the legislation and have nothing to do with the Budget.

Undoubtedly the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) will express the view that if we amend this legislation it will have to go back to the House of Representatives and so the sickness beneficiaries who are to receive the pensioner health benefit card may have that benefit delayed until after 1 November. I point out to the Minister that the House of Representatives sits tomorrow and there is no reason at all why this legislation cannot go back there tomorrow and then come back here as separate legislation, if we are allowed to divide it, or as an amended piece of legislation. If there is any delay in the provision of these pensioner health benefit cards, the delay in fact will be caused by the Government.

I wish to refer to sections of the legislation which concern sickness benefits. Clauses 4 and 14 of the legislation remove the income test provisions relating to sickness benefits so that sickness beneficiaries will receive pensioner fringe benefits. Insofar as it is one step along the way to removing discrimination against pensioners and beneficiaries we certainly welcome this provision. However, I point out to the Government that it is coming into effect at a time when the administration of sickness benefits in this country is in chaos. I was gratified by the statement of the Minister for Social Security ( Senator Chaney) this afternoon that he is now taking the sickness benefit problem to the Government. I hope this means that the amending legislation necessary as a result of recent actions will be introduced quickly.

I believe it is necessary to explain to the Senate the present situation of the sickness benefit instructions, and remind the Senate that this situation will continue until further new legislation gives back to ill and injured people their rights to sickness benefits, because without these rights they will not be able to receive the benefits of this legislation. Most of the shambles centering round the payment of sickness benefits results from an opinion given apparently to the Director-General of Social Security by the Attorney-General's Department last April or May which eliminated from entitlement to sickness benefits a large number of people who had been eligible since unemployment and sickness benefits were first introduced in this country in 1945. The result of this will be to cut down the amount of money paid to some other sickness beneficiaries and prevent many people who would otherwise be on sickness benefits from receiving the advantages of the provisions of this legislation and obtaining the pensioner health benefit card.

The opinion I referred to, allegedly from the Attorney-General's Department, purports to give a definition of loss of income which is at variance with the interpretation of this legislation since its inception in 1945. As the Minister for Social Security has not chosen to make this opinion available, I am not in a position, nor is anybody else in this place, to make a judgment as to whether that interpretation is valid. The Minister has known since the middle of the year, since July, that this legal opinion changed a policy the Department has administered consistently for 37 years. He claims it is not a change in policy but a response to what the law means. As far as I am concerned, and I am sure as far as any other honourable senator is concerned, if people have been entitled to a Commonwealth benefit for 37 years and the Minister is presiding over a department which no longer gives them that benefit, without any change in the legislation but because of some change in interpretation of the legislation, this can be considered only as a change in policy. I cannot understand how a legal opinion given in this way can suddenly drastically change the administration of a policy as it affects thousands of people.

I give some examples of confusion and the obvious injustice which exists in this situation. Under the new interpretation, self-employed persons whose businesses are going through a bad patch-there are increasing numbers-will not be paid sickness benefits if they sustain injury or illness. I have been given the history of two such people, one with a heart condition and one with injuries to his hands. Neither is fit for work and so they cannot be paid the unemployment benefit. One is getting $67 a week for three people-himself, a wife and a child-and the other is being paid nothing. So two people who would ordinarily have been paid sickness benefits are being kicked out of the way because of this new interpretation. I think one can only advise all self- employed people, farmers and so on, not to get sick because, even if they have no other benefit, they will not be paid sickness benefit. All unemployed persons who have not registered for unemployment benefits should do so immediately because, if they are in a car accident or if they fall ill, they will not be paid sickness benefit unless they are already in receipt of the unemployment benefit. If they are unwilling to take the unemployment benefit until their savings run out, they should forget their scruples because they will be paid sickness benefit only if they already are in receipt of unemployment benefit. They will not be paid if they have been on a pension because invalid pensions, for instance, unlike the unemployment benefit, have now been deemed not to be income.

According to the Department of Social Security, pensioners do not lose their income when they are taken off a widow's pension or if someone decides that they are no longer eligible for an invalid pension. They might lose money, cheques or whatever pays the bills, but the Department of Social Security says now that this is not income. If they have fallen below that mystical 85 per cent disability level but they are still unfit for work because of illness, they are deemed not to have lost income and, therefore, they are not eligible for sickness benefit.

I have had brought to my attention the case of a widow who was on a widow's pension. She lost her pension because her child went into care. Therefore she lost her widow's pension because she no longer qualified. The woman suffers from a severe illness and needs considerable medication. The Department of Social Security decided that the pension she lost was not income and so it refused to pay her the sickness benefit. It gave her a special benefit but because there are no attached fringe benefits-in particular, there are no pharmaceutical concessions-she has in fact been put in a mental hospital. She can function in the outside world only with medication. The Government has stopped her eligibility for sickness benefit which would give her the required medication. She is only 34 years of age and she has been institutionalised.

This situation is a mess. The Government should do something about it urgently. I do not think anyone in this community would complain if the Government reverted, while waiting to adjust the legislation, to the interpretation which it and every other government have used for the past 37 years. We have the ridiculous situation where people can be transferred from the unemployment benefit to the sickness benefit and they will have fringe benefits. But, if they transfer from an invalid pension to a sickness benefit, although they are in the same position as the unemployed beneficiaries-that is, they are people who have lost the invalid pension because they could be in the work force now or later or because they are sickness beneficiaries they are unable to work because of temporary illness or injury-they will not get these benefits.

The current legislation, I suggest, makes the stakes higher for people to go on to the invalid pension. The discrimination now is tougher than it should be. I think the Government should take a much more urgent look at this matter than it has in the past. This area has always been an administratively difficult area for the Department. It is now a nightmare for welfare workers. In some cases, such as in the case of the widow who has been forced into a mental home, it can be a personal tragedy from which people may not recover. There is an obvious solution. The Government should restore the sickness benefit provisions so that they are legislatively watertight, and progressively remove the distinctions between pensioners and beneficiaries.

As I said before, this legislation is not all that the Opposition would want but those provisions in it which improve the lot of the sickness beneficiaries, the invalid pensioners and those on rehabilitation allowances are certainly welcome. The Opposition does not oppose those provisions. The Opposition certainly does oppose those clauses in the legislation which discriminate against the very sensible move of the Victorian Government in relation to outpatients fees. Initially I will move an amendment to the motion for the second reading of this legislation to express the Opposition's concern. Later, in the Committee stage, the Opposition will oppose those clauses which it finds offensive. I move:
At end of motion, add ', but the Senate is of the opinion that-
(a) the provisions disallowing the cost efficient Victorian out-patient levy should be excised from the Bill;
(b) a simpler pharmaceutical benefits scheme should be constructed which does not discriminate between groups in similar income situations; and

(c) any further increase in the general contribution rate for pharmaceutical benefits is unwarranted given the significant increase in the last Budget, and the fact that over the past seven years, the increase in the general contribution rate has run far in advance of inflation'.

I suggest that this is a reasonable amendment to the second reading of this legislation. I believe that the Senate should support the amendment that I have moved. I hope that a majority of the Senate will support the excision of those two clauses which affect the Victorian Government's health provisions. If we pass this amendment, at least the Senate will have expressed its disapproval of the actions of the Government and the inadequacies of the legislation as it exists.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard from Senator Grimes that the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1982 is in two parts-one part pertaining to the amendments as a result of Budget decisions and the other a vicious attack upon the Victorian Government. The amendment moved by Senator Grimes describes the efforts by the Victorian Government to raise extra taxes as a cost-effective method of running the outpatient sections of their hospitals. The Victorian Government is levying a tax of 80c on every health insured person in Victoria. Whether they use outpatients services or whether they use their private doctor instead of outpatients facilities, health fund contributors in Victoria will have to pay a higher contribution rate. Senator Grimes has described this as a cost-effective method undertaken by Mr Roper in Victoria.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe it is a levy that has been placed on all those people who are insured to give the impression that the Victorian Government is running a free outpatients service. The general impression will be that one does not get charged when one attends an outpatients clinic. The insured people will have already paid for that service. Of course, those who cannot afford to insure are already paid for by the Commonwealth Government. The Cain Government has nothing to worry about in that regard. If this practice is allowed to continue, I believe that Mr Roper in Victoria will also put a levy on hospital services. We would then have a situation in which the people who entered public hospitals in Victoria would not be charged. Those people who were insured would not be charged for the service provided. That would put up the contribution rate for the Victorian people to such an extent that it would eventually undermine the whole of the health insurance scheme. I am not averse to suggesting that this was the original intention of the Cain Government. The levy was introduced not as a cost-effective method, not as an economic and simple method of charging for outpatients services, but rather as a means of undermining the whole of the health insurance area. I am quite sure that this was the thinking behind the original legislation passed by the Cain Government.

Senator Grimes skimmed over the Budget decisions very quickly. I am quite sure that those who are listening to the debate in this place tonight will realise why he has done that. As I said before, the Budget expresses the concern that the Government has shown for those in greatest need. It does so in many areas. I should like to run through them a little more thoroughly than Senator Grimes has done. I start with the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. As Senator Grimes said, a three-tier system will begin on 1 January 1983. The Government will subsidise pharmaceutical items obtained under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. The subsidy will be 50 per cent of the general contribution rate for those disadvantaged people who have health cards. The cost to the general public will now be $4 an item-a rise of 80c-but those disadvantaged people who hold a health card will pay just half of that, $2. This move has been applauded by all the pharmacists throughout Australia. They have been agitating for this move for some time and they were delighted with the Government's response in this area in the Budget.

Senator Grimes has indicated that the method of identifying the disadvantaged persons who are eligible to hold the health card and so are eligible for the $2 payment will be complicated. There will be no complications in this area. The Government has already said that the back of the prescription will have to be filled in by the eligible person to indicate that person's eligibility. That procedure will be sufficient for that person to pay only half the price of the prescription.

There are other Budget decisions in this omnibus Bill. There is an income test free benefit. Fringe benefits have been extended, income tax free, to the new rehabilitation allowance for those persons who undertake rehabilitation programs with the Commonwealth rehabilitation service. Total fringe benefits have also been extended, income tax free, to those people who are collecting sickness benefit. I am delighted with the Government's decision in this area. I believe that those people who are sick enough to be in receipt of sickness benefit ought to be able to have this benefit paid by the Commonwealth Government. Also there is the new mobility allowance and the new family income supplement. Neither of those allowances will be included in the eligibility test for the health card. I believe this is a great step forward. It is an indication that the Government is giving these two new allowances completely free.

For those invalid pensioners and others who receive the sheltered employment allowance and who want to have a go at entering the work force, the Government has provided a health card free of income test for 12 months. Some of those people have often said they would like to have a go at employment but if they did they would lose their benefits, so they cling to their benefits. They will now have a chance to see whether they can cope with employment in the work force and still hold the health card for 12 months. If they find they can cope, they will lose their health card; if they find they cannot cope, they will be back where they were and will have lost absolutely nothing.

In clause 23, as Senator Grimes indicated, the Commonwealth Government is prohibiting any State or Territory from applying a levy on registered health insurance funds. As I have already indicated, this is an area in which the Commonwealth Government has full control. That situation must remain. Health insurance funds are the complete responsibility of the Commonwealth Government and the contributors to those funds must be protected from any State Government which wishes to enter that field and apply extra levies.
Clause 19 is important primarily, I suppose, because I drew the attention of the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) to this matter last year when we were debating the health legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is called the Walters amendment.

—I thank the Minister. As he will recall, I drew this matter to his attention last year when we were debating the health legislation. I indicated at that time that the health funds had no redress concerning any directions that the Minister for Health may make to the health funds about their administration. The Parliament in fact had no knowledge of any direction the Minister might make. At that time Senator Baume indicated to me that the Government would look at this area and would correct it at the first moment that was opportune after the recess. I thank the Government for accommodating me in that regard. The matter was brought up in this omnibus Bill straight after the Budget. The situation now is that if the Minister gives a direction to a health fund on its particular method of administration the Minister's direction must be tabled in either House so that, 15 sitting days later, the Parliament may move for disallowance. Another initiative in this Bill is the right of appeal against administrative decisions. Previously there was no right of appeal. Other minor amendments also exist. I think that covers what I want to say in relation to the omnibus Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I would very much oppose the division of this Bill in any way. I believe that the Federal Government has acted correctly in saying that health insurance, as a Commonwealth initiative, is a Commonwealth responsibility. The Commonwealth is responsible for ensuring that the health funds are administered in the right manner and hence the Minister is able to direct them. The Commonwealth has full control over health funds and no State or Territory should be allowed within this area. The Commonwealth Government must protect the contributors of Australia. It must protect the contributors in Victoria against the wilful intrusion of that State Government in an effort to raise money as a direct tax. It would raise money well above the normal amount that outpatients would require and so subsidise its hospitals through those people who do not use outpatient facilities. I certainly will not be supporting the Opposition's amendment to this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Health Legislation Amendment Bill ( No. 2) is another one of the Government's omnibus Bills. It is different from the other omnibus Bills in that this omnibus Bill contains one or two rather unwelcome passengers, namely, clause 23 and clause 43, which are, as has been stated by a previous speaker, totally unrelated to the other proposals contained in the legislation and which were not foreshadowed in any way during the Budget Speech of the Treasurer (Mr Howard). I will deal with those clauses a little later.

SPEECH.PARA: The major part of this Bill affects proposals that were brought down in August by the Treasurer. It seeks to amend the National Health Act, the Health Insurance Act and the Health Insurance Commission Act. The Australian Democrats have no great quarrel with the provisions in all but two of the clauses contained in the omnibus Bill. Certainly we do not intend to oppose the Budget provisions which are included in this piece of legislation. I would, however, like to comment on one or two of the proposals which my party and I believe, and I have said this before in relation to other pieces of health legislation brought forward by this Government, do not effectively help the sorts of people who require the help which is allegedly being given.

Among other things, this Bill aims to implement an expansion of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. The Government proposes to make available drugs and medicinal preparations on the pharmaceutical benefits schedule at 50 per cent of the general contribution rate to a number of people who presently pay the full contribution rate. That, as far as it goes, is to be commended. These new arrangements will come into operation on 1 January 1983. The Minister for Health (Mr Carlton) in his second reading speech described a three-tier system of contribution in place of the present two-tier system. By virtue of clause 27, concessional beneficiaries, that is, health care card holders and those on social security pensions, including supporting parents' benefits or service pensions, who because of income are not entitled to a pensioner health benefit card, will now be entitled to pharmaceutical benefits at the reduced contribution rate of $2 per benefit item. The rest of the community, the Minister said, will pay an increased patient contribution of $4 per benefit item -an increase this year of 80c from the $3.20 which was, as honourable senators will recall, increased in the 1981-82 Budget.

Herein lies the major problem, because the rest of the community includes a great many people whose chronic illnesses, as Senator Grimes has pointed out, require them to expend a large proportion of their income on pharmaceuticals which are necessary for them to maintain a satisfactory quality of life, and in some cases which are necessary for them simply to stay alive. These people are not, as the Minister indicated, on pensions of some other sort and are not eligible for the $2 concession. Often, too, they are people who are part of a family with multiple problems. Earlier this year, in another health debate, I raised the situation of a family which was facing extraordinary problems in paying pharmaceutical costs. The father had cancer, the mother had another very debilitating disease, and they had a number of children who were faced with the usual childhood complaints.

This naturally enough, as I have pointed out, again in previous speeches, puts the pharmacist in an invidious position. He is faced with the dilemma of being approached by customers who come straight from a doctor with a number of prescriptions but with the money to pay for only one or two of them. That is a decision that no one should be asked to make. The costs of some chronic illnesses are astounding. The costs of diabetes, for instance, which is a particularly common and very chronic illness in Australia, are extraordinary. The annual costs of medical care, hospital visits, ancillary aids and medicine for diabetes in Australia has been estimated as being about $160m annually, and diabetes is by no means the only chronic illness which has that sort of cost to the community.

There is also an additional problem arising all too frequently these days which comes from the removal by the Government of drugs from the pharmaceutical benefits list after they have achieved a high degree of acceptance among users. In some cases the drugs are removed because it has been discoverd, too late in the piece, that there is some sort of dependency inducing quality in the particular medication; but that can hardly be considered to be the fault of the consumer. In some cases, too, the drug is simply removed as part of a cost- cutting exercise. On 2 January last year, the Age ran an item entitled: 'Doctors criticise cuts-

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Mr Deputy President. The honourable senator is reading her speech.
—In fact, I am reading from an Age article.
—She is quoting. She said that. Just listen to what she is saying and you will know what is going on.
—Order! There is no point of order.
—I assure you, Senator Bonner, that Hansard just about goes berserk some evenings when it tries to make some sense-
—Order! Senator Haines.
—The Age article on 2 January 1981, to which I was referring, was headed 'Doctors criticise cuts in free list drugs'. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The removal of some drugs from the pharmaceutical benefit list by the Commonwealth Health Department is provoking a stream of protests from doctors and pharmacists. One Melbourne pharmacist said that the removal of drugs was being decided by bureaucrats with little understanding of the effect it had on patients, particularly the poor. He said pensioners previously could obtain the widely used pain relieving drug, digesic, for nothing but now they had to pay $4 .93 for 50 tablets. The Minister for Health, Mr MacKellar, said in August that the trimming of the pharmaceutical list would save the Government $2.17m per year.

That same pharmacist went on to make the point that the system of reviewing drugs by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee seemed to lack perspective. He said valium was a valuable tranquilliser but more than 80 per cent of prescriptions for it were unjustified, and yet the Government was not removing it from the benefits.

The article went on at some considerable length to complain about the problems being caused to patients who had been induced into taking a particular drug by a doctor who was prescribing it on the understanding that it was free, presumably, from dependency inducing characteristics and because it was available on the free list, only to find later that it was taken off when the patient, often an elderly person, had become used to that particular medication.

I also received a letter recently from a gentleman in Western Australia who was concerned about this problem of the costs of pharmaceuticals. He suffers from chronic hypertension. He has had this condition for a considerable time. He said that it was diagnosed seven or eight years ago. In that time he has spent a total of three months in hospital in search of an effective combination of drugs to control his condition. Most drugs proved less than adequate, he said, and also induced adverse side effects, including sexual problems, difficulty in breathing and a tendency to fall asleep during working hours. His letter goes on to state:

My most recent admission to Kalgoorlie Hospital produced an admixture of Minoxidil, Propanolol, Frusemide and the potassium supplement Slow K. When it was first prescribed, Minoxidil was still undergoing clinical study and was available only from hospital pharmacies. At that time the drug was supplied free of charge. Not only did it control my condition to a high degree under all circumstances, but it was also relatively free of side effects.
He adds in brackets at this point-some honourable senators may care to note this -
(The only noticeable result was a tendency to reverse my incipient baldness and to increase the need to shave frequently.)

However, when I had become almost totally dependent on the drug for a normal life, a charge was introduced. The tablets now cost $50 per 100 . . . This one drug cost me $1 a day, or $365 annually. Together with the other medications mentioned, plus treatment for chronic sinusitis and frequent migraine, my drugs are costing me from $600 to $700 each year.
That is not an isolated situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the point? Is it that more drugs should be included ?

—Surely, the point, Senator Baume, is that it ought to be possible for this Government, which presumably contains some thinking members, to come up with some sort of scheme that would help people who are chronically ill but who are not necessarily pensioners. The Minister will recall that I have raised this point with him during Question Time. His answer to that, as I recall , was: 'Well, we cannot help everyone, so we have to get our priorities in order '. So we leave, in effect, a batch of people in the middle, in the twilight zone , who are not pensioners, who are not necessarily well off, but who are faced with massive pharmaceutical costs simply because they suffer from some sort of chronic illness.

SPEECH.PARA: Other amendments in this legislation extend health care card eligibility to persons in the work force after recently having been on invalid pension or sheltered employment allowances. Senator Grimes has gone into considerable detail on those particular areas and I do not want to deal with them in any detail tonight. However, I do want to discuss at some legth the two clauses which are included in this omnibus Bill and which have no business being there since thay have no connection whatsoever with the rest of the legislation or with anything to do with the Budget. Those two clauses are clauses 23 and 43; 23 being the substantive clause and 43 being the consequential one. They were inserted into this piece of legislation in an attempt to frustrate the perfectly constitutional actions taken by the Victorian Government. They are an attempt to invalidate an Act that was brought in by the Victorian Government to assist it in getting over the Commonwealth Government health funding cuts and to make up the costs for what was an inefficient, ineffective and costly method of administering the Victorian hospitals' out-patient departments. I understand that South Australia has a bulk billing system for in-patients and is planning on extending that to out-patients. If the Federal Government gets away with stopping the Victorian Government from taking its steps to introduce an administratively efficient system, I wonder whether it will then step in to stop the South Australian Government from doing what it wants to do to solve the same problem by a different route.

TALK.START.PARA: —Then Queensland.

—Yes, and then presumably Queensland will not be allowed to run its Golden Casket lotteries or whatever on similar grounds. The legislation which was passed recently by the Victorian Government imposes a levy on health insurance organisations in that State. It imposes the levy only on patients who are insured. While I question the size of the levy, it is nevertheless the province of the Victorian Government to decide how much money it needs to administer efficiently its public hospital system and therefore to whom it will spread the charge and how much it will charge those people. The levy is intended to finance, in effect, the out-patient services provided to insured persons in Victoria. Instead of bills being sent out in single accounts, they will be obviated.

SPEECH.PARA: According to the Federal Minister for Health the levy arrangement has a number of undesirable implications which, from the Federal Government's viewpoint, make it unacceptable. In other words, it offends against the present Government's user pays fixation. But not everybody seems to feel that this is a problem. The Age editorial of 18 October 1982 certainly did not share the Minister's concern. Age editorials are not noted for being particularly left wing or radical. The editorial stated:

The Commonwealth has no business to be interfering, at the behest of the private health funds and for dubious reasons of its own, with a perfectly legitimate and justifiable measure introduced by a State Government to reduce costs and raise revenue for its public hospitals.
It went on to say towards the end of the editorial:

In effect, the levy is borne by all Victorians with the exception of pensioners and the disadvantaged exempted under Federal policy . . . and of a small minority who feel they do not need or cannot afford health insurance.

The system also certainly meets with approval from the Australian Hospital Association. I have received-as I presume other senators also have-a number of telexes, one from the General Manager of the Victorian Hospitals Association Ltd and one from the National Vice-President of the Australian Hospital Association. These people too are not noted for their terribly extreme left wing or radical attitudes to health, to health insurance or to the provision of health care generally. The telex from the Victorian Hospitals Association states:
A return to the previous system of individual billing would add to patient confusion, increase administrative costs, reduce hospital income, and jeopardise the present level of hospital services.
There is no evidence to support the assertion by Minister of Health Carlton that the levy will lead to overcrowding in outpatient departments.
The second telex, which is from the Australian Hospital Association, states:

The Association accused the Federal Government of maintaining a double standard , arguing on one hand that the management of health services was a State responsibility and then interfering when it suited their political purpose. The Australian Hospital Association strongly supports the concept of States having full responsibility for health care delivery provided the Commonwealth Government adopt and maintain national standards for health. The revenue generated from the levy is essential to maintain current health services in Victoria.
The telex finished by stating:
The Association had not been consulted about the proposed legislation and it can only conclude that the Commonwealth Government has responded to pressure from the health insurance industry.

That, I suspect, is precisely what has happened, if the representations that have been made to me by the health insurance industry are anything to go by, because the health funds collected with the levy are some sort of back door way of providing universal health cover. The industry also claims that uninsured patients are getting free treatment, especially on weekends, because patients are not required to fill in a declaration stating that they are insured. That, of course, means that those who are insured and who may never use the out- patients department are paying for the uninsured who do. Again I say that is the State of Victoria's problem. That State is making whatever bed it has to lie on. If the Victorians do not like it they have a perfectly valid chance to express that disapproval at the ballot box in the next State election. Leaving that aside, this is not the first occasion on which the subsidisation of insured patients in public hospitals has occurred. On other occasions it has been done by the Commonwealth Government. I refer honourable senators to a very lengthy article which I do not intend to read. It is headed 'State of the Nation' and is by Geoffrey Barker.

TALK.START.PARA: —After reading everything else you may as well read that too.
—Would Senator Bonner like to hear it? Under the heading 'Health Care: the inequities abound', it states in part:

SPEECH.PARA: Last year's Budget Papers also estimated that Commonwealth outlays on private hospital bed subsidies this year would be around $100m. As only those insured at higher levels can generally afford private hospital care the bed subsidies represent another direct transfer of benefit to the more advantaged groups. Some 60 per cent of all admissions to public hospitals are in fact 'private patients' , paying uniform State-regulated fees of only about half average operating costs . Thus, again indirectly, Commonwealth dollars are subsidising the advantaged insured patient in public hospitals-and the greater their economic advantage, the greater the value of the subsidy to them.

That is simply because their insurance rebates are higher. The rather churlish refusal by the Government last night to allow the splitting of these two clauses from the omnibus Bill is a transparent piece of blackmail. In effect the Government is saying that the Senate will accept some unacceptable proposals if it wants to get through the rest of the legislation, which does offer some support and assistance to some sections of the population who are in need. I say that that will simply not work. Those of us on this side of the House will not now be subjected to the sorts of blackmailing tactics that have been put to us by the present Government any more than we were at the end of the last session. The Senate will recall that last session the House of Representatives rose considerably earlier than the Senate did and we were put in the invidious position of being asked to write out a carte blanche to give the Government what it wanted since we knew that there would be no opportunity for any amendments that we made to legislation being looked at by the House of Representatives, which had gone on holiday.

I understand from the buzzing in the corridors at the moment that this may well be the last substantial piece of legislation debated in the current session because the Government is intending to dissolve Parliament tomorrow and to have a full double dissolution on 4 December. If it does dissolve Parliament tomorrow on the grounds that the Senate is objecting to an intrusion by the Federal Government on the States' rights-in this case Victoria-then so be it. I can think of no better reason for the Senate to be accused of being obstructionist or difficult than that it is operating as a House of review, for which it is here, and that it is defending the rights of a particular State government to operate constitutionally.

There is no doubt in my mind at all that the Victorian Government has the right to do what it is doing. There is no doubt in my mind at all that the Federal Government has no right to include clauses 23 and 43 in what is essentially a piece of legislation intended to deal with Budget proposals. The Australian Democrats will be supporting the Australian Labor Party's amendment to the second reading motion. If this Government persists in not allowing us to split off clauses 23 and 43 so that those sections of the omnibus Bill which come into effect on 1 November can in fact do so, then we will have no option other than to vote against clauses 23 and 43 in the Committee stage and trust-I suspect somewhat in vain-that the Government will then move expeditiously to bring the amended legislation before the House of Representatives before it dissolves it tomorrow.
Motion (by Senator Bonner) agreed to:
That pursuant to Standing Order 364, the copious notes being quoted from by Senator Haines be tabled.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) which is a benefit Bill. I have appreciated the contribution of honourable senators. I was particularly interested in Senator Grimes's contribution, dealing as it did almost entirely with social security matters and only briefly with matters contained in this Bill. I found it most instructive but probably not completely relevant. The Bill contains several main provisions set out by speakers who have taken part in the debate. The first matter concerns the decision to confer a new benefit on those people who need pharmaceutical benefits and who are in a disadvantaged capacity. The Bill creates a new class of person for whom pharmaceutical benefits will be available at a discounted price. This is a new benefit. It will help a large number of people. In the Senate last year we promised that we would try to introduce something of this kind to ease the burden, referred to by honourable senators, which falls on those who have chronic illness, who need a number of drugs and who need these at a concessional price. As honourable senators will know, the three-tier system to be introduced will involve a large number of Australians who will pay nothing for their pharmaceuticals, some Australians who will pay $2 a prescription and the vast number of us who will pay $4 a prescription.

SPEECH.PARA: The second main group of features of the Bill concerns changes to pensioner health benefit card entitlements. These will be extended to new classes of people who at present do not have them. Again this is a benefit conferring measure. The PHB entitlement will now be given to all sickness beneficiaries, irrespective of how they would qualify under an income test This will help people who were previously not able to get the pensioner health benefit card. It will also be available to a new group of people receiving rehabilitation help through the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service and who become entitled to the new rehabilitation allowance. Again this is a benefit conferring measure to a group of people who are in need, who are undergoing rehabilitation and who will value the acquisition of the pensioner health benefit card.

There will also be an extension of the health care card to invalid pensioners who may in fact, although they may remain incapacitated, want to take a chance and try to work. The health care card extension will last for 12 months while these people undergo the experiment. In fact, this is an incentive measure. It will give people an incentive to try to get out and join the work force again without suffering a penalty in terms of eligibility for the health care card. The card will also be extended to those receiving sheltered employment allowances who also elect to go out into open employment. The third main group of features in the Bill are what I referred to earlier as the Walters amendment. That is the one to which Senator Walters referred and about which a promise was made to her during a debate some months ago. This is simply to ensure there is tabling and the capacity for disallowane in the Parliament of any directions given to organisations under the Act. This will enable Parliament to have continuing oversight of the administrative determinations of a Minister or his officers.

The final group of provisions in the measure relate to the levy which has been raised by the Victorian Government. This seems to be a matter which has aroused considerable passion amongst some honourable senators who have spoken. There is an indication that honourable senators may seek to set that aside. The Government believes that it is proper to resist these measures. We will persist to try to retain in the Bill those provisions which set aside what the Victorian Government has set out to do. I remind honourable senators that it is the Commonwealth that has the constitutional responsibility for health insurance matters. Health insurance rests with us. We are responsible for the registration and control of organisations, the establishment of the contribution rates which may be charged and the interests of contributors to health insurance funds. It is not the State governments but the Commonwealth Government which is responsible. The responsibility rests here. We take measures which we believe will protect the interests of contributors, and we make no apology for doing so. We ask honourable senators to consider whether it is not a proper exercise of our power and something that they would want us to do on behalf of the community .

Over three million people in Victoria have hospital insurance cover. What the Victorian Government has proposed will mean that these three million people will be paying, through health insurance, about 20c a week more for hospital insurance than they need pay. This is because the Victorian Government will be taking, by way of its levy, more money than it needs to cover the costs of the function it seeks to pay for. The levy is not based on an accurate assessment of the current utilisation of out-patient services in Victoria. It is a badly costed levy. The measure takes more from the Victorian people than is needed to cover the costs of what it is out to do. The cost is higher than it need be. It appears to be designed as a revenue raising measure quite separate from a recoupment measure for the use of out-patient services. If it was properly costed that might make a difference.

The States should not be allowed to apply levies of this kind which impinge and impose on the contributors to health insurance for revenue raising purposes. I put it to honourable senators that there is an issue of equity here. The levy would raise about $44m. The Commonwealth estimates that with complete collection about $31m should be sufficient to recoup the costs of out-patient services. I might say that the actual amounts being claimed under the current charging experience are much less than this. The Victorian hospitals in fact were raising only about $20m from their out-patient services. Not only will they be seeking to raise more than they were but also will they be seeking to raise more than they need and more than they can justify in terms of the services that they render to Victorians on proper costs. I put it to honourable senators that what we are proposing in those terms is reasonable. The levy will push up unduly the contribution rates for health insurance in Victoria.

What interest does the Commonwealth have in this matter? We subsidise health insurance rates not least because of the health rebate which they attract. This will be a revenue raising measure for Victoria not justified on economic grounds which will impinge upon the Commonwealth revenue by way of a tax rebate and additional revenue foregone. The Commonwealth has a responsibility to the people of Australia to ensure that health insurance is available to everyone and that it is available at the lowest possible cost. The measure being proposed by the Victorian Government is one that will raise health insurance costs and will do so unnecessarily. The Parliament has given the Minister for Health (Mr Carlton) the authority to control the benefit levels relating to hospital in-patient and out-patient charges. If the concept of a levy on health funds extends to cover in-patient services as well, the Commonwealth's control over health insurance would be eroded and our capacity to look after the interests of contributors would be virtually destroyed. If this levy and similar levies were allowed, the role of the Commonwealth in carrying out and exercising its constitutional responsibility to health insurance contributors and for health insurance would be impaired. We think the Commonwealth role could be then downgraded to little more than approving the contribution rates to meet the various levies raised by State governments on the health insurance funds.

The argument that a State has a capacity to raise taxes is incontestable. The argument that the Victorian Government, if it had chosen to do so, could have put a tax on the people of Victoria to raise that money is incontestable. But we believe that the route it has chosen to travel is the wrong route. We believe that its costings are wrong. We believe that it is seeking to raise too much money and that the contributors to health insurance will suffer. The Government will, therefore, press to retain those clauses in the Bill which have been the subject of some discussion and debate tonight.
