In addition, because this is a benefit conferring Bill, because there is a commencement date of 1 November for many of the benefits and because this is almost the last sitting day on which we can consider this legislation, we will oppose the amendment which has been moved by the Opposition and, during the Committee stage, we will seek to have the Bill retained intact.

I understand that in a few moments Senator Grimes will move for procedural purposes a motion to suspend Standing Orders. I will speak to that motion at an appropriate time. I might indicate now, however, that the Government believes the Bill should be considered as a unity. We believe that it can be dealt with clause by clause in Committee. That is within the competence of the Committee. There is no need to split the Bill so that the Opposition can make the points that it wants to make. There is no need to split the Bill for the purpose of passing or rejecting various parts. I will address that matter in a few moments when Senator Grimes moves his motion. However, in the meantime, having indicated the Government's position, I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The situation is that in effect the Minister has closed the debate on the second reading of this Bill. However, I understand that Senator Grimes wishes to seek leave to amend his amendment.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Grimes

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to make what I consider to be a minor amendment to the amendment that has been distributed by me. As Senator Baume was speaking, I was unable to let him have a copy of my further amendment. However, the amendment to the wording is really very minor. I believe that this change will probably make it easier for the government to accept my original amendment. In paragraph (a) of my amendment, I wish to delete the words 'cost effective' and all words after 'should be' and substitute the words 'taken out of the Bill and considered separately'. This means that paragraph (a) would read:

INTERJECT.PARA: The provisions disallowing the Victorian out-patient levy should be taken out of the Bill and considered separately;
The rest of the amendment would remain unchanged. I seek leave to amend the amendment in that way.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted? There being no objection, leave is granted.

INTERJECT.PARA: That the words proposed to be added (Senator Grimes's amendment) be added.

DIVISION.DATA.PARA: (The Acting Deputy President-Senator A. W. R. Lewis)

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I wish to raise a point of procedure. The Senate gave the Joint Committee of Public Accounts the right to sit while the Senate was sitting. The Committee commenced to sit at 8 o'clock this evening in the House of Representatives Committee Room No. 1. I would have expected that it would be understood that, the Committee having been given leave to sit, its members would automatically be paired. It so happened that when the bells rang Senator Lajovic and I found difficulty in leaving the committee room. Having got out of that room, we proceeded under great difficulties to this chamber. I repeat that, the Committee having been given consent to sit, its members should automatically have been paired; that it should have been quite unnecessary for Senator Lajovic and me to run madly through the corridors of the Parliament in order to reach this place. I ask what the position would have been if I had not reached the Senate in time. What would have been the position if the vote had been so close as to involve a difference of one? A very serious decision could have been made by the Senate in a certain way because of the absence of senators engaged in carrying out duties authorised by the Senate. I am still out of breath as a result of being subjected to that imposition and I suggest that the leaders of the House should take the matter in hand.
—What Senator Georges asks is not unreasonable but it might be fair to pursue it along the usual channels to see whether an accommodation can be reached at this stage.

—Yes. I believe there is no need for debate. Senator Georges's point is well taken and I realise that he has made a considerable effort to reach the Senate in time. However, the matter is one which involves a personal explanation rather than a point of order. As every honourable senator knows, pairing is not a matter for formal action by the Senate but rather one for the Whips of the parties. I am sure that both the Leader of the Government in the Senate and the Leader of the Opposition will take the matter up with the Whips and ensure that the situation will never occur again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Grimes moving:

That it be an instruction to the Committee of the Whole that the Committee divide the Bill so as to incorporate in a separate Bill clause 23 and Part IV of the Bill relating to the taxation of registered organisations.

I do not wish to delay the Senate. I am aware of the Standing Order that necessitates that an absolute majority of senators be in favour before the Standing Orders may be suspended. I am also aware that some honourable senators consider that Standing Order to be unconstitutional. Perhaps we should do something about it later. I attempted to follow this procedure last night. Due to circumstances beyond my control, and that of others, yesterday a contingent notice of motion in order to permit this procedure to be followed was not moved at the usual time. If it had been I would not now be seeking to suspend Standing Orders. I do so now merely because of that set or circumstances.

Last night, when I sought and was refused the opportunity to move my contingent notice of motion the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume)-not absolutely unreasonably, I suggest-pointed out that I had not given him very much notice. However, I believe that, quite unreasonably, he gave the further reason that he had been unable to consult the Minister in another place. I pointed out that it was not the business of a Minister in another place to decide what procedures should be followed in this chamber. The reason for the motion to suspend Standing Orders was clearly outlined by both Senator Haines and me during the second reading debate.

This Bill consists, firstly, of provisions which implement the Budget proposals of the Government. In fact, they are not opposed. We may have questions about the extent to which they go, or the way in which they will be applied, but we do not oppose them. However, tacked on to the Bill are two provisions-namely, clause 23 and Part IV-which have nothing to do with the Budget proposals. They were not announced in the Budget and have been tacked on quite separately.

TALK.START.PARA: —The legislation contains other clauses which are not associated with the Budget

—They have been associated, in previous announcements, with the Budget. The honourable senator should not become too excited; she will have her chance to speak. The Opposition believes that it is reasonable to remove them so that, in the course of referring the legislation back to the House of Representatives, we will be able to present to that House two clear and distinct pieces of legislation. Of course, the Opposition is concerned by the Minister's veiled threat that the provision of pensioner health benefits to sickness beneficiaries, which is due to begin on 1 November, may not take place because, if the legislation is referred back tomorrow, obviously the Government will decide not to deal with it. But I still move for the suspension of Standing Orders to make the point that we believe that these are separate pieces of legislation. They have separate functions and clearly they are not connected. We therefore believe that the Bill should be separated so that the Senate can deal with it in a sensible way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders for the separation of these particular clauses from the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). It is consistent with the amendment to the second reading that has just been carried by the Senate. It will have been observed by honourable senators that the original proposition in sub-paragraph ( a) in the addendum to the second reading motion was as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The provisions disallowing the cost efficient Victorian out-patient levy should be excised from the Bill.
That was the original proposition by the Opposition. That was then amended and became certainly acceptable to me. It was amended from the form I have just mentioned to the following form:
The provisions disallowing the Victorian out-patient levy should be taken out of the Bill and considered separately.

In my view, the Senate's having adopted that motion only a few minutes ago, it would be acting quite consistently if it now adopted the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders moved by Senator Grimes. I support that motion because of my long standing objection to the Government's penchant for tacking unrelated matters on to a particular measure, thus tying into that particular measure matters which ought, of their very essence, to be considered separately. I am perfectly well aware that this debate is academic. Even though the suspension motion is likely to attract the majority support of the Senate, that will not be sufficient, because of the provisions of Standing Orders, to carry the day. Of course, the reason for that is that such a motion, in the event that notice thereof has not been given, requires the support of a majority of the Senate, namely 33 votes. As we have observed in the divisions tonight, for some reason or other people seem to have taken off and gone over to South Australia. Of course, that is their business.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why would that be?

—Well might the honourable senator ask. Nevertheless, in my view it is an important principle and I support it. That does not mean that I support the further proposition that is down the track for the two clauses of the Bill dealing with the Victorian out-patients levy to be excised from the Bill. I should like to deal with those matters at the appropriate time. I would have preferred to have dealt with them, if it had been possible, as a separate issue from this Bill. I support the proposition for the suspension of Standing Orders so as to enable these matters to be separated out of the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue before the Senate really is not an issue as to whether the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) is divisible. The issue is not an issue about tacking or about the constitution of this Bill, nor is it a denial of the capacity of the Senate to rearrange its affairs if it so wishes. I accept the sovereignty of the Senate and of some of the declarations it has made in the past. The issue is what should happen here and now with this Bill. I am not questioning the principle. The Senate lays down procedures which are designed to protect the rights of all honourable senators. It was competent upon any honourable senator to have given a contingent notice of motion on any of the preceding days of sitting. Had that been done, the normal procedures of the Senate would have been followed. Honourable senators would have had the notice to which they are entitled under the Standing Orders. They would have had the protection of the Standing Orders and as Senator Harradine pointed out quite correctly, a simple majority of honourable senators would then have determined the issue.

SPEECH.PARA: As it happens, if people wanted to divide the Bill, surely it was not a last minute decision or recognition, surely it was not some eleventh hour decision of tactics. If they had wanted to divide the Bill, why was notice not given as laid down under the Standing Orders?

TALK.START.PARA: —You can do better.

—I am asking why it was not done in advance. Yesterday at the time for the giving of notices of motion, a notice of motion could have been given. The matter today would then be a simple one. As it happened, no notice of motion was given, and no notice of motion was given today.
—Because you would not allow me to do so. You refused leave.

—The honourable senator could have given a notice of motion today and honourable senators could have ensured that the second reading did not come on until tomorrow. Goodness me, it would have been no trouble. If Senator Harradine and I had been doing it together it would have been no trouble, using the Standing Orders properly, to have divided the Bill. It is a simple question. The Government is quite happy to discuss the issue of the Victorian levy. We are not contesting the divisibility. We are saying that it is not in our interests. It is not in the interests of the community, nor of anyone on this occasion, that this Bill should now be divided. We want the Bill dealt with as a unit and considered with its clauses as it is. If the aim of the Australian Labor Party is to oppose this Bill, then let it do so. Let it be seen to do so. There is no way that it can weasel around, to be able to oppose part of it and to be seen not to be opposing part of the package that we brought in. We oppose the suspension of Standing Orders and will vote accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I merely wish to say that I am disappointed in the level of the reply from the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume). As Senator Tate interjected, we have heard a schoolboy type debate from the Minister. Last night the Minister's reason for refusing me leave to give a contingent notice of motion was that he had not had sufficient notice of what it was about and that he could not consult with his colleague in another place. He has now had almost 24 hours notice. He now has two arguments. Firstly, he argues that we did not-I accept that we did not-get the contingent notice of motion in at the right time, for circumstances beyond my control, as I have said . But he then goes on and says that really we could have moved the notice of motion today and deliberately delayed this legislation until after 11 p.m. so that we would have been covered tomorrow. That is the sort of level at which the Minister and the Government operate. They claim that they want this legislation through by 1 November. We want to have the legislation dealt with tonight to give them the opportunity to take the Bill, if it is amended, back to another place, and to give them plenty of time to deal with it. They do not want time to deal with it. They are playing funny games and little tricks.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sorry that the Minister has taken this approach. I am sorry that he has changed his tack so much in the past 24 hours. He is pretty desperate but I accept, as does Senator Harradine, that, with the way the numbers are in this place and because of the Standing Orders, this motion will be defeated and we will then go on to deal with the Committee stages of the Bill. We will deal with that as Senator Baume advises us. But we will deal with it in a more complicated way than I suggest is necessary. We will not divide.
Question so resolved in the negative.
In Committee
Clauses 1 to 22-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 23 (Registered organisations not subject to certain taxes).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 23 of the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) was fairly widely debated at the second reading stage. I do not want to go through the arguments in detail. We oppose clause 23 because this clause, plus Part IV of the legislation, has the effect of preventing the Victorian Government from applying its levy to facilitate the collection of out- patient fees, to make it administratively more simple to deal with problems regarding out-patient fees and in particular to cope with the difficulties faced by Victorian hospitals in the collection of those fees, and to overcome the problem of bad debts. We believe, as do most other people, particularly those listed by Senator Haines, that it is a reasonable and sensible approach to the funding of out-patient departments of hospitals bearing in mind the health insurance system which we have.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) did not quite use the arguments that were used in another place in support of the legislation. For instance, I noted that he did not place the heavy emphasis that the Minister for Health (Mr Carlton) did in another place on this being contrary to the user pays principle, but he did make a great deal of the fact that he thought the levy was too high and that it put too much of a burden on Victorian insured patients. Tonight was the first time that I heard that proposition. The levy rate was set to collect $38.4m, which is the amount that the Commonwealth claimed Victoria should collect from insured patients and by which its grant was accordingly reduced. The Minister of Health in Victoria, Mr Roper, and the Premier, Mr Cain, have stated that if the Commonwealth revised that estimate up or down the levy would be adjusted. They were using the Commonwealth figures-the Commonwealth calculations. Suddenly in this place the Minister claimed there is a great disparity between the amount raised by the levy and the amount the Commonwealth claimed the Victorian State Government should raise by applying the out-patient fees.

I go back to the other argument that I used very briefly at the second reading stage. It seems to me that the Federal Government has an ideological obsession with Mr Cain and his Government. The Government thinks it is horrendous that the Victorian Government should use this eminently sensible method to collect out- patient fees, a method which is administratively less costly and more simple and which will release funds and people to perform the tasks that hospitals are supposed to perform-that is, to treat the sick rather than to collect bills and spend time pushing paper around wondering where those bills should be collected. For those reasons we oppose this clause of the legislation, as we did in another place. We urge all honourable senators to join us in that opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief. What appears to be the situation is that the Commonwealth is using its insurance powers to negative what the State of Victoria considers are its justified taxation powers to ensure that its responsibility in the health area is honoured. It appears to me that we have reached this stage because of a misunderstanding between the Commonwealth and that State. The Commonwealth reduced the grant to Victoria by estimates of amounts which it considered Victoria would be able to collect. Those estimates, for one reason or another, have been found to be short to the tune of something like $18m to $20m. Of course, the Government of Victoria must turn round and try to find that money. All sorts of reasons might well be advanced as to why this has occurred. First of all, why were the Commonwealth estimates so far out? That is a question which I now raise at the Committee stage.
—Could I answer it and you can take it up after that, because it might help.
—Yes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful to Senator Harradine because he has raised a fair question which I think I need to answer to help clarify the debate. I will try to be as brief as I can. On 16 May the Victorian Minister of Health issued a background paper. In that paper he stated that the Commonwealth had made an estimate-
—Don't talk it out.

—I am not trying to talk it out. He stated that the Commonwealth had made an estimate that at a charge of $15 a service Victoria should be able to raise $36m-that was his figure-of which 90 per cent was in respect of insured persons. Those were the figures he was using based on Commonwealth information. From 1 July 1982 the charge was $20 per service. As the arithmetic worked out, all other things being equal, an amount of $43.2m would have been raised from insured persons. This appears to have been the figure on which the Victorians based their levy calculations. This calculation was made despite the fact that a review of the revenue raising capacity was then being undertaken. Victoria had requested the review in February 1982 and it was being undertaken. The review was discussed and completed at the Premiers Conference held in June 1982. The results of that review provide the figures from which we should be working, not the earlier figures.

SPEECH.PARA: In the review the Commonwealth revised its estimate of out-patient revenue. Full details of that revised estimate were sent to Mr Roper on 6 August 1982. He had the figures; they were sent to him on 6 August. The amount of revenue estimated to be collected was reduced because of a decline in utilisation and because of the correction of erroneous out-patient data provided previously by the State. I have some more information as to why it was erroneous, but the figures were revised downwards. Also, in the Commonwealth view, insured patients would probably meet about only 77 per cent of the revenue figure, not the 90 per cent which had been our previous estimate. The State had not really considered the number of compensable patients, patients who were outside Commonwealth guidelines who were receiving free treatment, et cetera. For these reasons the figures were lower. They had been communicated to Mr Roper in early August and they were a result of a review which Victoria had requested in line with its entitlements under the new health arrangements.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — That raises another question. The question is simply: Why, then, is there a need now for the Victorian Government to come up with all this money? That is the point at issue. Is it not a fact that the Victorian Government suggested that that issue be looked at by the Commonwealth Grants Commission under section 12 of the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Act? I remind the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) that that Act makes provision for the Commonwealth Grants Commission to investigate the capacity of the State to raise revenue in respect of that relevant year from charges for health care provided at its public hospitals. Of course the relevant year therein mentioned is the year commencing 1 July 1982. This is the last year under this Act that these arrangements can be made. If the Victorian Government is prepared to submit the relevant facts concerning the charges for health care provided at its public hospitals for consideration by the Grants Commission, why should that not be agreed to by the Commonwealth so that the Treasurer (Mr Howard) can make supplementary consideration of those issues and then in the light of that make a separate adjustment so far as the State of Victoria is concerned?

SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned about this issue. I am not happy about the Victorian Government' s levy-I say that quite frankly-because it has inherent difficulties within it. For example, people who are insured and who are paying their contributions are being charged for services that they will not be involved in. The people who do not go to outpatient departments will be taxed, as it were, for nothing. Many people in country districts of Victoria will not have the ability to go to out- patient departments. I am concerned about it because of the principle and the likely flow-on to other States. Nevertheless, I am also concerned about the fact that apparently there is a difference of opinion between the Commonwealth and the State which, it seems to me on a reading of the provisions of section 12 of the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Act, could have been resolved by the Grants Commission. I would like the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) to address his mind to that.

Also, whilst I consider that another problem about this whole question of a levy of the character that is being proposed in Victoria is that it appears to shed responsibility for accountability in certain public hospitals, let me say this very clearly: The health funds also should have some surveillance over their particular operations, and certain outgoings, particularly from the Victorian funds, ought to be subject to audit and control. I know there are audit and control provisions but maybe what I have to say about that can wait to a later stage and be dealt with under a different subject heading. I know for a fact that there is some squandering of contributors' funds in respect of certain matters on foot at the moment. It is minor in the overall aspect but it is major in the other field. I will deal with it under a different heading at the appropriate time. Can the Minister address his reply to the point that I raised in particular, which was that if the Victorian Government was prepared, as I am advised it was, to have these matters looked at by the Grants Commission, why did the Commonwealth Government decline?

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish briefly to supplement Senator Harradine 's question, as it was one of the questions I was going to raise. It is my understanding that Mr Roper and the Victorian Government requested the referral of the estimates to the Commonwealth Grants Commission as they wanted independent arbitration because of the dispute between the Victorian and Federal governments over the actual costs. I think it is very important that the question be answered. Supplementary to that, in the second reading reply of the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) which I carefully took down the Minister said in the course of his arguments about this point that if the application of the levy was properly costed it may have been a different matter. Was the Minister saying that the problem is not so much the Victorian Government 's applying of the levy but the fact that in the Commonwealth view it did not cost that levy properly? That makes a great deal of difference to the way various people may see it. We have had so many arguments from Mr Carlton and the Minister in this place against this levy and it seemed to me that an extra dimension was added when the Minister suggested that his main problem was not so much the levy but the fact that it was not properly costed.

—Our objections were objections of equity and proper process as much as they were of the arithmetic, but the arithmetic was significant. Senator Harradine asked about a reference to the Commonwealth Grants Commission. I do not have an officer from the Department of the Treasury with me tonight and I cannot give an answer as to why certain procedures were or were not followed. I appreciate the point made by Senator Harradine-Senator Grimes has referred to it also-about the reference to the Grants Commission. I am unable to say and my officers cannot advise me as to why there was no reference. I can undertake to try to find out because I think Senator Harradine has indicated that that was an alternative way to try to resolve some of the issues which were raised. I can put that to the Treasurer, Mr Howard. On the information I have available to me now I cannot give a precise answer to the question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is extraordinary. Surely this matter is fundamental to any consideration of this subject. It appears to me that if there has been an attempt by the Victorian Government to have these matters resolved in a manner designed within the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Act to overcome this very problem, why has the Commonwealth not-

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Peter Buame-I don't know that they have; I don't know whether there has or not.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are in charge of the Bill.

—With due respect to Senator Harradine, the Grants Commission question is not one that was anticipated. It is not part of the Bill; it is an extraneous but relevant question which has come up. I can seek to obtain the information for the honourable senator; I do not have it here to night.

—This appears to me to be one way around a very difficult problem. A number of honourable senators would be concerned about the fact that the Victorian Government has chosen to bring in funds in a certain way; that is, by virtually a discriminatory tax on health fund contributors, some of whom will be unable to avail themselves of the services to which their moneys are being directed. That seems to me to be somewhat unjust. By the same token, it has been suggested that the Commonwealth underestimated the amount that the State could have raised in respect of revenue from charges for health care provided at public hospitals. That is a very important issue. Surely that is fundamental to a consideration of these particular clauses.
—I can have an answer in the morning.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 11 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Temporary Chairman do now leave the Chair and report to the Senate.
The Temporary Chairman having reported accordingly-

PROCTEXT.PARA: Standing Order 406

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 11 p.m., under sessional order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.
Senator Chipp-I raise a point of order. Do I understand that the Government is going to leave the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1982 in limbo after talking it out?

Senator Peter Baume-I wish to speak to the point of order. The Government did not talk it out. I was hoping to get a vote on this matter. Senator Harradine asked some questions to which he wanted a response. If Senator Chipp looks at the Hansard record, he will find that the Government did not talk it out. He will find that I am to get certain information for Senator Harradine in the morning and this I will do.

Senator Kilgariff-I want the Senate to note that the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1982 will be debated tomorrow. It is not a question of the consideration of the legislation being put off indefinitely. It will be brought on for debate first thing tomorrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bonner Sen N.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier this evening I raised a point of order because I believed that an honourable senator was reading a speech in the chamber. The Deputy President at the time said that the honourable senator was speaking from copious notes. Being a very patient person, I waited until that honourable senator had completed the speech. I then asked that the copious notes be tabled and incorporated in Hansard. Unfortunately, it was not possible for those copious notes to be incorporated in Hansard but they were tabled.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, you will recall, I am sure, that on two occasions-on the first, you were not President-we have had a debate in this chamber-many honourable senators from both sides of the chamber entered those debates-about whether honourable senators should read their speeches. Standing Order 406 states:
No Senator shall read his speech.

The debates that took place were about whether that Standing Order should be changed: On the first occasion I was one of those who spoke very strongly, I believe, in favour of honourable senators being allowed to read their speeches in this chamber. I felt, and I still feel, that some honourable senators who come into this place find it necessary to take time to prepare speeches, to carry out necessary research into a number of matters that are debated in this place and to read their speeches in this chamber. Of course, many honourable senators felt that that should not be done. They said that that was not the way we should act in this chamber. They put the view that we should be able to make speeches without preparing them and that sort of thing. On that first occasion, those of us who supported the right of honourable senators to read speeches were defeated. We accepted that defeat graciously and we carried on.

Mr President, you will recall that, during your time as President, another debate took place in this chamber about the same matter. In other words, we debated whether we should reject Standing Order 406. Again, a number of people made speeches supporting that view and others spoke against it. My friend and colleague Senator Missen spoke strongly against honourable senators having the right to read their speeches in this chamber. He felt-rightly so, I suppose, according to his philosophy and beliefs-that honourable senators should be able to stand in this place and make speeches without having a prepared speech in front of them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, without a prepared speech.

—I respect his view as just stated. I respected it at the time when the debate took place in this chamber although I disagreed with him and spoke strongly against his view. This evening I raised a point of order. I intend to continue to raise points of order on this issue. When I raised that point of order, I respected the Deputy President's ruling that the honourable senator at that time was reading from copious notes. I waited until the honourable senator had finished speaking. Then I asked that the copious notes, as they were called conveniently for that honourable senator, be tabled. I now have a copy of those notes. Without a doubt they are not copious notes in the true sense of that term. It is a prepared speech.
—You dill; half of it was the Minister's speech.

—It was a prepared written speech and typed for that honourable senator to read in this chamber. So far as I am concerned, that offends Standing Order 406. When I talked about it to a couple of that honourable senator's colleagues, the response was: 'Oh, but that senator is a shadow Minister'. Standing Order 406 says nothing about shadow Ministers; nor does it say anything about Ministers, if it comes to that. It refers only to senators. I can find nothing in the Constitution about this either. There are 64 senators in this chamber-60 from the States, two from the Australian Capital Territory and two from the Northern Territory. Standing Order 406 states:

SPEECH.PARA: No Senator shall read his speech.

The honourable senator concerned may be able to justify her actions because that Standing Order does not say: 'No senator shall read her speech'. Maybe that is a chauvinistic attitude that we will have to overcome at some time. Maybe that lets lady senators off the hook in this chamber. Maybe we should be looking at the Standing Orders to see whether we are being chauvinistic in this chamber by saying that no honourable senator shall read 'his' speech. I believe the Standing Orders apply to all honourable senators. That being the case, what gives a shadow Minister-

TALK.START.PARA: —Or a Minister.

—Or a Minister, if it comes to that, the right to read a speech in this chamber? I have sat in this chamber for almost 11 1/2 years and I have seen shadow Ministers get up time and again and read speeches, I do not know whether they prepared the speeches whether they were prepared for them by their research officers or research assistants, or whether they were prepared by some person in the broader community who has a vested interest and wants to say something against the incumbent Government, whether it be a Labor government or the present Government of which I happen to be a proud member. Someone outside who wants to serve it up to the government can prepare a speech for someone on the other side or on the cross benches who happens to be a so-called shadow Minister. I do not care about that. It does not worry me one iota whether that happens.

SPEECH.PARA: I was one of the senators who supported the right of an honourable senator to have his research assistants prepare, in conjunction with him, a speech for delivery in the chamber. I think that makes a lot of sense. I have heard people stand up in this chamber and speak off the top of their heads and when I have listened to them I have said to myself: 'What the heck is he talking about? He has not got a clue as to what he is talking about. He makes no sense to me'. Perhaps it would be better if he or she-I do not want to be considered a male chauvinist-were assisted by his or her research assistant or some of his or her constituents to prepare a sensible, rational speech for delivery in this place. I thought that was a sensible arrangement and I supported it. But there are those in this chamber who believe that that should not happen and supported the application of Standing Order 406, which says that no senator shall read his speech. Standing Order 406 is offended against time and again in this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a joke.

—It is not a joke. Senator McIntosh, if your so-called shadow Ministers can do it, why cannot I, as a back bencher, do it? Why should I be victimised because a so-called shadow Minister can read his speech? There is nothing in the Standing Orders which says anything about shadow Ministers. There is nothing in the Constitution that says anything about shadow Ministers.
—Or Ministers.
—Or Ministers. There is nothing at all that says anything about them. Yet you have the audacity to sit over there and say that your shadow Ministers should be allowed to read their speeches.
—Order! The honourable senator will address the Chair.

—I am sorry, Mr Deputy President, if I offended you. It does not matter whether it is someone on the Opposition benches or the cross benches or someone in the Ministry, as far as that is concerned. Why should they be in a privileged position compared to other honourable senators who are elected to this place to represent their constituencies, whether they be Victoria, New South Wales, Queensland, Western Australia, South Australia, Tasmania, the Northern Territory or the Australian Capital Territory? Why should they be in the privileged position of being able to come in here and read speeches which have been prepared by someone else and which look so beautiful in Hansard and have all the guys in the Press Gallery write them up, saying what great people they are; whereas some person who has come from a lowly background, who does not have that capacity and who stands up here and makes a speech that does not attract or appeal to the Press is left in limbo? I do not think that is fair at all. In my opinion, the privilege should apply to all honourable senators. I draw no distinction whatsoever between the other side of the chamber, the cross benches and the Government benches.

SPEECH.PARA: I come from a lowly background. Maybe there are times when I make speeches in this place which do not attract the media or anyone else because they are in simple language. I do not have someone writing speeches for me in flowery words and phrases. I do not speak for myself. I speak for someone who may come into this chamber with the same kind of lowly background as I have. I do not criticise the person about whom I raised the point of order tonight. But if we are to stick to Standing Orders, let us stick to them rigidly and make no exceptions whatsoever. As I said previously, Standing Order 406 states:
No Senator shall read his speech.

Again I apologise for the wording of the Standing Order. Maybe there was a time when there were only males in this place. But thanks be to God there are now ladies in this chamber. We should amend that Standing Order to state 'his or her speech' because ladies are also elected by the people and have every right to be in this chamber and they must accept the same responsibilities as their counterparts regarding the Standing Orders.

I do not apologise for raising this matter tonight. I do not apologise for calling to order an honourable senator who I believe was reading her speech, any more than I would apologise to any other person, male or female, who contrary to Standing Orders was reading a speech. I was one of those who fought valiantly in this chamber for the people who perhaps feel that they would better serve their constituency and the nation if they were allowed to read a prepared speech. I do not retreat from that position. I still maintain that that should be the right of every honourable senator. But if we are going to stick to Standing Order 406, let us stick to it rigidly and let there be no exceptions for so-called shadow Ministers. I cannot find any reference in the Standing Orders or in the Constitution to Shadow Ministers or, if it comes to that, to Ministers. We are failing in our duty under Standing Order 406 if we continue to allow it to go on .

It is all very well for the Deputy President or the President to say that someone is speaking from copious notes, or whatever they might be called. Forgive me; I may not have a complete grasp of the Queen's English on that word. But if we are to do that, we are stretching and are not sticking rigidly to Standing Order 406. I leave the matter with the Deputy President and the President for them to exercise their authority which is given to them under Standing Order 406.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I desire to join in this debate. I had no intention of doing so this evening but for some of the arrogance, ignorance and intimidation which I have received from some of my colleagues, on both sides of the chamber, outside the chamber this evening on the discussion on this subject, and knowing that this matter was being raised by Senator Bonner. I am not aware of the circumstances that occurred this evening. I did not hear the debate or the matter as it was raised by Senator Bonner at the time, and I am in no position to comment on the circumstances of the senator in question on this matter, although I am very interested in the views that Senator Bonner has raised on this subject.

SPEECH.PARA: As you know, Mr Deputy President, I raised this matter by way of motion before I left this country recently, and the matter was brought on with everyone knowing that I had to leave to catch an aeroplane shortly after 4.30 p.m. on that day. I was able to make a very short speech on that occasion and very briefly to explain my views, after which I believe that the debate in this chamber went on for about two hours. I have since had the opportunity to read the debate, and to appreciate some of the contributions in that debate, such as that of Senator Peter Baume and, although I disagree with him, that of Senator Bonner-made without notes and with great eloquence on that occasion. I believe that there were many speeches in that debate that indicated how well people could speak without using notes, or using only very bare notes on that occasion.

However, some of the things said in that debate were absolutely ridiculous. I had no chance to reply to that debate. I have resented the fact that it was brought on at a time when I was unable to take part in it in any way, apart from making an initial statement, and finding that persons in the Senate proceeded to work on the basis that what I was arguing at that time was that people should not use notes-which I have never said and I never indicated for one moment that I believe. I believe that people are fully entitled to use notes and ought to use them. If they need to bring before the chamber some matter which requires great accuracy, they ought to have leave to incorporate matters in debate. I have never for a moment suggested the contrary. Yet the debate proceded on that occasion as though I were suggesting what someone described tonight as schoolboy oratory, just off the top of the head, with no notes, and so forth. That is something to which I have never suggested that the Senate should descend.

I must disagree with my colleague, Senator Bonner, in one respect particularly- that it is not a matter of all or nothing. It is not a matter of no one being able to read anything to this chamber or else all being able to do it. In the motion that I put forward some months ago I made exceptions in the case of Ministers who are putting down a second reading speech, where accuracy is needed with regard to explaining the clauses and the details of a Bill, and which will go a long way. But I would have objected equally strongly to Ministers making their replies on Bills by reading them. Likewise, I object to shadow Ministers making their replies not from copious notes-they may use those-but reading them so that debate does not ensue and so that people do not enter into the spirit of debate and do not respond to interjections. The things in which this Senate was at its glory in the past are now, I regret, in something of the sinking stage of debate in this chamber. They are losing some ground.

I have returned to this country, as the President well knows, but before I left , when I learnt the result of the debate on my motion, I made it very clear by writing to the President that I was prepared to fight whatever guerrilla warfare was necessary if the Standing Orders Committee did not take some action to properly enforce the Standing Order. I am told by some of my colleagues: 'You must not touch this matter because this Standing Order might be taken out'. If the Senate is so gutless, if its members are so unable to uphold their Standing Orders and the things for which this Senate has been gloried, so be it. It is not my doing; it is the doing of honourable senators. I do not believe for a moment that they would be prepared to see the Standing Order taken away so that we degenerate to the stage of the House of Representatives, where even last night Mr Armitage, a member of that House, pleaded that speeches should no longer be allowed to be read. There are persons in that House who recognise the degeneration of the standard of debate in that House. I do not believe that honourable senators would be prepared to go the same way.

I have said that I do not believe that this is a matter which has to be all or nothing. In the letter that I wrote to the President before I left this country, I said that I hoped and expected that the Standing Orders Committee would raise and consider this matter. I am aware that at its last meeting it did not have time to reach this item, and that it is on the agenda for the next meeting. I have not raised points of order against honourable senators since I have been back here and since we have resumed debate in this chamber. Yet I have noted with pleasure the number of honourable senators who have told me that they have ceased to read their speeches. They are no longer doing that. I welcome that. One notes the improvements and the interest that their speeches engender because of that very fact.

I have not sought to make this a matter of confrontation. I have sought and hoped that the Standing Orders Committee will become strong in this matter and will lay down the conditions under which people may be permitted to read speeches and under which they may not do so. I have already said that I think there are some circumstances in which it is necessary. There are always circumstances in which an honourable senator may appeal to his colleagues, saying, 'I wish to read this for a particular reason', and get leave to do that. These things can always be done by leave. I believe that there is a reasonable situation here. However, unless we act, unless we stop the arrogant reading of speeches which has been taking place in this chamber for the last 18 months, unless the Standing Orders Committee faces up to the responsibility that it has a Standing Order to obey and then the Presiding Officers from time to time carry it out and do not, with a smile, talk about copious notes when they know that what is being read is word for word, I shall certainly, if nothing is done, take point of order after point of order. I shall make all the efforts that I can under the Standing Orders to ensure that something is done.

I assure Senator Bonner that I shall be with him very strongly in that matter. But I hope that, before that, the Standing Orders Committee will have grasped this nettle and will have taken some sensible course. I say to my colleagues who are not present tonight but who have abused me outside the chamber that I shall not be intimidated in the course I have undertaken, because I believe that the Senate is worth fighting for and I shall fight for it to the bitter end.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bonner Sen N.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of clarification-
—Do you seek leave?
—Yes, Mr Deputy President.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Missen said that he disagreed with me on the question that there are people who should be allowed to read their speeches. Standing Order 406 states: 'No Senator . . .' There is no distinction. Unless that Standing Order is changed, there is no exception. I do not think that we have a disagreement there. Senator Missen said that we have a disagreement on the matter. I have no disagreement with him on it whilst that Standing Order stands as it is. If the Standing Order is changed to allow for Ministers and shadow Ministers to read their speeches, I go along with it. At present, the whole basis of what I have said tonight is based on Standing Order 406 as it is at present. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: No Senator shall read his speech.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.30 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) On what occasions have economic sanctions or bans been applied by Australia against a trading partner in the past twenty years.
(2) What was the country involved in each case.
(3) What was (a) the nature; and (b) the period of the sanction.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (3) Information available is that economic sanctions or bans applied by Australia against a trading partner in the past twenty years have been as follows:
SOUTHERN RHODESIA
16 November 1965-18 December 1979
ban on import of Rhodesian tobacco
suspension of Commonwealth tariff preferences
amend definition of sterling area in the Banking (Foreign Exchange) Regulations to exclude Rhodesia
take action to prevent evasion of British exchange control measures
terminate appointment of Australian trade representative in Rhodesia
8 December 1965-18 December 1979
ban on import of Rhodesian ferro-alloys, chrome ore and asbestos
suspension of money order service between Australia and Rhodesia
2 September 1968-18 December 1979
control of entry into Australia and export from Australia of imports from and exports to Rhodesia under terms of paragraphs 3 and 4 of United Nations Security Council Resolution 253 (29 May 1968)
1 May 1970-18 December 1979
ban on export of anhydrous ammonia from Australia to any African destination
DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF VIETNAM
31 January 1969-22 May 1973

total prohibition of imports to and exports from the Democratic Republic of Vietnam. (There had previously been, from 1965 onwards, a ban on the export of tallow to the DRV, subsequently subsumed in the wider ban. The ban on tallow was applied to all Southeast Asia to prevent transhipment to the DRV).
SOUTH AFRICA

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 17 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many recommendations were made by the Review of Commonwealth Functions.
(2) How many of these recommendations have been implemented.
(3) Which recommendations have been implemented.
(4) Which recommendations have not been implemented.
(5) What savings overall have resulted from implementation of the recommendations.
(6) What savings individually have resulted from implementation of the recommendations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Some 350 decisions were taken in the context of the Review of Commonwealth Functions.

(2) to (4) Of these 350 decisions, most have been implemented or are in the course of implementation by Ministers, under the general oversight of the Review of Commonwealth Functions Committee of the Cabinet. The most significant area where decisions are still being implemented relates to the disposal of assets. Where assets are being sold, there has been a need for negotiations with interested persons or bodies to take place in accordance with established tendering and sale procedures and this has proved time-consuming. The administrative and legal issues involved have had to be resolved in a way which satisfies the interests of the employees, the prospective owners and the taxpayer.

The facilities of the Australian Wool Testing Authority were transferred to a new private sector company which commenced operations on 1 July 1982. It is anticipated that there will be substantial progress in relation to the disposal of other assets over the next few months.

(5) to (6) Financial savings have been and will continue to be made as a result of the Review, both directly and also indirectly arising from those measures designed to contribute over time to the efficiency of government. In a previous reply to the honourable senator (see the reply to Senate Question Nos 1257-1282 in the Senate Hansard for 23 February 1982, pages 297-8) it was explained why precise figuring of the type sought on savings cannot be provided. The effects of Review decisions on Budget outlays are combined with those of other government decisions and with variations in other factors affecting expenditures . It is not practicable to separate out the financial effects of each of the many interacting influences on the financial estimates.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 17 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of the ease with which school children in the United States have been able to crack the codes of some of the most sophisticated and confidential computers in that country.
(2) Is it possible for people in Australia to perform the same feats of these American schoolchildren and gain access to information stored in computers used by the Minister's Department.
(3) What security precautions have been taken to prevent such invasions of privacy.
(4) Does this ability to penetrate the secrecy of computers pose a grave security risk and leave hundreds of thousands of Australians open to blackmail and blatant invasion of privacy.
(5) Can the Minister give an assurance that confidential information related to his departmental files cannot be obtained by this method of 'plugging in' to computer systems.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) and (3) I understand that the unauthorised access referred to in the honourable senator's question relates to access by means of a telephone to various computing facilities. Most of my Department's present computing facilities do not allow any telephone access at all and are therefore totally secure from this type of access. Very limited telephone access is possible to the central development computer. However, adequate controls exist over access to the limited data on this computer, viz:
Only a very small number of officers are approved for access by the telephone link.
Knowledge of the telephone number to gain access is restricted to these officers who must identify themselves by special 'log-on' procedures and passwords.
Most data held on the computer is in an abridged statistical form (minus personal identification information) and most items of information are held as coded values.

A major computer re-equipment program for my Department is now under way which will increase the accessibility to data by departmental officers. Safeguards to ensure the highest practicable level of security will be important considerations when choosing the new computing equipment.

(5) All practical safeguards are being employed and these are continually under review. No absolute guarantee can be given but procedures ensure that the chances of unauthorised access to usable data are so low as to be regarded as non-existent.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory, upon notice, on 21 September 1982:

(4) How does the Minister account for the revised price, announced by him on 17 August 1982, of $370m as of March 1982, in view of the fact that the price in real terms, that is adjusted to the Australian cost of living index from a base figure of $220m, ought to have been $319m, arrived at as follows:
Cost including
Inflation compound Date
% p.a. interest
(5) What is the reason for the apparent price escalation of $51.4m in real terms.
(6) Can the Government give a positive assurance that no further cost increases in real terms will be permitted during the remainder of the building programme.
(7) What is the amount of architects' fees due to be paid on the current costing of the project.
(8) To whom, and in which country, will these fees be paid.

(9) What percentage of foreign ownership obtains in the case of the following companies concerned with the project: (a) Concrete Constructions Pty Ltd (Sydney ); (b) John Holland (Constructions) Pty Ltd (Sydney and Canberra); (c) Rawlinson , Roberts and Partners (Perth); and (d) McLachlan Group (Sydney).
(10) Was it estimated in September 1981 that 'non-building items' such as artworks and furnishings would cost an additional $82m.
(11) What is the estimate now.
(12) Will that estimate increase in pace with the Consumer Price Index.
(13) Will the Government undertake that the estimate will not increase in real terms.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Capital Territory has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The building cost of $156m in May 1978 dollars was the figure provided by the winning architect in accordance with the competition conditions which required each competitor to provide 'a broad order of costs'. The competition assessors had the estimates generally reviewed by an independent cost planner and reported to the Authority that 'we are as satisfied as we can be at this stage that the Competition Winner's cost estimate is generally credible and realistic'. However the estimate is 'subject to detailed confirmation, and it may be that on further investigation and analysis, in consultation with the architect, there will prove to have been some areas of underestimation . . . it must be noted that several significant ''optional'' features of the design . . . '.

The Construction Authority in its report, tabled in the Senate on 21 August 1980, advised that it was 'essential that a realistic estimate of the cost of the building be established at this stage which recognises the extent of the scope of work portrayed by the conceptual models and drawings submitted and endeavours to anticipate what will ultimately be required when those concepts have been developed for the final construction and presentation of the building. ' To this end, 'intensive examination and discussions have taken place between the winning architects, the Authority's Project Manager and the selected Construction Manager, Cost Planner and Project Planner. As a result, the Authority is convinced that a realistic estimate of the cost to build the winner 's design concept is $220m at May 1978 prices'.
(2) Yes.
(3) As reported to the Senate on 21 August 1980, there were a number of specific items which increased the $151m base price for a notional building. These were:

Increase in usable area by about 20 per cent over the design brief to allow for larger public and ceremonial areas and other spaces where future expansion would not be practical such as basement and service areas-$29m.
Underground car parking, not specified in original brief-$18m.
Site works and landscaping to implement the unique solution of the winning design, which relies on a landscaping rather than architectural concept for its success-$13m.
Energy saving devices to achieve substantial reductions in building operating costs-$5m.
Greater than anticipated areas devoted to ceremonial and public spaces demanded higher standard of finishes-$5m.

(4) The budget for the building is updated to reflect the inflationary effects of movements in the cost of wages and materials specifically in the building industry in the Australian Capital Territory. The 'Australian cost of living index' referred to in the question does not equate to movements in the costs of building and is therefore an inappropriate means of updating the building budget .

The Government has adopted an index calculated independently by the Department of Transport and Construction as the basis for updating the building budget. This index is derived by measuring the actual variation in costs of a large number of representative building components and applying this aggregated factor to the building budget after deducting work completed. The index is therefore a measure of the real increase in building costs rather than an indication of general movements in prices.

(5) The $370.4m budget at March 1982 prices reported to Parliament on 17 August 1982, is made up of the original $220m at May 1978 prices plus $141.5m for inflation based on the approved index, plus $8.9m for additional requirements previously approved by Parliament. The base building budget has been adjusted to reflect the approved variations and therefore there has been no price escalation in real terms.

(6) The Parliament House project receives regular and on-going scrutiny by both Houses through the Joint Standing Committee on the new Parliament House. Only where proposed changes are approved by the Committee and Government are they implemented by the Construction Authority. To date the changes approved by Parliament amount to less than 3 per cent of the building budget. Under this system it is Parliament which exercises strict control over the budget.
(7) The estimated fees due to be paid to the Architects is $15.315m in March 1982 dollars.
(8) The architects' fees will be paid to Mitchell/Giurgola and Thorp, Architects in Australia.

(a) Concrete Constructions Pty Limited is fully owned by Concrete Constructions Holdings Pty Limited, a company incorporated in the Australian Capital Territory and which has foreign ownership of 14.8 per cent.

(b) John Holland (Constructions) is a fully owned subsidiary of John Holland ( Holdings) Ltd. Ownership of the shares in the public company is almost exclusively in the hands of Australians, foreign ownership being less than 1 per cent.
(c) No foreign ownership obtains in the case of Rawlinson Roberts and Partners.
(d) No foreign ownership obtains in the case of the McLachlan Group.

(10) Yes. The figure foreshadowed the cost of providing items required for the fitting out of the building and not included in the building budget such as furniture, sound and vision broadcasting equipment, internal and external communications equipment, kitchen equipment, document/goods movement systems, waste disposal systems, security equipment, high voltage electrical equipment and artworks.
(11) $92.3m at March 1982 prices.

(12) The consumer price index would not be an appropriate measure of the effects of inflation on these items. The budget will be updated by an approved index calculated in a similar way to the building index but using factors which more accurately reflect movements in the cost of individual components which make up each non building item.
(13) As with the building budget, the budget for non building items will not increase in real terms except with the approval of Parliament and the Government .

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 22 September 1982:

(2) Does the Report refer to the effects of changes in the general economic climate leading to more students being in need and to more calls on students assistance schemes including emergency loan services.
(3) Will the Budget-announced increases in the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme and Commonwealth Post-Graduate Awards bring substantial relief to students as described in the Report.

(4) Is the Report evidence that the student loan scheme proposed by the Government would be so welcomed by tertiary students that the amount of $50m for the 1983 academic year is likely to be fully taken up.

(5) Does the Report urge individual institutions, especially in the College of Advanced Education and Technical and Further Education sectors, to take more responsibility for the development of student services.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) Yes. The study, which explored the appropriateness of the services to the needs and priorities of students, noted that a number of circumstances, including scarcity of part-time and vacation employment, were increasing the demand for emergency financial help offered by institutions.

(3) Yes. It is expected that the increases in allowance levels for TEAS and PGA announced in the Budget will lead to a substantial improvement in the financial situation of students receiving allowances as from 1 January 1983. The TEAS living allowance is being increased by 20 per cent-a significant increase in real terms-and the PGA living allowance is being increased by 48 per cent.

(4) The report does not indicate the extent to which students will seek support through the Tertiary Student Loans Scheme. Nevertheless a considerable number of students will be eligible for assistance under the Scheme and the indications are that many are likely to avail themselves of its benefits.

The Scheme will help meet the needs of students who are experiencing financial difficulties. It will provide an additional source of support for students eligible for TEAS and other student assistance schemes as well as for students, who though ineligible for direct assistance, satisfy a simple means test.
