TALK.START.PARA: —On 20 May 1982 (Hansard, page 2213) Senator McLaren asked the Minister for Finance the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Noting that the $121,700 appropriated in the Additional Estimates for the Department of Administrative Services for a mailing service for the Government Information Unit represents $2,300 a week, if it is for a whole year, I ask whether it is in fact for a whole year or for only part of a year. If it is not over a year, what is to be the weekly cost over a full year? I further ask whether her Department or any other Department will conduct any kind of effectiveness audit of this service?
The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Government Information Unit provides a service whereby information papers relating to Government policies and programs can be distributed quickly following announcements to selected interest groups. Distributions are not on fixed or regular dates or to a constant number of recipients. Costs vary therefore from week to week. The year 1981-82 was the initial year of operation of the scheme and the requirement was difficult to anticipate. In the event an amount of $23,847 was expended between March and June 1982. The effectiveness of such mailings is kept under close review by the Government Information Unit and by the Department concerned. In general this may be judged by the number of people seeking further information. While this response varies, experience suggests that the service is greatly appreciated by recipients.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 August 1982 (Hansard, page 394) Senator McLaren asked me as the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Has the Government received any representation from the South Australian Premier, Mr Tonkin, for assistance in preventing the cellulose paper mill at Millicent from closing, with the resultant loss of more than 300 jobs?
The Acting Minister for Industry and Commerce has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
There have been discussions between the Premier of South Australia and the Acting Minister for Industry and Commerce concerning the Millicent mill.
The South Australian Government has been kept informed of the company's intentions and discussions between that Government, the company and the trade unions have been scheduled.

The company operating the Millicent mill, Australian Paper Manufacturing Ltd, announced on 15 September its intention to close the number 2 paperboard machine at Millicent in South Australia on 5 November 1982. The mechanical pulp mill at Millicent will continue to operate.
The intended closure of the paper machine is attributed to technological changes in the paperboard industry which have resulted in a rapid decline in the demand for the machine's products.

Should the machine close on 5 November 1982 as the company intends some 150 jobs could be affected. The company will enlist the assistance of the Commonwealth Employment Service and the Department of Social Security in trying to minimise any hardship.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 September 1981 (Handard, page 560), Senator Bolkus asked the Leader of the Government in the Senate a question without notice concerning the collection of statistics on foreign investment in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Australian Bureau of Statistics does collect statistics relating to the inflow and level of foreign investment in Australia. These statistics are published on a quarterly basis. In addition to measuring the magnitude of flows and levels of investment, the statistics are classified in a variety of ways- principally by type of investment, country of investor and industry of investment.

Prior to 1978 the Bureau also compiled and published statistics on foreign ownership and control of industry sectors in Australia. In that year, following an assessment of relative priorities within the Bureau given available resources, a decision was taken by the Statistician, and supported by the Government, to discontinue the statistics on foreign ownership and control.

However, in a statement on 20 January 1982 concerning the outcome of a review of foreign investment policy by the Government, I indicated among other things that I had requested the Australian Bureau of Statistics to re-introduce the surveys measuring the extent of foreign ownership and control in sectors of the Australian economy.

On 7 September 1982 the Acting Treasurer announced that the Statistician had examined a number of matters related to the resumption of the surveys. As a result of this examination, the ABS is to recommence a program of foreign participation studies. In order to retain simple and objective criteria for classifying companies, the concepts, definitions and measures used for the new series will be similar to those used in previously published statistics of foreign ownership and control. The main change will be that, as far as possible , separate aggregates will be published for naturalised and naturalising companies, and for joint Australian/foreign controlled enterprises, which would otherwise come within the statistical definition of foreign control. The first publication, which is planned for release in the second half of 1983, will relate to foreign ownership and control of the mining industry and selected minerals processing industries for the year ended 30 June 1982. Work will also be started on the preparation of foreign participation statistics for other sectors including manufacturing and possibly agricultural industries.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 15 September 1982 (Hansard, page 919) Senator Siddons asked me a question without notice concerning the steel industry.

ANSWER.PARA: In my reply to the honourable senator, I undertook to seek further information from my colleague the Minister for Trade and Resources regarding Taiwan and South Korea. The Minister for Trade and Resources has provided me with the information necessary to allow me to complete my answer to the honourable senator's question.

The facts supplied by the honourable senator concerning the import regimes in Taiwan and South Korea appear generally to be correct. While the import regimes established by Taiwan and South Korea provide for licensing of importers and controls on imports, it is worth noting that Australia's exports of iron and steel (excluding wastes and scrap) to Taiwan in 1981-82 (preliminary details only) were of the order of $15.5m as compared with our imports of these goods from Taiwan which approximated $4.4m.

During the same year our exports of these goods to South Korea were about 23. 3m compared with imports from that country of approximately $49.4m. This imbalance in favour of Korea being at least partly attritutable to Australia's cost disadvantages against that country in the world market.

If we have regard to Australia's exports of iron ores and concentrates to these countries which in 1981-82 amounted to about $32.7m for Taiwan and $83.4m for South Korea it becomes obvious that Australia has had a large surplus in its trade exchanges with the steel industries in those countries.

As was stated in the earlier answer to this question, the Government has pegged imports at 1981-82 levels. This accords the steel industry a breathing space during which its case for long-term assistance can be reported on by the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) and considered by the Government. In taking this action the Government was mindful of the potential cost implications for downstream users and for the economy as a whole, of any action which increased the price of steel.

At the same time the Government has set up a consultative body, the Steel Industry Council, including union, producer, user and importer representatives, to advise the Government on matters pertaining to the industry's viability and structure, employment aspects and future development. I am sure that honourable senators will all agree that Australia should be seeking to develop and efficient and profitable steel industry.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 16 September 1982 (Hansard, page 1004) Senator Robert Ray asked me, as Minister representing the Prime Minister, a question without notice concerning the tabling of an extract from the Costigan report. I undertook to provide him with answers to the following questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) Whether the Prime Minister consulted with the Victorian State Government before tabling the synopsis of the unpublished Costigan report?
(b) If he did not, what explanation can the Minister provide for the Prime Minister's action?
The Prime Minister has supplied the following information in answer to the honourable senator's questions:

Commissioner Costigan's letter of 6 September 1982, incorporated in Senate Hansard (pages 653-4) on 7 September at the time of tabling the edited Chapter 10 of the Royal Commission's Interim Report No. 4, outlined the background to the provision of that chapter in a form suitable for publication. Mr Costigan wrote to the Victorian Premier and me in response to requests from the two Governments for review of the recommendation that Volumes 2 and 3 of the Report be kept confidential, indicating that it was for the Governments to determine the extent of publication of Chapter 10.

Commonwealth officers were in contact with the Royal Commission prior to tabling the report and gained the impression, mistakenly it subsequently appears, that the Victorian Government had advised the Royal Commission of its agreement that the edited Chapter 10 be published. I have since written to the Victorian Premier explaining how this misunderstanding arose.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 September Senator Watson (Hansard, page 1044) asked me a question without notice concerning the Conzinc Riotinto proposal for solution mining of gold. I asked my Department to give me information concerning the use of the cyanide process elsewhere and whether or not there are stringent rules regarding health.

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised that the proposed CRA operation will be the first of its type in the world. My Department is not aware of any other operation in the world which uses in situ leaching techniques to mine gold. However, a similar technique using acid/alkaline solutions rather than cyanide has been used for many years in the in situ extraction of uranium in the United States.

Solution mining involves the pumping of chemical solutions into the ground via injection wells with the objective of dissolving certain metals. The process is controlled by varying the amount of solution extracted at the recovery wells and is monitored by means of a series of wells situated around the periphery of the extraction zone. The technique is safe provided it can be demonstrated that the chemical solutions introduced into the groundwater can be contained within the area of interest and recovered without permanently polluting the local groundwater.

In this context, CRA has reported that the groundwater at the Eastville site is almost stationary and that tests with dyes have indicated that solutions pumped into the aquifer can be contained within the defined areas and can be recovered when required.

CRA's field research at the Eastville site has been conducted under a Management Plan approved by the Victorian Minister for Mines and Energy and supervised by officials from his Department. Furthermore, a Preliminary Environmental Report on the proposed field trials using cyanide solutions has been prepared by CRA at the request of the Victorian Minister for Conservation and is available for public comment.

I understand that following a period of public review, the Victorian Minister for Conservation will be preparing an Assessment Report for the Victorian Minister for Minerals and Energy. On the basis of such information the Victorian Government will take the final decision on whether solution mining for gold could proceed, if it were to prove economically viable.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Tax Avoidance: Appointment of Special Prosecutor

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 September 1982 (Hansard, page 1044) Senator Gietzelt asked the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question is directed to the Minister representing the Acting Attorney- General. Are reports in the Australian Financial Review of 20 September to the effect that the Government is having difficulty in finding a barrister suitable for appointment as special prosecutor for the prosecution of bottom-of-the- harbour tax avoidance schemes true? Specifically, have barristers considered been rejected after scrutiny by the Australian Taxation Office? What are the reasons for some barristers being found unacceptable? When will the Government be announcing the appointment of the special prosecutor?
The Acting Attorney-General has supplied the following answer:

Mr Roger Gyles Q.C. of the Sydney Bar was appointed Special Prosecutor on 22 September 1982. At that time, the Acting Attorney-General issued a Press statement outlining Mr Gyles's experience and stating that he will be supported by a special task force.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 17 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has a directive been issued by the permanent head of the Department of Finance requiring officers of that Department to establish a parallel system of files to contain Cabinet minutes, Cabinet submissions and, dating back to 1974, all documents leading to Cabinet submissions.
(2) Is it the case that the last-mentioned category is so broad as to potentially include nearly every document generated by the Department.
(3) Will the effect of this directive be to circumvent the operation of the Freedom of Information Act when it eventually comes into operation.
(4) Is the Attorney-General aware of similar directives being given in other, and if so which, departments.
(5) Has the advice or approval of the Attorney-General's Department been sought or obtained in relation to the directive or directives referred to.

(6) What steps are being taken by the Attorney-General's Department to ensure that the proper administration of the Freedom of Information Act is not being prejudiced and undermined by internal arrangements of the kind referred to.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Acting Attorney-General has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1)-(3) These matters fall within the administration of the Minister for Finance. The Minister for Finance has advised me that no directive along the lines referred to in Part (1) of the honourable senator's question has been issued within the Department of Finance, and that, in particular, no departmental directives or guidelines issued by the Permanent Head or any other officer have referred to 'documents leading to Cabinet submissions', either in the context of the Freedom of Information Act or otherwise. The long-standing requirement that all departments maintain a separate series of Cabinet files is not intended specifically to facilitate the administration of the Freedom of Information Act but neither does it circumvent or frustrate the administration of that Act.
(5) Not applicable.

(6) My Department has, with the assistance of the Public Service Board, conducted extensive training programs to acquaint officers of departments and statutory authorities with the requirements of the Freedom of Information Act. Details of the programs conducted between 12 June 1981 and 26 May 1982 involving some 1,200 officers were given in the answer by the Attorney-General to a question by Senator Missen (Senate Hansard, 26 May 1982, page 2487).

Further training programs are now being conducted. The current series of seminars, which began on 13 September 1982, are being attended by some 2,500 officers of the public service and of statutory authorities in Canberra and in the mainland State capitals. In addition, my Department is issuing written guidelines on the more important aspects of the Act. These guidelines explain, amongst other things, the purposes of the Act and the obligations which it imposes on agencies. My Department will be monitoring the operation of the legislation and would take up with the agency concerned any practice considered to be contrary to the legislation. It might be noted that there is a statutory obligation to include in the annual reports to be furnished under the Act information as to the efforts by my Department to assist agencies to comply with their obligations under the Act.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Support, upon notice, on 17 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What chain was purchased from overseas for (a) the Navy; (b) the Air Force; and (c) the Army in the financial year 1981-82.

(2) From what countries were these purchases made, what was the purchase price in each case, which Australian firms tendered in each case and what were the details of the tenders of the Australian firms for each of the services.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Support has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No chain was purchased from overseas sources by the Department of Defence Support or the Department of Administrative Services during 1981-1982 on behalf of Navy/Air Force/Army. However, the Department of Defence undertakes its own purchasing in respect of supplies valued at less than the public tender threshold ($10,000) and may place purchase requests direct on overseas posts. The Department of Defence Support would have no record of such purchases.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 17 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What possible justification could the Government provide for the proposed termination of Master of Business Administration (MBA) evening studies at the Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology (an institute which has a longer tradition in management education than any other tertiary body in Australia), as proposed in the recently released Commonwealth Inquiry into Management Education .

(2) Is the Government aware that if the Inquiry's full recommendations are implemented in Victoria, only those students who have the necessary individual wealth or who are able to obtain total or weekly day release from their employment over several years will be able to undertake an MBA.
(3) Can the Government give an 'in principle' commitment that part-time evening courses in business administration, which offer the widest opportunities for in- service education, will be encouraged.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (2) and (3) The Report of the Inquiry into Management Education (the Ralph report) recommended, inter alia, that the MBA program at the Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology, and a number of other MBA programs be discontinued. I made a statement to Parliament on 9 September this year concerning the Government's decision on the report's recommendations. I stated that the Government agreed in principle with the report's strategy of rationalising programs and concentrating resources in management education. I also indicated, however, that the Ralph Committee did not state the criteria used for differentiating between institutions nor did it set out an overall program to meet the varied needs in each State for access to different levels and forms of courses in business administration.

There has been considerable criticism from RMIT and other institutions which stand to have their course offerings curtailed if certain of the report's recommendaations are implemented. State Governments have also expressed their concern.

The Government's objective is to provide wide access to a range of management education programs (full time and part time courses) of the highest possible standard. These programs should meet the great diversity of education needs now faced by managers. Consequently the Government has asked the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission to invite submissions from State authorities and institutions on how best to achieve in each State the rationalisation of courses and concentration of resources envisaged by the Ralph Committee. The Commission is to report by March 1983.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Attorney-General made himself aware of the decision referred to in my question without notice of 24 February 1982 (see Hansard, page 390); if so, is he prepared to meet the legal cost involved by Mr Hall in the litigation in question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Acting Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I believe that the decision to which the honourable senator has referred is Attorney-General v Lundin in which the High Court of Justice in England held that a journalist was not obliged to reveal the name of a source of evidence as this information was not necessary in the interests of justice and could have served no useful purpose in the particular proceedings. As to Mr Hall's legal costs in the proceedings for contempt of a royal commission, he may wish to make an application for legal aid to the Australian Legal Aid Office or to apply to the Attorney-General for legal or financial assistance. If he should make such an application it would be considered in accordance with the relevant directive and the means and needs test guidelines of the office or the relevant criteria for the provision of legal or financial assistance. I mention, however, that for many years it has been the practice of the ALAO not to grant aid to cover legal expenses incurred prior to the making of the application for legal aid. If Mr Hall makes an application it would be necessary for him to show that exceptional circumstances exist to justify a retrospective grant of aid or assistance. If he is able to do so the application would be looked at as it would have been looked at had it been made in good time. A similar approach is taken in relation to applications to the Attorney-General for legal or financial assistance.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

(2) Has the estimated cost escalated since 1970 and if so, does it now appear that $40m is required to complete the scheme. Does it not seem that if the Commonwealth Government continues its funding at only $1m per annum, while the Queensland Government contributes $1.3m per annum, there is little likelihood of this scheme being completed within at least another twenty years.

(3) Why has not equal consideration been given to adequate funding of the Eton irrigation scheme in view of the agreement by the Government to contribute substantially to the Bundaberg irrigation scheme and the Burdekin dam project.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) While about $40m is still required to complete the project, its scope is now wider than that proposed when the Commonwealth made a commitment of support in 1973. This year, the Commonwealth is offering $1.8m to the State towards the cost of the project under the National Water Resources Program. This represents an increase of 80 per cent over last year's allocation.

(3) The Eton irrigation project has not been accorded a very high priority for Commonwealth assistance by the Queensland Government under the National Water Resources Program. It has not been possible, therefore, to meet in full the State's request for funds for the project after the requirements of higher priorities have been met within the overall Budget appropriation for the program .

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Elimination of Water Hyacinth, Warehouse Beetle and Blue-green Spotted Aphid

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 15 September 1982 (Hansard, page 922) Senator Teague asked me a question without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate. His question concerned the elimination of water hyacinth, warehouse beetle, blue-green aphid and spotted alfalfa aphid.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Water hyacinth, warehouse beetle, blue-green aphid and spotted alfalfa aphid are considered established in Australia to the point where eradication is not feasible. Consequently control measures are necessarily aimed at ensuring the economic costs of these pests are minimized as far as possible.

A biological control program was initiated to control water hyacinth in 1975. To date, two insects which feed on water hyacinth have been released and are well established in Australia. Currently, other insects which attack water hyacinth in South America, are being sought to extend the control already achieved, to a wider range of habitats in which the weed occurs.

The Standing Committee on Agriculture Consultative Committee on Warehouse Beetle decided at its last meeting in Gunnedah, New South Wales in July 1981 that the eradication attempt started in 1977 was no longer feasible, in view of new occurrences in New South Wales. It was decided that a control program funded jointly by the Commonwealth and States be co-ordinated by New South Wales to control warehouse beetle infestations in New South Wales, for a period of one year. The control program is currently underway and will terminate in December 1982, after which time control measures will be the responsibility of the State in which the infestation occurs.

The blue-green aphid and the spotted alfalfa aphid were detected in Australia in 1977. A combination of resistent lucerne varieties, insect parasites and predators, fungal pathogens, management practices and sprays have been employed to control lucerne aphids. In most regions, this combination of control measures, have reduced losses due to lucerne aphids to a fraction of those encountered when the aphids first arrived.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 September 1982 (Hansard, page 1192) Senator Lewis asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is it a fact, as reported, that the Dumping Branch of the Department of Industry and Commerce currently has before it some 68 complaints from Australian industry and that notwithstanding the increased staff levels provided last year, inquiries are taking up to 12 months to resolve.
Will the Government give consideration to imposing some trade sanctions against countries dumping in Australia by imposing, say, import bans for a set period.
Will the Government also give consideration to contracting some of the investigatory work to private enterprise in order to speed up investigations during this period of economic recession.
The Minister for Industry and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

As at 7 October 1982 the Department of Industry and Commerce had 67 formal cases on hand, an increase of 36.7 per cent over the number on hand 12 months earlier. On 8 October 1982 the Public Service Board approved an additional 15 positions for the Dumping Branch. This increase should result in a further speeding up of completion of dumping complaints.
